text: Perception of the environment requires developing models of and differentiating between externally and self-generated sensations.  We will discuss joint theoretical and experimental efforts that provide a detailed account of how specific neural circuitry and plasticity mechanisms support a well-defined and ethologically relevant neural computation of this type.  Past work has suggested that cerebellum-like circuitry in weakly electric mormyrid fish serves to predict and cancel self-generated input related to a stereotyped motor behavior--the electric organ discharge. We will discuss how such predictions, termed negative images, are generated at the circuit level: including how brief, highly stereotyped motor command signals are transformed into longer-lasting and more diverse temporal patterns in granule cells, the critical role for spike timing-dependent plasticity in sculpting negative images, and how the temporal structure of granule cell responses appears matched to the self-generated sensory input and also explains unexpected features of negative images. We will also discuss how these mechanisms may be extended to understand the more complex and ubiquitous problem of predicting the sensory consequences of movements.
title: From Sensation to Perception: Sensory predictions in an electric fish

text: Inhibitory neurons alter the computations performed by their target cells via two fundamental operations, division and subtraction. We show in mouse visual cortex in vivo that the critical feature underlying specific operations by somatostatin (SOM) and parvalbumin (PV) expressing neurons, the two inhibitory neuron classes that target pyramidal neurons,  is their response mode relative to target neurons. In particular, SOM neurons respond at long latencies to briefly flashed small visual stimuli, and provide subtractive inhibition when probed optogenetically with single pulses. With large stimuli, however, they respond at short latencies coincident with their target cells, and they switch to provide divisive inhibition crucial for gain control, similar to PV neurons.
title: The functional logic of cortical circuits

text: Cortical neurons tend to show great heterogeneity in response properties during behavior. For instance, neurons in prefrontal cortex can encode mixtures of sensory, motor and other features with unique temporal dynamics, resulting in a ‘cortical response zoo’ that complicates the interpretation of neural responses. There is similar diversity in the cell-type-specific architecture of cortex, leading to the hypothesis that response heterogeneity may be in part explained by different neuron types. My talk will explore this hypothesis in the context of cortical inhibitory interneurons. To gain a better understanding into the behavioral roles of interneurons we employed an optogenetics-assisted cell type identification technique that allows us to electrophysiologically record from genetically identified neurons in freely moving mice. We studied the three major classes of interneurons, somatostatin  and parvalbumin-expressing interneurons, which regulate the input and output of pyramidal neurons, respectively, and vasointestinal peptide-expressing interneurons that control other inhibitory interneurons. I will describe our results revealing that different interneuron types are recruited at specific behavioral moments and conditions. Thus the function of interneurons may go beyond network coordination at fast time scales. In conclusion I will describe an emerging model in which interneurons exert control over cortical information flow by selectively gating and modulating different input and output channels at behavioral time scales and governed by behavioral requirements.
title: Mapping the behavioral repertoire of cortical interneurons

text: Using millisecond-timescale voltage-sensitive dye imaging in lightly anesthetized or awake adult mice, we show that a palette of sensory-evoked and hemisphere-wide activity motifs are represented in spontaneous activity within the delta frequency band. These motifs can reflect multiple modes of sensory processing, including vision, audition and touch. We found similar cortical networks with direct cortical activation using channelrhodopsin-2. Regional analysis of activity spread indicated modality-specific sources, such as primary sensory areas, a common posterior-medial cortical sink where sensory activity was extinguished within the parietal association area and a secondary anterior medial sink within the cingulate and secondary motor cortices for visual stimuli. Correlation analysis between functional circuits and intracortical axonal projections indicated a common framework corresponding to regional long-range monosynaptic connections between cortical regions (defined using the Allen Inst. mouse connectivity atlas). Similar maps were observed with other indicators of neuronal activity such as intracellular calcium and measures of neurotransmitter release (glutamate imaging).  We anticipate that knowledge of these core structural and functional maps will be critical for study of both normal experience dependent changes to networks,  as well as pathological changes to following diseases such as stroke.
title: Imaging and optogenetic tools for elucidating cortical circuit structure-function after stroke

text: Findings regarding patterns of auditory spectro-temporal receptive fields have inspired new approaches in machine listening: For instance, models of receptive fields were modified and applied to problems in spoken language processing. This auditory approach helped to lower error rates of various speech tasks, thereby bridging the gap between human speech recognition and automatic classification. On the other hand, methods in machine listening such as auditory-inspired feature extraction or multi-layer neural networks are by now sufficiently elaborate to improve psychoacoustic or physiological models. Examples include the prediction of human speech intelligibility and models of neural transformations in the human auditory cortex. This talk presents several of these examples that highlight the mutual benefit of research of biological systems and machine learning.
title: Machine listening and computational auditory neuroscience models - a relation with mutual benefits

text: Retinal degeneration leads to blindness due to gradual loss of photoreceptors. Information can be reintroduced into the visual system by patterned electrical stimulation of the remaining retinal neurons. Photovoltaic subretinal prosthesis directly converts light into pulsed electric current in each pixel, stimulating the nearby inner retinal neurons. Visual information is projected onto the retina by video goggles using pulsed near-infrared (~900nm) light. Subretinal arrays with 70mm photovoltaic pixels provide highly localized stimulation:  retinal ganglion cells respond to alternating gratings with the stripe width of a single pixel, which is half of the native resolution in healthy controls (~30mm). Similarly to normal vision, retinal response to prosthetic stimulation exhibits flicker fusion at high frequencies (>20 Hz), adaptation to static images, and non-linear summation of subunits in the receptive fields. In rats with retinal degeneration, the photovoltaic subretinal arrays provide visual acuity up to half of its normal level (~1 cpd), as measured by the cortical response to alternating gratings. If these results translate to human retina, such implants could restore visual acuity up to 20/250. With eye scanning and perceptual learning, human patients might even cross the 20/200 threshold of legal blindness. Ease of implantation and tiling of these wireless modules to cover a large visual field, combined with high resolution opens the door to highly functional restoration of sight.
title: Restoration of Sight with Photovoltaic Subretinal Prosthesis

text: Myoelectric control consists in the recording of EMG signals for extracting control signals to command external devices, such as hand prostheses. In commercial systems, the intensity of muscle activity is extracted from the EMG and used for single degree of freedom activation (direct control). Over the past 60 years, the academic research has progressed to more sophisticated approaches but, surprisingly, none of these academic achievements has been implemented in commercial systems so far. The academic state-of-the-art relies on pattern recognition as a method to control multiple motor tasks using a relatively small number of electrodes. After several decades of development, this approach still shows major limitations, thus a change of focus on myocontrol research may be needed. Novel approaches, recently proposed, include techniques for simultaneous and proportional control of multiple degrees of freedom, which are based on regression methods. Moreover, it seems evident that the exclusive use of EMG as a source for feed-forward control of prostheses poses important limitations. These limits can be partly overcome by including additional sensors, within semiautonomous systems. Finally, sensory feedback is essential in prosthetic control, thus there is the need to introduce robust and intuitive methods for sensory substitution. The talk will cover these approaches with a discussion on the major challenges in filling the gap between commercial/clinical and academic methods for myocontrol.
title: The Extraction of Neural Information from the Surface EMG for the Control of Upper-Limb Prostheses: Emerging Avenues and Challenges

text: The perceived qualities of sounds, such as the pitch or direction of a baby's cry, or the quality and type of a speech sound, are not so much external, objective properties of incoming sound waves, but rather "an interpretation" of the sounds, which stems from the neural processing of the auditory information. Much previous work has speculated about the existence of specialized pathways for the processing of either pitch or space or timbre, either in topographic maps or specialized streams. In this talk I will summarize recent work which questions this view and instead proposes a closely intertwined neural representation of the perceived features of real world sounds.
title: Neural representations of the pitch, timbre and source location of complex sounds

text: Through the combination of in vivo two-photon microscopy and chronic expression of genetically encoded calcium indicators it has recently become feasible to directly 'watch' neuronal population dynamics in the neocortex of awake, head-restrained mice during specific behaviors. I will introduce the current state-of-the-art approaches for in vivo calcium imaging and present examples of the recent application of for measuring neocortical dynamics in behaving mice. For example, we train mice in a texture discrimination task and analyze the activation patterns of identified cortico-cortically projecting neurons. We also utilize running wheels to study aspects of the cortical control of locomotion. I will discuss how these types of experiments can help to decipher the neural codes in the neocortex under behaviorally relevant conditions.
title: In vivo calcium imaging of information processing in mouse neocortex during behavior

text: The principle of efficient coding has been quite successful in explaining the tuning of neurons to sensory stimuli across a diversity of systems (e.g. work by Olshausen & Field, Smith & Lewicki, Salinas, among others). Balanced networks have been successful in providing mechanistic explanations for the irregularity of firing in neural systems, and have led to the subsequent experimental verification of a balance between inhibitory and excitatory conductances (e.g. work by Shadlen & Newsome, van Vreeswijk & Sompolinksy, Brunel, etc.). We here show that both theories can be derived from a single principle: efficient coding with spikes. Starting with this simple objective, we show how a network of integrate-and-fire neurons can learn to first balance itself and then encode its inputs efficiently, using only local learning rules. Both the integrate-and-fire network dynamics, and the learning rules, are directly derived from objective functions. One consequence of our theory is a networks' ability to instantaneously restore its function when part of a circuit is perturbed or knocked out. This optimal compensation leads to instantaneous changes in the tuning of neurons after perturbations, and we compare our theoretical results with experimental knock-out studies in several sensory systems. The limits of restoration depend on the nature of the disruption. [Joint work with David Barrett, Ralph Bourdoukan, Wieland Brendel, Pietro Vertecchi, and Sophie Deneve.]
title: Efficient Coding and Balanced Networks: A Unification

text: This lecture describes recent advances in our understanding of the neural mechanisms responsible for some forms of decision-making. A common framework, known as bounded evidence accumulation or sequential sampling, explains the speed and accuracy of a decision. Recent studies from our lab suggest that this framework also extends to the assignment of confidence that a decision is likely to be correct. I will describe neural recording and microstimulation experiments from nonhuman primates which reveal a common mechanism underling the speed, accuracy and confidence in a decision.
title: Predicting the accuracy of a decision: A neural mechanism for confidence

text: Psychological and neurophysiological studies of decision-making have focused primarily on scenarios in which subjects are faced with choices that are stable in time, permitting a serial process of representing the relevant information, careful deliberation about the choice, followed by action planning and execution. However, the brain evolved to interact with a dynamic and constantly changing world, in which the choices themselves as well as their relative costs and benefits are defined by the momentary geometry of the immediate environment and are continuously changing during ongoing activity. To deal with the demands of real-time interactive behavior, animals require a neural architecture in which the sensorimotor specification of potential actions, their valuation, selection, and even execution can all take place in parallel. I will describe a general hypothesis for how the brain deals with the challenges of such dynamic and embodied behavior. I will then present the results of a series of behavioral and neurophysiological experiments in which humans and monkeys make decisions on the basis of sensory information that changes over time. These experiments suggest that sensory information pertinent to decisions is processed quickly and combined with a growing signal related to the urge to act, and the result biases a competition between potential actions that takes place within the same sensorimotor circuits that guide action. I will also show data suggesting that a common mechanism controls both the urgency to make a decision as well as the vigor of the selected movement, yielding a unified policy for maximizing reward rates.
title: Neural mechanisms for making decisions in a dynamic world

text: In this talk, I will present the dynamics of neuronal activity in two areas of the posterior parietal cortex that support looking and reaching, area LIP and the parietal reach region, PRR. We identify neurons in area LIP and PRR that fire coherently with LFP activity recorded locally in the same area as well as long-range in the other area. We then study the relationship of the firing of the coherent neurons to on-going behavior. The coherently-active neurons appear to play a privileged role in decisions about where to look and reach as well as in how we coordinate look-reach movements. I will discuss how the results are broadly consistent with a role for spike-field coherence in inter-areal communication.
title: A role for coherent neural activity in coordinating look and reach movements

text:
Cochlear implants (CIs) are neuronal prostheses which allow deaf people to hear and understand speech, but noise and reverberation create problems. A second CI delivers binaural information, often providing some source localization ability. Binaural temporal information is particularly important for localization in reverberant space. CI users with higher sensitivity to interaural time difference (ITDs) showed greater robustness against reverberation (Kerber and Seeber, 2013). Seeber and Monaghan (2013) presented a method which enhances selected sound onsets to increase the salience of the ITD cues transmitted. The approach sets the envelope to zero immediately prior to those envelope peaks with a direct-to-reverberant ratio (DRR) above a threshold. This improved sound localization in reverberation in simulated listening with CIs.

We investigated the DRR near peaks in envelopes processed similar to CIs. Speech sounds were convolved with room impulse responses of different rooms and source-receiver configurations. The envelope was extracted from the reverberated speech in frequency-specific channels. The DRR was generally largest at or prior to a peak, indicating that envelope peaks coincide statistically with the moments where direct sound energy dominates over reverberant energy.

Variations of the onset enhancement algorithm were evaluated in a lateralization and a speech test for different source-receiver distances. Onset enhancement improved lateralization performance compared to no enhancement. Lateralization was slightly increased when the enhancement occurred at the peak instead of prior to it. Speech intelligibility measured was not affected by the onset enhancement. In conclusion, the onset enhancement approach has been confirmed to improve localization performance in reverberant spaces using simulated listening with CIs. Since it did not impair speech intelligibility it can be suggested as a method for improving binaural hearing with CIs.
title: Optimizing envelope enhancement to improve localization with bilateral cochlear implants

text:
Controlling advanced upper limb prostheses by applying pattern recognition to electromyography (EMG) signals is promising, however the approach still lacks commercial breakthrough. One reason for this failure may be that only very few studies currently report testing of new prosthetic control systems by users employing physical prostheses in daily life activities, which are anyway limited to controlled laboratory environment. In this work, we describe a software prototyping approach that allows surpassing these limitations. By implementing a control algorithm on a smartphone and using wireless communication with a prosthesis worn by an amputee, the experimental setup is freed from laboratory equipment and tests can be conducted in activities of daily living of end-users. Moreover, high flexibility is maintained through the user interface on the phone and amenities of high level programming languages can be exploited, which are necessary features for effective research.
For this study, a novel control method was implemented on an HTC One S smartphone, featuring a 1.5GHz processor with 1GB RAM and running the Android 4.1.2 operating system. A custom application was created, connecting to a Michelangelo hand prosthesis (Ottobock HealthCare Products GmbH) via Bluetooth. The transmitted EMG data were processed in real-time (i.e., without user-perceivable delay) on the phone and control commands were sent back to the prosthesis. 
The preliminarily evaluated system will facilitate amputee user testing in the laboratory and more importantly environments of the daily living, e.g. at home, work or leisure time. The results of this work will provide insights in the true benefit of the novel prosthetic control for end-users in real-life tests, gained by leveraging the computational power of today’s smartphones for the use of rapid software prototyping. Beside the system tested, the proposed system can be used for testing any other control system, with any type of prosthesis.
title: Smartphone-based rapid software prototyping for real-life validation of advanced prosthetic control

text: Modern hand prostheses are flexible systems with an intuitive control for restoring motor functions, but with no somatosensory feedback [1]. The prosthesis state can be transmitted to the user by delivering electrical pulses to the skin, eliciting tactile sensations [2], [3]. In order to design effective feedback, the response of the human subject during closed-loop control using electrotactile stimulation needs to be investigated [4].  In this study, four able-bodied subjects (25±4 yrs) used a joystick to control dynamic systems [SYS1 = 1/s+1, SYS2 = 2/s(0.25s+1)], simulating the behavior of a prosthesis. The reference trajectory was a pseudorandom multisine (Fig. 1[c] and [e]). The momentary tracking error was provided by delivering stimulation via two electrodes placed on the forearm. For each trial, the human frequency response was identified (cross-spectral analysis) and then a linear transfer function (Fig. 1[a] and [b]) was fitted (prediction error estimation). Finally, the transfer function was applied to predict (Fig. 1[d] and [f]) the human response (joystick signal).  The outcome measure was the cross-correlation coefficient (CCC) between the reference and generated trajectory (Fig. 1[c]), and the estimated and actual response (Fig. 1[d] and [f]). The results demonstrated that the subjects were able to accommodate both dynamic systems, with the worse performance for SYS2 (CCC=82±10% vs. CCC= 87±7%, p < 0.01 t-test). The linear models captured the main features of the human response, although the control strategies for handling the two systems were different (Fig. 1[d] vs. [f]). The prediction was less good for SYS2 (CCC=72±13% vs. CCC=79±8%, p < 0.01 t-test). The limited estimation quality implies the existence of non-linear control strategies, which became more dominant as the difficulty of the control task increased (SYS2). More advanced models will be tested in the future to refine the estimation of human behavior in electrotactile feedback systems.
title: Modeling Human Response in  Closed-loop Control Systems with Electrotactile Feedback

text: Low-level electrical pulses delivered to the skin to elicit tactile sensations (electrotactile stimulation) can be used to provide feedback to the user about the state of a myoelectric prosthesis [1]. However, the stimulation corrupts the recorded myoelectric signals, thereby interfering with the control. One approach to avoid the stimulation artifacts is to implement time-division multiplexing (TDM), in which the stimulation (feedback) and recording (control) are performed in non-overlapping time windows [2], [3]. In the current study, nine able-bodied subjects used myocontrol to command a model of a prosthesis so that the hand aperture followed a predefined reference trajectory comprising a sequence of hand closing/opening (Fig. 1[a] and [b]). Momentary tracking error was fed back to the subjects using electrotactile stimulation with continuous feedback and control (CONT) and with TDM. The stimulation and recording windows for TDM were set to 120 ms. The control command was computed using the data collected within the recording window and then kept constant until the next update. The outcome measures were root mean square tracking error (RMSTE) and time delay between the reference and generated trajectories. The quality of tracking when using TDM was good (Fig. 1[a] and [b]) but the average control performance was worse (Fig. 1[c] and [d]) compared to CONT (p < 0.001 t-test). This was despite the fact that the task dynamics was rather slow (Fig. 1[a] and [b]) and that both the command and feedback were updated at least 4 times per second, which is higher than the human control bandwidth (~2 Hz). It seems that briefly but periodically interrupting the afferent stream was enough to decrease the ability of the subject to perceive and/or process the feedback information. This effect likely depends on the duration of the feedback window. The next step is to test TDM with different feedback window duration and for the control of a real myoelectric prosthesis.
title: Evaluation of Time-Division Multiplexing  for Closed-loop Control using Electrotactile Feedback

text: Myoelectric activity can easily be recorded through surface electrodes, placed on the skin above the muscles of interest. These signals can be used for a variety of medical and biomedical applications. However, several factors limit the usefulness of surface electromyograms (EMGs): sweating modifies electrode impedance, and movements change the electrode location relative to the muscles. Moreover cross-talk limits the capacity to pick up signals from small or deep muscles [1]. These aspects particularly impair the reliability of EMG-based prosthetic devices, which require long-term stability of the conditioned signal. Conversely, signals recorded internally are more reliable, but typically require acute recordings that are unsuited for prosthetic use. Here we show that signals recorded from a fully implanted, induction-powered wireless system allow to continuously decode proportional force information. This implant, developed in the context of the Myoplant project [2], transmits up to four channels of EMG activity, using bipolar epimysial electrodes. Two Rhesus macaques received implants, which have currently been functioning for 5 months. Electrodes were placed in the upper arm (biceps, triceps, and over two fiber groups of the deltoid). One of the monkeys was trained to do a cursor task via a haptic robot, which allowed us to control the forces exerted to/by the animal during arm movements. We used an artificial neural network (ANN) to decode time-varying force profiles during a simple two dimensional reach task. Importantly, a decoder trained with data from a single day maintained an accurate decoding performance during the following weeks. The decoding performance was compared with standard surface EMG recordings conducted simultaneously. Results show that a fully implantable, intramuscular wireless system is particularly suited for applications requiring continuous force decoding such as advanced forelimb prosthetic devices with multiple degrees of freedom.
title: Long-term continuous decoding of force profiles for prosthetic control from wireless myoelectric signals

reasonForTalk: We address the importance of response classification and neural coding in neuroprosthetics.
text:
Objective:  To improve existing retinal prostheses by incorporating visual coding of the retina.  From visual and electrical responses of over 2000 retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), we have seen that the diversity of visual response types is also accompanied by a broad diversity of electrical response types.  Therefore, we sought to develop effective methods to quantify and classify these different visual and electrical responses to see whether specific visual RGC types correlate to specific electrical response types.
Methods:  Mouse RGC spike trains were recorded with a multi-electrode array from the isolated retina (wild-type and degenerated rd10 strains) during epiretinal stimulation with square wave, monophasic pulses of varying voltage and duration as well as during visual stimulation with full-field flashes (2 sec ON, 2 sec OFF).
Results:  Only about half of RGCs respond to electrical stimulation.  Surprisingly, many RGCs do not respond to increasing electrical stimulus with a sigmoidal function.  Furthermore, electrical responses frequently occur during one or more specific epochs of time after stimulation.  The diversity of response patterns appears to reflect the diversity of network inputs and physiological properties across the RGC population.  In a preliminary analysis, we found no correlation between electrical response latency, and visual response latency, duration, amplitude, or ON/OFF index.
Conclusions:  This analysis requires a large database of paired visual and electrical responses to stimuli that are sophisticated enough for discrimination of ~20 distinct RGC types.  We continue to assess whether additional data and better analyses can identify RGC types with unique visual and electrical response patterns.  If we are successful, it may become possible in the degenerate retina to functionally identify RGCs in the absence of visual responses - in turn, enabling the application of more sophisticated visual coding in retinal prostheses.
title: The importance to retinal prostheses of considering RGC diversity.

text: The analysis of impairments on cognitive tests due to brain lesions is undoubtedly the root of cognitive neuroscience and has led to tremendous insights into the neural substrate of cognitive functions. Voxel-based lesion symptom mapping (VLSM) (1) introduced mass-univariate analyses developed for fMRI to lesion mapping allowing for a hitherto unknown neuroanatomical precision in lesion mapping. Here, we undertake a new step and combine VLSM with computational modeling by fitting a cognitive model with interpretable parameters to the neuropsychological data whose neural correlates are then mapped with VLSM. We used a large sample of lesion patients (n=306) who have been administered the Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST), a canonical measure of executive control that detects impairments in set switching. We selected a recent computational model of the WCST (2) that describes the cognitive process as a gradual shift of attention weights to the 3 sorting dimensions. These weights are updated in proportion to a feedback signal that determines the weights eligible for updating based on the current sort of the subject. The model has 4 parameters: reward and punishment sensitivity (PS) regulate the proportional updating of the attention weights, decision consistency models the stochasticity of the choices, and attentional focussing regulates the extent of the updating of all weights.  Model parameters were determined using hierarchical Bayesian estimation and MCMC sampling with JAGS. Simulated data exhibited very similar WCST standard scores thus confirming a good model fit. VLSM analyses of the model parameters revealed a large effect for PS in the right prefrontal cortex (including insula) and the underlying white matter. This effect largely overlapped with the neural substrate for perseverative error, one of the hallmarks of impaired executive control. Regression analysis showed that PS is the most important model parameter for predicting perseverative errors. Conceptu
title: Delineating impaired executive functions in humans with model-based lesion mapping

text:
Neurophysiological recordings of the same task often vary from each repetition of the experiment (trial) to the next (e.g. [1,2]). Trial-to-trial variability has been observed in multiple modalities of neural recordings (e.g. [1-3]) and it has been studied using a variety of techniques ranging from multivariate statistics  to information-theoretic approaches [2].  Identifying the functional role of this observed variability is an essential question in neuroscience; however gaining a fundamental insight into trial-to-trial dynamics in ensemble recordings is still a major challenge.
In this study we present an empirical criterion to discern whether the observed trial-to-trial variability in neural ensembles is essentially driven by stochastic transitions among stable states, as often assumed [2] or by deterministic processes.
First, we present empirical evidence of attracting dynamics in prefrontal cortex ensembles during decision making tasks; and how this dynamic landscape is modulated on a trial-by-trial basis [4]. Next, we evaluate the capacity of a simple statistic based on the behaviour of trajectories in classification settings, the trajectory coherence, in order to identify the origin of trial-to-trial dynamics [5]. Towards this goal we first devised a parsimonious model of non-stationary classification problems [6] and then estimated the coherence of class-trajectories in reconstructed state spaces. We show how this analysis can discern subtle variations attributable to deterministic processes from stochastic fluctuations. 
In a final stage, we analyse the coherency of neural trajectories in rat's frontal cortex ensemble activity during a decision-making task. Results suggest that, in line with recent hypotheses, rather than internal noise, it is the deterministic trend which could underlie the observed trial-to-trial variability [7]. Thus, this approach potentially enable us to infer empirically the source of variability dynamics in in vivo recordings [5].
title: Attracting dynamics, non-stationarity and trial to trial variability of frontal cortex ensembles

text:
Striatum (Str) is the critical structure in various cognitive processes. The direct and indirect pathways of dorsal Str determine the actions in performing goal directed behaviors [1]. Ventral Str (nucleus accumbens-NAc) calculates the reward value of tasks and the error in expectation [2]. This reward value may alter an action decision even when the dorsal striatal output is against it, especially for effort-related decision making processes [3]. Recent research shows that both ventral and dorsal Str take part in decision making processes [4]. Striatal processing of a stimulus under the presence of dopamine (DA) signaling from midbrain neurons produces the stimulation to the motor circuits of the brain.
We compare the results of two computational models to study the effects of neural synchronization in action initiation. Both models integrate the outputs of dorsal and ventral striatal structures to show that through the striato-nigro-striatal pathway, limbic regions have impact on the motor regions of the basal ganglia. The first model uses conductance based neuron models to demonstrate the physiological properties of neurons in each basal ganglia structure. Each brain structure is represented by a single neuron. Striatal neurons are modeled as two groups which have D1 or D2 type DA receptors. This model is simulated on MATLAB.
The second model realizes the same network by using AdEx type neurons and demonstrating each brain structure by 100 neurons. The neuron groups are randomly connected with a sparseness factor of 0.1. Total neural activity of each neuron group is studied via raster plots. This model is simulated with BRIAN neuron simulator.
The results of both models show that ventral striatal structures can modify the action decisions even when connections are sparse and random and neural firing frequencies vary. The dynamics of the designed neural circuitry can be efficiently used in computational neuroscience to understand the cognitive processes.
title: Comparing Single and Multiple Neuron Simulations of Integrated Dorsal and Ventral Striatal Pathway Models of Action Initiation

text: Robotic systems can perform well-defined tasks with exquisite precision at high speeds, but they have much more difficulty when operating in unstructured environments. Improved spatial navigation skills would increase autonomy of robots and would extend the range of tasks they could potentially address. Standard solutions integrate different sensory signals to localize a robot’s position with reference to external objects. However, such localization algorithms only work well in static surroundings. On the contrary, animals such as rats and humans effortlessly adapt to new environments and learn to orient themselves even in dynamical situations. With the discovery of place cells and grid cells, neuroscientists are starting to disclose the mechanisms underlying spatial navigation skills in animals. In this work we propose a neuromorphic architecture for robotic spatial navigation that aims at taking advantage of the flexibility and robustness of biological neural networks. Our architecture runs on the neuromorphic hardware SpiNNaker, a massively-parallel computing architecture specifically designed to model large-scale spiking neural networks (Khan et al. 2008). We take advantage of SpiNNaker’s support for PyNN, a simulator-independent language for modeling spiking neural networks and we adapt existing models of grid and place cells based on recent experimental evidence (Couey et al. 2013). We validate our neural controller on a mobile robot that continuously acquires odometric and visual information about its motion and its local position to update its internal spatial representation. The neuromorphic architecture drives the robot in dependence of pre-set goal locations that affect the neural dynamics. The close integration of goals and sensory information could be crucial to build robotic systems that can ultimately match human spatial navigation performance.
title: Neuromorphic architecture for robotic spatial navigation

text: Motor synergies have been supposed to simplify motor control [1]-[5]. In order to test it, we exploit the correlations of our hand's joints to discover some underlying simplicity in a complex stream of behavioral actions. Instead of averaging variability out, we take the view that the structure of variability may contain valuable information about the task being performed. Therefore, we asked 7 subjects to interact in 17 daily-life situations and quantified behavior in principled manner using cyber glove technology. We combined Probabilistic Principal Component Analysis (PPCA) with a Bayesian classifier to analyze the data. Our key findings are: 1. we confirmed that hand control is low-dimensional, where 4-5 dimensions were sufficient to explain 80-90% of the variability in the movement data [6]. 2. We established a universally applicable measure of manipulative complexity that allowed us to measure this quantity across vastly different tasks. 3. We discovered that within the first 1000 ms of an action the hand shape already configures itself to vastly different tasks, enabling us to reliable predict the action intention [6]. 4. We suggest how using the statistics of natural finger movements paired with Bayesian latent variable model can be used to infer the movements of missing limbs from existing limbs to control e.g. a prosthetic device. Overall, these predictabilities could be used to build intelligent Neuroprosthetics for lost fingers that implement the task from the movement of the remaining limbs.
title: Bayesian approach to handle missing limbs in Neuroprosthetics

text:
AIM: In this paper we propose a novel simultaneous and proportional multiple degree of freedom (DOF) control method for active prostheses. The method is based on non-negative matrix factorization of EMG signals, as previously proposed [1], but is enhanced by the application of sparseness constraints.
METHODS:  In [1], a control scheme for active prostheses is based on EMG factorization, as:

$${\widehat{\mathbf{Z}^2(t)}}_{N \times t} = \mathbf{W}_{N \times L} \cdot {\mathbf{F}(t)}_{L \times t}$$

$${\widehat{\mathbf{Z}^2(t)}}_{N \times t} = \left[ \cdots, W_i^+, W_i^-, \cdots \right] \left[  \begin{array} {c} \vdots \\ {f_i^+}(t) \\ {f_i^-}(t) \\ \vdots \end{array} \right]$$

where ${\widehat{\mathbf{Z}^2(t)}}_{N \times t}$ represents the root mean square (RMS) value of the N-channel surface EMG recording, $\mathbf{W}$ is the matrix of the basis control signal, and $\mathbf{F}(t)$ is the coefficient matrix of $\mathbf{W}$. ${W_i}$ is the individual basis control signal, and it is a column vector, ${f_i(t)}$ is the time series, and it is a row vector, N represents the number of electrodes, and L the number of the basis control signal. Eq. (1) satisfies the NMF frame. To this basic scheme, we applied a sparseness constraint NMF, nsNMF [2], to the columns of $\mathbf{F}(t)$.  
RESULTS: Compared with the standard NMF, in the training stage, the sparseness constraint NMF can extract the basis control information in one step, instead of the DoF-wise approach in [1]. In the testing stage, the simultaneous control performance of nsNMF is similar to that of the standard NMF, as shown in Fig.1.  
CONCLUSION: An improved scheme to the NMF based simultaneous and proportional multiple-DOF prostheses control system is described. By applying a sparseness constraint to F(t), in training stage, the basis control signal can be extracted in one step. And in the testing stage, the simultaneous control performance of nsNMF is similar to that of the standard NMF.
title: Simultaneous and Proportional Multiple Degrees of Freedom Control of Active Prostheses with Sparseness Constraint Non-Negative Matrix Factorization of EMG Signals

text:
When two opposing force fields are presented on subsequent movements, substantial motor interference occurs and neither force field is learned (1,2). We recently showed that immediate prior movement acts as a contextual cue reducing motor interference during the learning of opposing force fields (3). Here we examine if future movements affect motor learning in a similar fashion.

First, subjects performed a two-part movement, from the start to a central via-point and then on to a target, either leftward or rightward of the initial direction. On the first movement, a randomly selected clockwise or counter-clockwise velocity-dependent curl field was applied, where the second movement was predictive of its field direction. The second movement direction could act as a contextual cue for field direction, and indeed led to a significant reduction in interference.

Next, we investigated if subjects could employ both future and past movement contextual cues simultaneously. Subjects performed adaptation movements between two via points in randomly selected opposing curl fields, where the field direction was specified by both prior and future movements. After substantial training, subjects could simultaneously utilize both past and future movement contexts to produce a XOR-like adaptation to the force fields.

Finally, we examined if future motion affects learning a single force field. We hypothesized that if dynamic learning were followed by variable follow-through movements (1 of 9), each would partition learning in the preceding movement. In contrast, a single follow-though movement would result in no partitioning, and therefore faster learning. We compared the two conditions finding significantly faster learning with a single follow-through.

Overall our results suggest that information arising from future motor planning can not only influence the formation and recall of multiple motor memories, but also affect learning a single set of dynamics.
title: The value of the follow through: Future movements influence dynamic learning

text:
Behavioral and neuroscientific data on reward-based decision making point to a fundamental distinction between habitual and goal-directed action selection. An increasingly explicit set of neuroscientific ideas has been established for habit formation centering on the temporal-difference learning account of phasic dopamine response, whereas goal-directed control just started to attract researchers' attention. While using functional magnetic resonance imaging to address the involvement of brain areas abounds, ideas on the algorithmic and neural level are scarce.
In this talk, we suggest an algorithm based on dynamic programming for goal-directed control in animals and humans and present a neural network implementation that solves the Bellman equation using biologically realistic neurons and synapses. Finding the solution, commonly considered a hard optimization problem, can be accomplished quickly when using a surprisingly simple neural network. We theoretically prove the convergence of the neural dynamics to the optimal value function. Further, we present how the environmental model can be learned using a local synaptic plasticity rule. Function approximation extends the applicability of the model from discrete to continuous state spaces. We demonstrate the applicability of the model by presenting simulations results on various benchmark tasks from the machine learning literature, yielding competitive results.
title: Model-based Reinforcement Learning with Spiking Neurons

text:
Neurons in dorsal premotor cortex (PMd) and parietal reach region (PRR) can simultaneously encode two alternative motor goals when monkeys have equal preference to choose either goal. This is true even if goals are selected based on two competing spatial transformation rules. Here, we test if graded preferences for such rule-based reach goals are reflected in graded spatial selectivity of individual neurons.
A monkey had to determine the correct reach goal from two instructive cues. A spatial pre-cue consisted of two differently colored triangles, pointing to two opposite directions. The pre-cue indicated, first, the two possible goals in a given trial, located at $90^0$ clockwise and counterclockwise relative to its own position (rules). Second, the triangle sizes could differ and represented the probability with which the rule guided by each triangle would be instructed later. After a delay, a spatially neutral color cue was presented. In instructed trials the color matched to one of the pre-cue triangles and indicated the valid rule. In interspersed free-choice trials the color was neutral and both potential goals were rewarded with equal amount and probability.
Preliminary results show that the pre-cue successfully induced a graded preference in the monkey: The alternative which was more likely to be instructed was chosen more often and faster in free-choice trials where there was no objective advantage from selecting this alternative. The spatial selectivity of individual PMd and PRR neurons during motor planning was modulated in accordance with the degree of later choice bias.
We conclude that in a rule-based motor goal selection task, the probability with which a rule is instructed induces a reward-independent subjective preference in free-choice behavior. The degree of behavioral preference is reflected in the degree of spatial selectivity of individual neurons in PRR and PMd corroborating the relevance of both areas in rule-based motor goal selection.
title: Reward-independent preferences are reflected by graded neural selectivity in sensorimotor cortex during rule-based reach goal selection

text:
During visually guided reach planning, neurons in monkey parietal reach region (PRR) and dorsal pre-motor cortex (PMd) encode task-relevant spatial information. When reaches are directed towards objects then object shape and size partly determine the relevant space for motor planning. Accordingly, we could show that reach goals are encoded not only relative to the own body or gaze direction (egocentric reference frames), but also relative to the target object (object-centered reference frame) in these areas [1]. Here we test if not only the object position influences the center of reference for spatial selectivity in PRR and PMd, but also if the object size determines the spatial scaling (tuning width) of the neural selectivity. Further, we test if object-centered encoding is temporally stable or specific to specific stages of reach planning [2]. 
A rhesus monkey was trained to conduct an object-based reach task. The monkey had to memorize a briefly flashed peripheral visual cue which could occur at one of five locations relative to a memorized extended visual object. After a first delay period (visual memory) the object but not the cue re-occurred. After a second delay (motor planning) the monkey had to reach to the previously cued target location on the object. The first and second object occurrence could be at congruent or incongruent spatial locations. The object had always the same shape, but could be of the same or different size in both occurrences.
Preliminary results suggest that PRR and PMd switch their encoding from predominantly object-centered during the visual memory period to predominantly egocentric during movement planning. We also found that a subset of neurons scaled their spatial selectivity with the size of the object. 
Our results suggest that neurons in PRR and PMd dynamically adjust their spatial selectivity to the behaviorally relevant spatial space, including spatial parameters of target objects.
title: Reach target object determines spatial selectivity and reference frame in the parietal reach region and dorsal premotor cortex.

text: One of the main challenges in decision neuroscience lies in the fact that humans do not make decisions alone, but rather are affected by their social environment. Particularly, besides making choices according to the action-outcome association, humans tend to align their behavior with the others, even without any direct social interaction. A long tradition of economic and social psychological studies has demonstrated a robust effect of social influence and conformity on perceptual decision making (Asch, 1951). However, relatively little is known about what is the nature of the computations carried out by human minds to achieve optimal decisions when social influence is presented. To this aim, we developed a novel experimental paradigm which allows for investigating real-time interaction between multiple players while engaging in a probabilistic decision-making task under uncertainty. By employing computational modeling techniques from reinforcement learning (RL) framework, we show that the decision making process involves two reinforcement learning signals. Specifically, besides the reward prediction error (RPE), there exists a social prediction error (SPE), by which the difference between one’s own selection and group choices is computed. We found that the mixed RL model with weighted combination of RPE and SPE could provide a better fit to participants’ behavior than does RL model with RPE or SPE alone. We further observed that, the combination between expected values and the others’ choices were computed using a weighted average that reflects each player’s reliability (i.e., how successful the other has performed of the last few trials). These findings provide evidence that social influences exerted by the group members could be used to refine initial decisions and predict future behavior change.
title: Reinforcement Learning Signals of Social Influence on Human Decision-Making

text: Task instruction is a key component of any psychological experiment, yet little is known about the process by which instructions are encoded. In a previous study, we have attempted to measure the speed of the encoding process by varying the time delay before a retrieval request and measuring variations of the response time (Bugmann et al., 2013). The results were explained by constraints on the time available for Hebbian synaptic learning during the time delay. A completely different analysis is proposed here, inspired by properties of the attentional blink (Shapiro et al. 1997).  A blocking instruction encoding process is assumed, during which requests for instruction retrieval are queued and are executed only after encoding is completed.  Interestingly, the attentional blink literature shows that the queued request can be masked out by another sensory input. We have tested this interpretation in an experiment with or without masking. The experiment (see fig) consists of showing to a subject a Stimulus-Response task rule for tsr=200ms, then showing a mask 1 during a variable delay (delay=50-1300ms), then showing a Stimulus at time ts either for up to 5 sec or until the Response is produced (unmasked condition) or showing the Stimulus only for 100ms, followed by a mask 2 (masked condition). Our computational model of the attentional blink hypothesis fits the response time data well (see fig) by assuming a Gamma distribution of encoding times with a peak at 340 ms, and an additional random time td_av =500 ms taken by a subject to respond in the masked runs.  The model reflects the assumption that the duration of the attentional blink is the time required for instruction encoding. How can this be verified? If encoding were through synaptic learning, would the encoding time follow a Gamma distribution? How would the brain detect the completion of learning to end the attentional blink?
title: Fast encoding of task instructions: An attentional blink hypothesis.

text:
A system that is used to control a device based on the brain’s activity without using the normal output pathways of peripheral nerves is a so called brain-computer interface (BCI). BCIs processing steady-state visual evoked potentials (SSVEP) have a high information transfer rate (ITR). Changing the stimulation sequence to code-based VEP (c-VEP) promises better accuracy and higher ITR. In this work we investigate the online accuracy of an ECoG based BCI, which is decoding c-VEPs that are generated by visual stimuli embedded within a video-application.
A 63 bit m-sequence was used for visual stimulation in combination with a 60 Hz monitor. Data were acquired with 256Hz and then band-pass filtered between 0.5 and 30 Hz. A patient suffering from intractable epilepsy participated in the experiment after implantation of clinical subdural electrodes. Eight ECoG channels covering the visual cortex were recorded to get the best c-VEPs. The experiment was separated into a calibration run (i) and an online accuracy run to test the classifier (ii). In (i) the subject was asked to gaze at a rectangular control element on the screen, which was flickering over 200 stimulation cycles. The derived signals were used to compute a classifier based on the canonical correlation analysis between averaged VEPs and the individual recorded trials. After calibration, the patient performed the second task (ii), in which four visual targets were presented on the screen simultaneously showing a phase shifted version of the calibration sequence. Specifically, the patient performed 20 trials including 3 s blank screen and then 7 s of visual stimulation. A linear classifier identified the current selection based on the correlation coefficients between a 2.1 s ECoG buffer and the calibration templates. After finishing task (ii), the subject achieved an online accuracy of 90 %. Therefore, the experiment successfully showed that intracranial c-VEPs can be used to setup a continuous controlled BCI.
title: A BCI controlled video application using electrocorticographic VEPs

text:
Aberrations of synchronous neuronal activity have been correlated with a multitude of neurological disorders. While the pathophysiology of these brain disorders is both distinct and unresolved, pathological hypersynchronization of neuronal groups has been consistently reported. Additionally, human, animal, and theoretical studies have demonstrated a shift back towards physiological state concomitant with desynchronization of the abnormal activity. 
Models of plasticity have been derived to simulate and explain network dynamics with high levels of synchronization. Spike time dependent plasticity (STDP), has been explored and extrapolated to disorders of hypersynchrony. Circuit function with respect to disorders of synchrony, however, must also include hyposynchrony such as described in TS; yet, there are virtually no reports addressing this regime.
Recently, chronic recordings from the human thalamus demonstrated a correlation between low gamma synchrony and positive symptoms of the disorder (tics). Despite being persistent, tic expression waxes and wanes, however the mechanism by which this occurs is unclear. I propose that the governing dynamic is one of alternation between strongly and weakly synchronized states, representing the waning and the waxing modes of tic expression. By considering STDP in this regime, the two states coexist in the network with synaptic strength dictating the level of synchrony. A model for this bistability has been described as the Sisyphus Effect, in which a network is characterized by spontaneous fluctuations between the two levels of synchrony.
Under conditions of STDP, a network can be moved into either a synchronized, desynchronized, or bistable state. Additionally, by means of feed forward inhibition, such as occurs in the recurrent loop of TS, GABA can control STDP by reversing its polarity. These processes can be used to increase neuronal coordination from the hyposynchronized pathological state to a normal physiologic one.
title: The role of plasticity and oscillations in the symptomotology of Tourette syndrome

text: Memory of a linked list of attractor waypoints has been proposed [1] to account for the ability of insects such as desert ants  to follow extended routes through cluttered environments without chemical trails [2]. However, an alternative explanation [3] is that at each point on the route, the ant could rotate until the difference of the current image from any stored snapshot is minimized; this tends to be the direction it needs to go to move along the route. We show that this method is effective when tested in a realistic simulation of the visual experience of ants based on ecologically relevant data. But how could the ant’s brain implement this mechanism? We explored whether our previously developed model of olfactory learning in the MB of fruit flies [4] could also explain ant route following. The odour pattern activating the projection neuron (PN) layer is replaced by a 10x36 pixel image experienced by the simulated ant as it moves along the route. The Kenyon cell (KC) layer of 20,000 spiking neurons is innervated in a random pattern (i.e., not preserving retinotopy) such that each KC gets input from 10 PNs, and needs coincident activation from several PNs to fire. All KC outputs converge on a single extrinsic neuron (EN). Learning takes place at the KC-EN synapses, and is controlled by a three-factor rule [5]: spike timing dependent plasticity tags the KC synapses that were active shortly before or after EN firing and is combined with a reinforcement signal which permanently decreases the strength of tagged synapses. After training with route images, the rate of spiking in the EN corresponds to ‘novelty’ of visual input. By choosing the heading that produces the lowest firing, the simulated ant is able to recapitulate the route. The mushroom body circuit thus appears to support a general function for evaluating complex sensory patterns and deciding whether to approach or avoid.
title: The neural architecture of the insect mushroom body can encode route memory in complex natural environments

text: Goal-directed decision making in biological systems is broadly based on associations between conditional and unconditional stimuli. This can be further classified as classical conditioning (correlation based learning) and operand conditioning (reward-based learning). A number of computational and experimental studies have well established the role of the basal ganglia (striatal system) towards reward-based learning, where as the cerebellum evidently plays an important role in developing specific conditioned responses. Although, they are viewed as distinct learning systems [1], recent animal experiments point towards their complementary role in behavioral learning, and also show the existence of substantial two-way communication between the two structures [2].  Based on this notion of co-operative learning, in this work we hypothesize that the basal ganglia and cerebellar learning systems work in parallel and compete with each other (Figure 1). We envision such an interaction being driven by a simple reward modulated heterosynaptic plasticity (RMHP) rule [3], in order to guide the over all goal-directed behavior. Using a recurrent neural network actor-critic model of the basal ganglia and feed-forward correlation learning model of the cerebellum (input correlation learning-ICO) [4], we demonstrate that the RMHP rule can effectively combine the outcomes of the two learning systems. This is tested using simulated environments of increasing complexity with a four-wheeled animat in a dynamic foraging task. Although, they are modeled within a highly simplified level of biological abstraction, we clearly demonstrate that such a combined learning mechanism, leads to much stabler and faster learning of goal-directed behaviors in comparison to the individual systems.
title: Goal-directed Learning with Reward Modulated Interaction between Striatal and Cerebellar systems

text:
Animals have evolved diverse navigational strategies in order to survive in complex dynamic environments. Path integration (PI) is one of these strategies, which enables them to integrate angular and linear ego-motion cues to maintain a vector representation of their current location with respect to the starting point, called home vector. It has been observed in many animals ranging from arthropods to mammals. Especially social insects, such as ants and bees, exhibit astonishing capabilities in PI as part of their central place foraging [7].  PI plays a crucial role in acquiring spatial knowledge by providing a metric. In recent years, many neural models of PI have been proposed [3, 6]. However, only few of them have been applied on an actual physical robot [2, 4], and even fewer have discussed how PI mechanisms can be integrated in a neural architecture for complex navigation [1].
We present a neural PI mechanism interacting with neural locomotion control for homing behavior and associative goal learning in an autonomous hexapod walking robot. The mechanism is fed by inputs from an allothetic compass and an odometer. The home vector is computed and represented in circular arrays of neurons where heading angles are population-coded and linear displacements are rate-coded. Incoming signals are sustained through leaky neural integrator circuits and compute the home vector by local excitation-lateral inhibition interactions. An actor-critic reinforcement learning control [5] uses the computed home vector for state space exploration and associative learning of rewarding goal locations.
Using the angular difference between the heading and the home vector as feedback error for steering, we show that the PI mechanism can guide the robot back to its home position (see Fig. 1). Furthermore, vector representations of goals can be successfully learned by combining reward- and correlation-based learning methods [5].
title: A Neural Path Integration Mechanism for Adaptive Vector Navigation in Autonomous Robots

reasonForTalk: This study challenges widely held beliefs that PFC is resistant to memory interference
text: The primate lateral prefrontal cortex (PFC) and posterior parietal cortex are major nodes in a brain network that supports short-term memory. While PFC has been shown to protect important memory content from distracting stimuli, parietal cortex is driven more strongly by sensory inputs, irrespective of their relevance to the current task. We compared extracellular single-unit activity from the PFC and the ventral intraparietal area (VIP) of two rhesus monkeys trained to memorize and discriminate visually presented set sizes (numerosities). While performing the task, the animals had to resist a salient distractor numerosity that appeared during the memory delay. Surprisingly, PFC neurons preferentially encoded distractors during their presentation. Shortly after this interference, however, PFC neurons restored target information, which predicted correct behavioral decisions. In contrast, most VIP neurons only encoded target numerosities throughout the trial. Representation of target information in VIP was the earliest and most reliable neuronal correlate of behavior. Our results challenge the commonly held view that resistance to inference in PFC is the key mechanism for selection and maintenance of task-relevant stimuli in working memory. Instead, our data suggest that distracting stimuli can be bypassed by storing and retrieving target information, emphasizing active maintenance processes during working memory with complementary functions for frontal and parietal cortex in controlling memory content.
title: Distinct roles for primate frontal and parietal cortex in guarding working memory from distractors

text:
Studies focusing on the neural representation of hand forces have traditionally targeted the primary motor cortex (M1) due to its direct connections to the corticospinal tract. Few studies have also looked at premotor areas, where a stronger representation of movement planning is found. In this study we focused on the macaque ventral premotor cortex, also known as area F5, and on the anterior intraparietal area (AIP) because of their strong representation of grasping movements. 
We trained a macaque monkey on a delayed grasping task, in which a manipulandum (handle) was grasped with the right hand with one of two grip types, either a power grip or a precision grip. Every grip had to be held for 1 second at one out of three force levels. Both the particular grip type and the required amount of force were cued to the monkey at the beginning of each trial. We then recorded neural activity from F5 and AIP in the left hemisphere, contralateral to the moving arm, with chronically implanted floating microelectrode arrays (FMAs; MicroProbes for Life Sciences). Two 32-channel FMAs were implanted in each area (total of 128 electrodes).
We found that single unit activity in F5 and AIP was strongly modulated by both grip type and grasping force. Response to grip type was similar in both areas. However, grasping force was more strongly coded in F5 than in AIP during most epochs of the task. Only during the cue presentation and the holding phase, when the monkey was actively maintaining the force level, similar proportions of AIP neurons showed force modulation as in F5. Neural modulation was also different in both areas, with F5 neurons showing more often an increase in activity with increased hand force, whereas AIP neurons were modulated to similar degree toward an increasing and decreasing force level.
These preliminary results demonstrate a clear, but potentially different involvement of AIP and F5 in the planning and execution of grasp forces.
title: Grasp force coding in F5 and AIP in a delayed grasping task

text: Beta oscillations are often considered as pathological activity in Parkinson's disease and have also been implicated in motor suppression of healthy animals. However, recently we demonstrated that behavioral correlates of beta oscillations are more complex as, for example, beta power also increased in rats when sensory signals prompted them to quickly initiate movements [1]. To study the underlying neural mechanisms and the complex relation between beta oscillations and behavior, we combined computational modeling of basal ganglia networks with electrophysiological recordings from behaving rats. Previous computational models showed that increased inhibitory input from striatum to globus pallidus (GP) can generate pathological beta oscillations in the subthalamo-pallidal network [2]. To test whether the same model can also reproduce the experimentally-observed transient beta oscillations, we identified rat striatal medium-spiny neurons that increased their firing rate when the rat initiated movements. This striatal activity was then used as an estimate for inhibitory input to the GP in our network model. Indeed, we found that the movement-related increase in striatal activity leads to transient beta oscillations in the model with a time course that closely matches the experimentally measured oscillations (see Figure).  Furthermore, we studied the effect of additional excitatory input to the subthalamic nucleus in the model. It turns out that not only the amplitude, but also the relative timing of the inputs to GP and the subthalamic nucleus affect the amount of beta power in the model. We conclude that the striatal indirect pathway can drive transient beta oscillations during movement initiation and that transient beta oscillations in behaving animals share some of the underlying mechanisms with pathological beta oscillations in Parkinson's disease.
title: A computational model of basal ganglia dynamics during movement initiation: striatal indirect pathway drives transient beta oscillations

text:
We considered a temporal sequence task performed by macaque monkeys where to match a stimulus with an appropriate movement[1] and rearranging the association is expected. We utilized Basal ganglia-Thalamus-Cortex(BTC) model to realize action selection and to select appropriate action, reinforcement learning rules are used to update BTC model parameters using temporal difference method. In [2,3], it is claimed that temporal difference method is biologically meaningful.  This working memory task is realized on humanoid robot, Darwin-Op on which online training is carried out.
During task, robot learns to associate different stimulus with desired actions as summarized in figure. There are three different stimuli which are red, blue and yellow colours and three different actions. Robot recognizes the colours with the embedded camera and detected colour stimulus is the input of BTC model, where action selection is done. Robot is expected to decide on an action at first. Green colour is reward, and it is shown to robot if the selected action is the correct to be associated with the stimulus. At first, robot was expecting nothing and a given reward raises its expectation error. This urges robot to reinforce the desired stimulus-action pair. Once robot is rewarded due to a right choice, expectation error(ee) updates the parameters of BTC model in charge of action selection. When update is completed, robot manages to select the desired action to a given stimulus. In case, when an expected reward is not given to the selected action associated with a stimulus, this also causes an ee and urges robot to rearrange the previously built association between a stimulus and action. 
So, robot manages to rearrange its associations by changing parameters of BTC model, which directly effects action selection and is biologically meaningful. As a future work, it is aimed to investigate the biological correlation between the parameters of BTC model and role of dopamine on action selection.
title: Real Time Learning of Rearranging Associations on a Humanoid Robot

text:
Recent technical advances in cell-type specific neuronal perturbation present the opportunity to systematically examine structure-function relationships in the brains of genetic model organisms. In the fruit fly, two prominent behaviors requiring sophisticated neuronal computation are visual object fixation and figure ground discrimination, yet the neural substrates remain unknown. Recent experiments in motion blind, walking flies revealed object responses due to a position system distinct from the T4-T5 cell dependent motion pathway [1]. We performed behavioral experiments in which we blocked synaptic output from T4-T5 cells and observed a lack of stripe fixation and figure ground discrimination at fast dynamics. Thus, for mediating these behaviors, the motion dependent system is necessary and the position system is insufficient.
To address the question of whether the T4-T5 motion system is sufficient to mediate such behaviors, we implemented two dynamical models based on measured properties of well-studied HS cells [2], immediate post-synaptic targets of T4-T5. The key component of both models is motion asymmetry in the responses of model neurons, whereby front-to-back motion elicits stronger responses than back-to-front motion. The first model is a simplified phenomenological model and the second is more physiologically realistic. Both couple a bilateral pair of neurons to turning behaviour. We show that these models are sufficient to mediate object tracking and figure ground discrimination in the presence of noise and predict fixation in front of moving backgrounds. Thus, we propose that already well understood neurons of the motion pathway, known to mediate wide field visuo-motor responses, are sufficient to allow flies to track small field objects under various conditions. It will be interesting to extend these modeling efforts with further anatomical, physiological and behavioral results to work towards a deeper understanding of fly visuo-motor behaviors.
title: Multiple fly visuo-motor behaviors predicted by a single biologically plausible circuit

text:
Purkinje Cells of the cerebellar oculomotor vermis play an important role in the control of visually guided saccades. Despite a large variety of eye movement related firing rate changes of single cells, their population is able to explain the duration of the eye movement. Thus, most computational models of the neurons involved in the control of saccades use the spike density functions averaged over trials. In contrast, we created and compared three single trials models which predict the occurrence of individual spikes. The single units data contained 3x20 cells collected from each of the following structures in Rhesus macaques: Purkinje Cell (PC) Simple Spike units from the saccade-related cerebellar oculomotor vermis, caudal fastigial nucleus (cFN) neurons and abducens nucleus motoneurons (AN). We describe the discharge patterns of these units by spiking neuron models, comprised of a stochastic spike generator whose rate is controlled by a generalized linear model (GLM) with various regressors, including recent spiking history (Paninski 2004). The first model regresses onto eye X/Y positions with kernels drawn from Gaussian processes. The second model employs unimodal kernels, and adds speed and acceleration to the regressors to evaluate the dependence on these kinematical variables more explictly. The third model uses a biophysically plausible the eye plant model to regress on net forces computed from eye positions.
The well-described AN neurons (Prsa et al. 2010) served as a ground-truth for our method. All three computational models resulted in equally good predictions of the AN spikes. The models’ predictions for our data samples of  PC and cFN neurons were significantly worse than the ones for AN, but still well above a baseline computed from a model accounting only for the inter-trial variability, implying that a) GLM models can explain the task-related within-trial variability of these spiketrains and b) spikes relate to kinematical parameters via forces
title: Forces matter for relating spikes to saccade parameters in motoneurons and the oculomotor cerebellum

text:
Visual information processing is mediated not only by feedforward inputs but also profoundly modulated by feedback.  Whether cortico-thalamic feedback substantially changes the representation of visual information in the dorsolateral geniculate nucleus (dLGN) remains an open question, as previous investigations have yielded inconsistent results. Here, we used the mouse model to test how cortico-thalamic feedback affects temporal and spatial processing of dLGN neurons. 
To study the role of cortico-thalamic feedback we performed extracellular recordings with multisite linear silicon probes in dLGN of awake head-fixed mice. During recordings, we transiently silenced visual cortex by optogenetically stimulating parvalbumin–positive (PV+) inhibitory interneurons.
To assess feedback-related changes of temporal response properties, we first examined spontaneous activity. We found that during global inactivation of V1, spontaneous firing rates decreased abruptly. After 200 ms of cortical inactivation, dLGN neurons transitioned into burst mode firing, leading to a 3-fold increase in the burst-tonic firing ratio.
To assess feedback-related changes in spatial response properties, we measured size tuning in the dLGN by presenting gratings of different diameter. We found that numerous neurons in mouse dLGN exhibit surround suppression. Importantly, in dLGN neurons, transient inactivation of visual cortex led to an expansion of receptive field center size (22.3%) and a reduction of surround suppression (21.8%). We observed many dLGN neurons in which the decrease in surround suppression during cortical inactivation seems driven by two effects: a reduction of responses to stimuli up to the optimal size and an increase of responses to stimuli exceeding the optimal size.
We conclude that, similar to what has been reported for higher-order mammals, both temporal response properties and spatial integration in mouse dLGN are at least partly shaped by cortico-thalamic feedback circuits.
title: Influence of cortico-thalamic feedback on visual information processing in mouse dorsolateral geniculate nucleus

text: Bidirectional neuronal prosthetics would benefit tremendously if the writing in of neuronal information would be noninvasive. Conveniently, the superficial dendrites of projection neurons in superficial as well as infragranular layers should in principle allow for selective noninvasive optogenetic stimulation. To examine the feasibility of this approach we stimulated the dendritic tufts of layer V neurons with a sparse micro-movie of high temporal and spatial resolution in seven anesthetized Thy1-line18 mice. Simultaneously, we recorded extracellularly from of those neurons with dense multichannel electrodes. To quantify the transfer function from the sparse stimulation to the neuronal spiking we calculated spike triggered averages of the light stimulation pattern. Similar to the standard spike triggered averages of sensory receptive fields we found that a neuron has an area on the brain surface where it is sensitive to the light stimulation. The size of this area corresponded to the extent of the dendritic tuft of layer V neurons. Intriguingly, and to our great surprise, the size of this field changed over time until the spike was evoked. In general the field expanded over the last 20 ms before the spike was evoked. Moreover, the size of the field could be controlled by an early priming stimulation, indicating that the integrating field is not hard coded but can be changed dynamically. The expansion was seen in the presence of AMPA and NMDA antagonists suggesting a local mechanism. We speculate that the observed effect can be explained by a nonlinear dendritic mechanism possibly involving calcium and sodium dynamics. Our findings and technical set up provide directions for defining transfer functions for non-invasive “writing in” of complex spatiotemporal activity patterns in cortex for neuronal prosthetics.
title: Optogenetic surface stimulation reveals dynamic dendritic computations in motor cortex
