text:
In this study, we report that the injection of genetically engineered viral vectors in cat primary visual cortex (area 17) and a higher area (area 21a) can provide expression of channelrhodopsin and corresponding optogenetic control of neuronal activity. We used recombinant adeno-associated viral vectors (AAV2.1/5/9.CamKIIα.hChR2(H134R).eYFP) to transduce neurons in the visual cortex of three adult cats. The vector contained the channelrhodopsin-2 (hChR2) gene under the control of a CamKIIα promoter in order to target excitatory neurons, and was injected either into area 17 or area 21a. After 6-7 weeks, neuronal recordings were performed under isoflurane/sufentanil anesthesia using metal electrodes or multi-contact silicon probes. Optical stimulation with blue light (473 nm) was done by an optrode with 200 µm optical fiber or by surface illumination via a 2 mm optical fiber. Yellow light (593 nm) was used as a control. Surface and optrode stimulation both caused pronounced firing of the recorded multi-units in area 17 and 21a using the AAV2.1 and 2.9 vector. In area 17, spike latency in response to a 2 ms light pulse was 4.5 ms at a power density of 30 mW/mm2 and decreased with higher light intensities to 2.5 ms (60 mW/mm2). At the same time, firing rates increased with increasing light power, saturating around 70 mW/mm2. Spikes could be entrained to the stimulation frequency by both rectangular light pulses (at least up to 80Hz) and continuous wave stimulation. Transduction quality was confirmed by using confocal microscopy. With the AAV2.5 viral vector, we could not evoke any spiking or LFP activity nor could we identify fluorescence.
In summary, these results demonstrate that hChR2 expression in cat visual cortex mediated by rAAV2.1 or rAAV2.9 provides a promising tool for investigating neuronal processing and in particularly rhythmic activity in visual cortex.
title: Optogenetic modulation of neuronal activity in cat visual cortex

text: With the advent of modern stimulation techniques in neuroscience, the opportunity arises to map neuron to neuron connectivity. In this work, we developed a method for efficiently inferring posterior distributions over synaptic strengths in neural microcircuits. The input to our algorithm is data from experiments in which action potentials from putative presynaptic neurons can be evoked while a subthreshold recording is made from a postsynaptic neuron. I will present a realistic statistical model which accounts for the main sources of variability in this experiment and allows for significant prior information about the connectivity and neuronal cell types to be incorporated if available. Due to the technical challenges and sparsity of these systems, it is important to focus experimental time stimulating neurons whose synaptic strength is most ambiguous, therefore we also developed an online optimal design algorithm for choosing which neurons to stimulate at each trial.
title: Bayesian inference and online experimental design for inferring synaptic strengths

text:
Cortical neurons receive massive recurrent input as well as input from subcortical and higher cortical regions. The relative strength, their functional roles and their structure are subject to many theoretical and experimental studies. This is partly due to the difficulties of experimental access: For instance, it is unclear how networks of living cortical cells reacts to well defined spatially structured external inputs, how consistent their responses are and how their activity is modulated by an external drive. 

We address this problem using a cell culture of optogenetically modified rat neurons. We consider this simple two dimension system as surrogate cortex as it resembles cortical tissue to some extend in structure, activity and development [1-3]. We then drive the neurons with spatially complex light patterns, generated by a holographic photostimulation system [4]. The neural responses are monitored with a multielectrode array. 

Here, we show a performance test of our setup, we show that cultured neurons react well to external stimuli and we present some preliminary results of modulations in network activity due to the external drive.
title: Response of neural networks to spatially structured optogenetic input in-vitro

text:
The aim of this work is to provide a global stability analysis for delayed neural field equations with any Lipschitz activation functions and arbitrary connection structures. 
Neural fields provide information of neural activity in time and space, by modeling the neuronal populations involved as a continuum. Delayed neural fields additionally take into account  the spreading of action potentials along the neural axons. A delayed neural field model of $n$ populations of $k\in\{1,2,3\}$ dimensions is given by 
$$ \tau_i \frac{\partial U_i}{\partial t}(r, t) = -{U_i}(r, t) + \int_{\Omega} \sum_{j=1}^n {W_{ij}}(r, r') S_j(U_j(r', t-d_{ij}(r,r')))dr' + {I}_i^{\text{ext}},\quad i\in\{1,\ldots,n\}, $$
where $\Omega\subset \mathbb R^k$ is a bounded set over which the populations are distributed and, for each population, ${U_i(r,t)}$ represents the mean neuronal activity at position $r$ and at time $t$, $\tau_i$ is a time constant, ${I}_i^{\text{ext}}$ is the external input, $d_{ij}(r,r')$ is the time needed for the information of the population $j$ at location $r'$ to reach population $i$ at location $r$, ${W}_{ij}(r,r')$ describes the synaptic strength between location $r'$ in population $j$ and location $r$ in population $i$, and ${S}_j: \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is the activation function of neural populations.

Several works have addressed the stability of neural fields, [1, 2, 3].  In [3] the delayed neural field is linearized around an equilibrium and a local stability analysis is conducted using a Krasovskii-Lyapunov functional. We extend that work by relying on Razumikhin theorem to propose a sufficient condition, involving the Lipschitz constants of the activation functions, the axonal delays, and the synaptic strength, for the delayed neural fields model to have a unique equilibrium to which all solutions converge. Numerical simulations are also provided.
title: A global stability analysis for delayed neural fields

text: In the recent years the complexity and size of neural models developed in the computational neuroscience community increased rapidly. In addition to the easy description of neurons, synapses and connectivity patterns [1] a parallel evaluation of large scale neural network models is particularly important. A number of research groups have focused on developing parallel algorithms and simulators best suited for the simulation of spiking neural models on CPUs but also on the upcoming GPUs, leading to several spiking simulation environments, e. g. Brian [2], NEST [3] or NeMo [4]. We present a neural simulator called ANNarchy (Artificial Neural Network architect) which targets the parallel evaluation of large scale rate-coded networks in addition to spiking neurons, through an explicit model description in Python similar to Brian. ANNarchy is capable of generating C++ and CUDA code allowing the parallel simulation of rate-coded, spiking and hybrid neural networks. Rate-coded and spiking implementations require different evaluation and underlying data structures to achieve an adequate speedup on the specific parallel hardware [5]. We show the suitability of our approach on CPUs and GPUs within our simulation environment at several examples, including randomly connected rate-coded and spiking networks. We show the parallel performance on GPUs and CPUs on more advanced models: a pulse-coupled spiking network and the bar learning problem.
title: ANNarchy: parallel evaluation of rate-coded and spiking neural networks

text: A vast collection of tools is available for researchers in computational neuroscience to efficiently simulate biologically realistic neural networks, for example Brian [1], NEST [2] or NeMo [3]. Most of them propose a set of built-in neural or synaptic models which can be easily parameterized and combined to create a neural network, often through a Python interface. The neuro-simulator Brian proposes an equation-oriented description of neural variables allowing efficient code generation at runtime [4], but is limited to spiking point-neural networks. We present here the neuro-simulator ANNarchy (Artificial Neural Networks architect) which uses a comparable model description mechanism for neuron and synapse models, but allows the simulation of rate-coded, spiking or even hybrid neural networks. Rate-coded neuron models can be described by a set of continuous ordinary differential equations (ODE) and parameters, while spiking point-neuron models can additionally define event-based updates after a spike is emitted. Synaptic transmission and plasticity follow a similar model. These equations are parsed and analysed using the Python library for symbolic mathematics Sympy, numerized using one of the backward, forward or exponential Euler methods and ultimately transformed into a platform specific code (either C++ code using OpenMP for CPUs or CUDA code for GPGPUs). The Python interface for network definition is mostly compliant with PyNN and allows to interface the network with external libraries (either in Python, C or C++) through Cython extension modules. ANNarchy is therefore particularly suited for building complex neural architectures and applying them to real-world problems such as neuro-robotics.
title: ANNarchy: efficient code generation for rate-coded and spiking neural networks.

text:
Fast oscillations of the population firing rate in the gamma range (50-200 Hz), where each individual neuron fires irregularly with a low rate, have been observed in networks of simulated leaky integrate-and-fire (LIF) neurons as well as in population signals in the living brain.
An analytical explanation of oscillatory population rates has been given in [1]. However a systematic approach identifying circuits responsible for specific oscillations in a potentially complicated structured network of populations of neurons is currently not available. Such a method would provide a tool for the identification of connections responsible for the emergence and propagation of oscillations in anatomically constrained networks and shed light on local dynamical mechanisms amplifying or suppressing certain frequencies . It could also be used to design a LIF-network with desired spectral features.

In this study we consider the spectra of population firing rates produced by networks with population specific connectivity. The populations are composed of randomly connected LIF-neurons. In our analysis we make use of the formalism developed in [2], who recently closed the gap between the descriptions of linear rate models and LIF-neurons. We derive an expression for the effective connectivity matrix which incorporates the anatomical (synaptic weights, in-degrees) as well as the dynamical properties [3] of the circuit. We are able to predict the spectra of the population firing rates for any connectivity pattern that allows for asynchronous activity. The analytically obtained predictions are validated by comparison with simulation results of a multi-layered cortical network model [4].

Decomposing the effective connectivity matrix at a frequency where the spectrum shows a peak reveals the dominating eigenmode. By reconstructing the anatomical and dynamical contributions to this eigenmode we can narrow down the physical connections associated with the peak in the power spectrum.
title: Identifying anatomical circuits causing population rate oscillations in structured integrate-and-fire networks

text:
Despite the importance of self-organized structures in networks with spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) [1,2] and a number of simulation reports [3,4] there are only few analytic results published [5]. In the present study we investigate plastic feed-forward networks of nonlinear rate neurons with a correlation sensitive learning rule inspired by and being qualitatively similar to STDP. 
After obtaining equations that describe the change of the spatial shape of the signal from layer to layer  in adiabatic approximation, we derive a criterion for the non-linearity ensuring stable dynamics for arbitrary input: on one side of the critical border every perturbation decays, on the other activity explodes for sufficiently strong perturbations. On the border we analytically find stable self-reproducing solutions with a plateau of arbitrary width. Precise tuning of parameters is required for the existence of such synfire chains. Furthermore, sigmoidal nonlinearities naturally bring the system near to criticality.
On the subcritical side in the vicinity of the border long-living bump solutions still resemble the stable solutions on the border. The velocity of their  decay is independent of bump size  and increases with distance to criticality. Two bumps can unite if the interplay of diffusion and nonlinearity at the activity minimum overcomes the decay within their lifetime, otherwise they remain disjoint. For the united bump the same scenarios exist, so a kind of association tree can appear in this way.

text:
A growing body of research reports the sequential activation of neural assemblies, suggesting that some brain computations are performed through sequence-based dynamics. A number of models have been proposed to explain this type of activation. Kremkow et al. (1) demonstrated that timing differences between correlated excitation and inhibition - temporal gating - can control the propagation of spiking activity transients. We adapted this mechanism in the following scenario. We simulated a recurrent balanced network of 20,000 conductance-based integrate-and-fire neurons and embedded a chain of 3 to 20 gates exploiting the temporal gating principle. We found that this connectivity enables reliable feed-forward propagation and transient amplification along such a chain.
However, in a recurrent network the synchronous activity in a chain can also excite the rest of the network, which then leads to instabilities such as persistent oscillatory activity. If the total excitation is weaker to compensate for such effects, the network elevates its activity during the signal propagation which is followed by the period of hyperpolarization of most of the neurons.
We next investigated the possible role of two mechanisms in stabilising network activity under these conditions. Spike Frequency Adaptation did not prevent the network from entering the oscillatory regime but allowed it to return to its normal state. Short-term plasticity in a form of synaptic depression allowed the network to remain in its stable state and shortened the hyperpolarization following chain activation. Next, we embedded multiple chains to test the robustness of this framework. If the chains are non-overlapping, the signal propagation is successful in all of the chains. When the chains share too many neurons, the signal gets disrupted and may lead to simultaneous activation of two or more chains. The next step is to find the conditions that allow for reliable signal propagation in such overlapping chains.
title: Synaptic depression enables reliable sequential activity cascades in recurrent networks

reasonForTalk: We present a novel homeostatic mechanism, compatible with recent experiments and of broad interest.
text: Gaseous neurotransmitters such as nitric oxide (NO) provide a unique and often overlooked mechanism for neurons to communicate through diffusion within a network, independent of synaptic connectivity. NO provides homeostatic control of intrinsic excitability. Here we conduct a theoretical investigation of the distinguishing roles of NO-mediated diffusive homeostasis in comparison with canonical non-diffusive homeostasis in cortical networks. We find that both forms of homeostasis provide a robust mechanism for maintaining stable activity following perturbations. However, the resulting networks differ, with diffusive homeostasis maintaining substantial heterogeneity in activity levels of individual neurons, a feature disrupted in networks with non-diffusive homeostasis. This results in networks capable of representing input heterogeneity, and linearly responding over a broader range of inputs than those undergoing non-diffusive homeostasis. These results suggest a mechanism for dynamically maintaining neural heterogeneity, and expose computational advantages of non-local homeostatic processes. We currently investigate how these forms of homeostasis might interact with STDP during learning. Preliminary results suggest that diffusive homeostasis enables broader synaptic weight distributions and leads to networks which learn input patterns more effectively than those with non-diffusive homeostasis.
title: A diffusive homeostatic signal maintains neural heterogeneity and responsiveness in cortical networks

text:
It has been known for some time that nerve cells are highly sensitive to synchronous input from larger groups of neurons [1]. Which synchronous patterns are favored by a recurrent network, thus, depends to a large degree on network structure. 
	Recently, Pernice et al. were able to dissect the contribution of specific structural motifs in networks of arbitrary topology to pairwise correlations [3], based on a minimal model for networks of spiking neurons [2]. Unfortunately, the further generalization of this result to higher-order correlations (HOCs) has, until now, never been attempted. 
	In this work, we show that results pertaining to correlations of order 2 can be naturally extended to the case of HOCs. Building on the dynamical system approach of Pernice et al. , we obtain intuitive decomposition formulas, in which cumulants [4] of neuronal spiking activity are seen as weighted sums of network motifs, responsible for their generation. The structures relevant to the emergence of HOCs turn out to be all subtrees of the given network graph, connecting neurons amongst which higher-order interactions have been observed.
	Our results represent a suitable starting point to develop efficient methods for neuronal data analysis, as they reduce the problem of computation of HOCs to one of enumerating all network substructures, capable of generating them. However, as the number of such relevant motifs grows supra-exponentially with correlation order, we also develop a pseudo-algorithm, capable of dealing with this combinatorial problem.
title: Interplay between topology and correlations of higher order in networks of spiking neurons

text:
Neuronal variability constrains  computation and coding, both at the single-cell and circuit level. Such limitations are particularly severe when spike counts within behaviorally relevant time intervals are so low that discretization becomes an issue. For example, grid cells in rat medial entorhinal cortex discharge on average with only 2.0Hz ±1.3Hz (std)), and even the mean maximum firing rate within one of the hexagonally arranged grid field is just 9.7Hz ± 5.3Hz (std), or one spike per theta cycle, the dominant oscillatory component of the local field potential. Notably, grid cells have Fano factors larger than unity (super-Poisson) [1]. In addition, the trial-to-trial fluctuations of spike counts, relative to the values predicted from mean-firing-rate maps, are correlated across grid cells. These noise correlations depend on the spatial overlap of the cell's’ tuning curves [2,3].

Using data from Sargolini et al (2006) [4], we estimate grid-cell firing rates along an animal’s spatial trajectory. These firing rates form the basis of a stochastic model based on inhomogeneous Poisson processes. For Poisson processes without co-modulations, the noise correlations are expected to scatter around zero, but as in [2,3] we observe significant deviations from this prediction. To capture these correlations, we co-modulate the firing rates in a time-dependent fashion. To this end, we take into account that throughout the hippocampal complex, local field potentials exhibit oscillations in the theta frequency band (6-10 Hz). We study the influence of the simultaneously recorded theta signal on the noise correlations and let the modulations in different cells have shifted phases. The match between model and real data suggests a coupling between theta modulations, spatial-grid phase, and noise correlations. This result has implications for the spatial precision of population codes and for models that describe the formation of spatially modulated neuronal discharge.
title: Noise correlations in cortical neurons of navigating rats  and the effect of theta oscillations

text:
Grid cells in rat medial entorhinal cortex are thought to play a critical role for the neural representation of space and, in particular, for spatial navigation. Grid cells are activated whenever the animal is close to a vertex of an imaginary hexagonal lattice spanning the environment [1]. Within each of these firing fields, the spike phases of a grid cell, relative to the theta-band local field potential, tend to occur at successively earlier phases [2]. This phenomenon has been termed “phase precession”. 
Recent studies suggest that phase precession carries spatial information at the single-trial level. This has been shown for rats running back and forth on linear tracks [3] as well as moving freely in two-dimensional environments [4]. We therefore asked whether spike phase or phase-precession can be directly used for path integration. Analyzing single-run data, we find no evidence that the position of the animal is mapped one-to-one onto spike phase. But we do find non-trivial effects if we compare the amount of phase precession along paths through a firing field that intersect twice or multiple times. We discuss these results with respect to their relevance for path integration.
title: Spatial coding of grid cells in rat entorhinal cortex:                                Can phase or phase precession underlie two-dimensional path integration?

text:
Recent experimental findings suggest that plasticity mechanisms of long-term depression involve selective elimination of weak synapses and retaining of strong synapses[1], implying a reorganization of network topology rather than just adjustment of connection weights. Here we present a simple model that explores network topology changes resulting from two different plasticity rules. 
Networks of excitable neurons were modeled with deterministic excitable nodes involving discrete susceptible, exited and refractory states (SER model), where susceptible nodes nodes became excited by excited linked neighbors. Neurons were connected into random networks with varying numbers of nodes (up to 279) and different density of links (varying from 25% to 75% of fully connected). Simulations were randomly initialized with 10% of excited nodes and equal assignment of susceptible and refractory nodes. After fixed intervals, a Hebbian or Spike time-dependent (STD) like plasticity rule was applied, based on the simultaneous or sequential coactivation matrix of the network, respectively. Specifically, the probability of pruning links was proportional to the normalized (simultaneous or sequential) coactivation of linked nodes.  After application of the pruning rules, the same number of pruned connections could be returned to the network in random uniform or local fashion.
Simulations with the Hebbian like plasticity rule shaped initially random networks into modular  networks, with an associated limited range of sustained network activity. By contrast, simulations with the STD like plasticity rule resulted in hub networks, with a clear segregation on in the degree distribution between averagely connected nodes and a small number of highly connected hub nodes. The latter networks displayed a wide dynamic range.
Thus,  despite the relative simplicity of the dynamic model, the two plasticity rules produced networks with  distinctive topological features of modules and hubs that are widely found in biological neural networks.
title: Modules and hubs induced by Hebbian and STD like plasticity rules in excitable networks

text: One distinctive feature of Purkinje cells is that they have two types of discharge: in addition to simple spikes they fire complex spikes in response to input from the climbing fibers. These complex spikes have an initial rapid burst of spikes and spikelets followed by a sustained depolarization; in some models of cerebellar function this climbing fiber input supervises learning in Purkinje cells. On the other hand, synaptic plasticity is often thought to rely on the timing of pre-synaptic and post-synaptic spikes. It is suggested here that the period of depolarization following a complex spike, combined with a simple spike-timing-dependent plasticity rule, gives a mechanism for the climbing fiber to supervise learning in the Purkinje cell. This proposal is illustrated using a simple simulation in which it is seen that the climbing fiber succeeds in supervising the learning.
title: Spike-timing dependent plasticity and supervised learning in cerebellum.

text:
Multielectrode arrays (MEAs) are an excellent tool to record neuronal cell networks derived from human pluripotent stem cells (hPSC-NN) (1,2). In silico modeling of such neuronal networks will enhance our understanding of neuronal systems and their development. In the past, we have built a phenomenological model called INEX (INhibitory-EXcitatory) that was used to simulate developing hPSC-NNs on MEAs. In this paper, we propose a simulation of mature hPSC-NNs by modifying our INEX model to simulate their activity. We focus on synchronous bursts which are a main feature of mature neuronal activity patterns. The INEX model is based on inhomogeneous Poisson processes to simulate spontaneously active neurons (3). Each simulated neuron has either an inhibitory or an excitatory effect to its postsynaptic neurons. The parameter types are chosen in such a way that the resulting spike trains resemble spike trains of in vitro MEA experiments with hPSC-NNs with respect to spike and burst rate. A network with 1,000 neurons and 10 per cent connectivity was simulated. 
For validation, we examined MEA recordings from 9 relatively mature hPSC-NNs performed for approximately 300 seconds 27 to 39 days after plating. We calculated the median and quartiles of the spike and burst rate, the number of spikes per burst and the burst duration using the burst analysis tool by Kapucu et al. (4) for both the simulated and the experimental data. Moreover, we used the detection method of synchronous burst events published by Raichmann and Ben-Jacob (5). The results showed that we can simulate typical spike and burst patterns as known from MEA experiments with mature hPSC-NNs and in particular synchronous bursts. The validation showed that all calculated median values of the INEX data are within the lower and upper quartile of the MEA data. To conclude, the calculated features adapted from spikes and bursts show that matured hPSC-NNs as observed in MEA experiments can be modeled by the INEX model.
title: Simulation of matured neuronal cell networks derived from human pluripotent stem cells

text:
Functional MRI (fMRI) of the ongoing brain activity at rest, i.e., without any overt-directed behavior, has revealed patterns of coherent activity, so called resting-state functional networks. Dynamical organization of nodes into these functional networks is closely related to the underlying structural connections. However, functional correlations have also been observed between cortical regions without apparent neural links, and mechanisms generating functional connectivity between distant cortical regions are largely unknown. It has been suggested that indirect connections and collective effects governed by the network properties of the cortex play a significant role. 

We use a modeling approach in conjunction with experimental data to 
study dynamical aspects of functional connectivity in the human brain. Based on numerical simulations, we investigate the underlying mechanisms with reference to remote synchronization and network symmetry. At first, we demonstrate how the coupling topology is extracted. Our procedure is based on connectivity maps derived from fMRI and diffusion tensor imaging experiments, combining both functional and structural connectivity. Consequently, our network model includes the important information whether direct or indirect neural connections exist between functionally associated regions. 

Neural activity and inferred hemodynamic response of the network nodes are modeled as self-sustained oscillators embedded in topologies of complex functional brain interactions. In the simulated functional networks, we find that remote synchrony between pairs of nodes arises from symmetry in the interactions, which are quantified by the number of shared neighbors. An increasing size of a joint neighborhood positively correlates with a higher level of synchrony. Therefore, our results indicate that a large overlapping neighborhood in complex networks of brain interactions gives rise to functional similarity between distant cortical regions.
title: Functional connectivity of distant cortical regions: Role of remote synchronization and symmetry in interactions

text:
The interaction of multiple forms of plasticity was shown to be able to lead to the development of interesting dynamical properties in neural network models [Vogels2012, Tetzlaff2012, Zheng2013] and is also believed to play a vital role for network function of biological neural networks [Vitureira2013].

Previously, we showed that endowing balanced state random networks of leaky integrate-and-fire neurons with a combination of excitatory and inhibitory spike-timinig-dependent plasticity (STDP) rules and synaptic scaling can lead to stable effects of self-organization [Effenberger2013]. In particular, we observed that the synaptic plasticity rules allow a fraction of the excitatory cells to become driver neurons that form strong excitatory synapses to their postsynaptic targets. Driver cells in our model act as leader neurons, a concept that attained substantial experimental interest in the last years [Eckmann2008, Pasquale2013].

We present here an detailed analysis of this phenomenon and show that a delicate interplay of the different forms of synaptic plasticity leads to the observed effects of self-organization. We separated influences from different sourses in a set of simplified models that serve as a mean-field approximation to the particular aspects of the network dynamics. By studying their properties we gain a deeper understanding of the derived phenomena and are able to support our simulation results by analytical arguments.
title: On the interaction of different synaptic plasticity rules in balanced random networks

text:
The auditory brainstem of the barn owl, and in particular the coincidence detection circuit in nucleus laminaris, provides an exceptional model system to study the emergence of extracellular electrical potentials. The stereotyped spatial arrangement of axons and neurons and the well known input of the nucleus laminaris facilitate a quantitative understanding of the origins of evoked potentials. We take advantage of these properties in modelling extracellular potentials due to synaptic and axonal currents, and we compare the model to electrophysiological data.

We present a minimal model of one-dimensional axon bundles that affords analytical treatment, and a biophysical model that is able to incorporate more details such as the axonal nodes of Ranvier and current kinetics. On the basis of these models, we are able to understand several previously unexplained aspects of the evoked potentials: the spatio-temporal structure of the responses to transients, which is due to the arrangement of bifurcations and terminations in the axon bundles, and the signatures of synaptic adaptation. 

To test the computational models, we analysed extracellular electrophysiological recordings of the responses to auditory stimuli in anaesthetised owls, in normal condition and during iontophoretic application of synaptic blockers. Adaptation is revealed by the comparison of these control and synaptic blocker conditions, and the observed adaptation matches the behaviour of the biophysical model. Here, the system provides a rare opportunity to study the dynamics of synaptic adaptation in vivo.

The results presented here can be used to understand the nature of noninvasively measured potentials such as the auditory brainstem response. Furthermore, they can help elucidate the role that active currents play in the generation of field potentials observed in other brain regions, which were previously thought to be largely passive in origin.
title: Modelling and analysis of extracellular field potentials in the auditory brainstem: spatial-temporal structure of fields and the role of synaptic adaptation

text:
Calcium imaging techniques have been used to monitor the dynamic activity of both individual neurons and assemblies of neurons.  With these techniques the accurate reconstruction of action potentials (APs) from fluorescence signals is restricted because of noise, the low temporal resolution of these signals, as well as by an indirect nonlinear relationship between intracellular calcium transients and the membrane potential. Therefore, several approaches for AP reconstruction from calcium imaging data have been introduced, for example template matching [1], deconvolution [2], and  sequential Monte Carlo methods [3]. 

In the present work, we propose to apply Bayesian inference to well-established biophysical models thereby inferring the underlying neuronal activity so that APs can be detected. This method adopts a generative model, including evolution (spiking model) and observation (fluorescence-calcium mapping) equations so that the neuronal membrane potential and calcium kinetics are connected to fluorescence signal generation. This generative model is inverted using variational Bayes [4] to infer the biophysical parameters of the neuron, such as membrane potential (thus, APs), and calcium transients. The framework can adopt models of different complexity, for example Hodgkin–Huxley model [5], burst firing models [6], novel non-hybrid leaky integrate and fire models and phenomenological models. We propose to identify the best model to explain calcium imaging data using Bayesian model comparison [4]. We applied and validated the framework on both simulated and real data from the CA3 area of hippocampal slices.

In conclusion, the new technique enables the parameter optimization of biophysically plausible models and Bayesian model comparison using calcium imaging data. This is not only useful for reconstructing APs but may also be used to infer parameter changes, e.g. due to a pharmacological intervention.
title: Reconstruction of action potentials from calcium imaging data using biophysical models and Bayesian inference

text: Studies carried out on human subjects during upright standing hypothesized that RI may be a better source of feedback control since the Tibialis Anterior (TA) proprioceptive activity is unmodulated by the homonymous muscle activation during postural sway [1]. Here, the role of RI on human postural control was investigated by computer simulations performed on a biologically based large-scale neuromusculoskeletal model. Mathematical models were used to represent the fundamental neuromechanical elements of the postural control system (see Figure 1), such as: i) spinal MNs and INs associated to the motor nuclei of the Triceps Surae and TA muscles [2]; ii) musculotendon units; iii) muscle receptors; iv) sensory fibers; and v) an inverted pendulum that represents the human body during upright standing. Two model structures (Model 1 – without RI; Model 2 – with RI) were used to evaluate the role of the RI pathway on postural control. Time- and frequency-domain metrics associated to the postural sway were calculated from the simulations to validate the model outcomes with respect to the experimental data from the literature [3]. Additionally, cross-correlation analysis was performed between muscle fiber lengths and center of mass (COM) displacements. Simulation results showed that both models reproduced the postural control metrics frequently observed from vestibular-loss subjects standing on a stable surface without visual feedback. For the Soleus muscle, cross-correlation analyses showed a predominance of “paradoxical” behavior (negative length-COM correlation) for the Model 2, whereas Model 1 exhibited a predominant “orthodox” behavior. Gastrocnemii and TA muscles always exhibited an “orthodox” behavior. These results reinforce the view that “paradoxical” muscle fibre behavior may be influenced by RI [1]. Nonetheless, even in the absence of RI (such as in some neurological disorders) the posture control may be achieved through the autogenic feedback pathways.
title: The role of reciprocal inhibition on human postural control

text: The random-dot-motion (RDM) task, which tests motion signal perception in noise, has proved extremely useful in the study of sensory decision-making. Neuronal recordings in monkeys have revealed how motion-direction information is accumulated between stimulus onset and a monkey’s decision and inspired much recent work on applying stochastic diffusion models to decision-making. However, a non-invasive and easily-measured variable that reflects the dynamics of decision-making in humans at a fine temporal scale remains to be found. . Here, we evaluate whether slow eye movements (SEMs) in humans viewing a RDM pattern are correlated with their ongoing decision-making process, inspired by the known parallels between motion perception and SEMs (like smooth pursuit). Human subjects viewed a low-coherence RDM pattern containing signal dots moving to the left or right and indicated their decision about motion direction using either a keyboard press (Experiment 1), a horizontal saccade (Experiment 2) or a vertical saccade (Experiment 3). Independent of response modality, their eyes slowly moved (“drifted”) on average in the direction of the impending decision in all three experiments. Trials with SEMs were associated with better performance. The average SEMs on error trials indicated the direction of the subject’s incorrect response, rather than the direction of the coherently moving dots. SEMs in the direction of the subjects’ response were also found in trials using zero-coherence stimuli. SEMs appear to show a pattern similar to that of the neural activity of single neurons in monkey parietal cortex reported in the literature. SEMs may thus provide a non-invasive window into decision-making and allow the testing of motion-processing models with high temporal resolution and on a trial-by-trial basis.
title: Using slow eye movements to test models of human perceptual decision-making

text:
Unsupervised learning in neuronal networks involves various mechanisms of neuromodulation. In particular, extrasynaptic level of dopamine (DA) may play a critical role in long-term changes of synaptic strength. In modeling spike-timing dependent plasticity (STDP) rule modulated by DA has been proposed to resolve the distal reward problem (Izhikevich, 2007). Using the single synapse model has explained several network level phenomena of reinforcement learning, i.e. classical and instrumental conditioning, shifting the DA increase from response to unconditioned to conditioned stimuli (Izhikevich, 2007) and increase the firing rate of an arbitrarily chosen neuron (Legenstein, Pecevski, & Maass, 2008). Following those results we presented a model of network level learning based on reward dependent changes of synaptic efficacies. The model is proposed in the form of a recurrent network of spiking neurons randomly connected by DA-modulated STDP plasticity synapses. 
Key properties of network-level learning associated with DA-modulated STDP rules were formulated and examined using computer simulations. Changes of synaptic efficacies in the whole network during the reinforcement learning procedure were studied. The learning mechanisms were illustrated using an example of the network solving a particular task. In this simple example the reward dependent synaptic changes occurred when the chosen neuronal group was activated in a pre-defined spatial order. Stability of the reinforced synapses and interplay between the new reinforced groups of neurons and the existed ones were investigated. The informational capacity of the network as the maximal numbers of co-existing non-interfering neuronal groups was estimated depending on the plasticity parameters and the network properties.
title: Role of dopamine modulation of synaptic plasticity in network level learning

text:
Globus pallidus externa (GPe) is proposed to mediate the NoGo pathway in Basal Ganglia (BG). Until recently, GPe was considered to be a homogeneous network but recent experimental data shows that GPe is composed of two sub-populations expressing either parvalbumin (GPe-TI) or preproenkephalin (GPe-TA). Interestingly, GPe-TA neurons fire in-phase with Subthalamic Nucleus (STN) neurons during cortical slow wave activity (SWA) and target upstream (striatum) while GPe-TI neurons fire in anti-phase with STN neurons and target downstream BG nuclei, (STN and GPi) [1]. Here, we studied the consequences of this dichotomy using a mean field model of BG. The unknown network parameters were fitted by tuning the mean field model to reproduce the results in [4]. Recently a mean field model has been used to make predictions about effective connectivity of GPe-TA ,TI and STN network [5]. However, in this work, inconsistent with the data, pallidostriatal back projections were ignored. Here, we show that including striatum introduces more parameter regimes that can fit [4]. We also confirm our findings in a spiking network model of BG [3].

Our results provide many insights. Firstly, we found that multiple parameter combinations could replicate the results in [4]. This implies, that there are multiple mechanisms to manifest a pathological state of the BG network and can explain the limited efficacy of therapeutic measures in alleviating the disease related symptoms. Secondly, we provide predictions about effective connectivity to/from GPe sub-populations to other BG nuclei including striatum, for example, (1) striatal input to GPe-TI should be much stronger than to GPe-TA (2) GPe-TI is the more dominant projection among GPeTA-TI interactions etc.
Lastly, our model suggests that dichotomy in the two GPe sub-populations plays an integral role in maintaining their anti-phase relationship during SWA, segregating the two sub-populations as separate functional pathways.
title: Homologous pathological network states in basal ganglia and the dichotomous GPe – a mean field study

text:
Characterization of the dynamics of purely inhibitory network is crucial for understanding the computations performed by brain areas such as the striatum, globus pallidus and central amygdala. Previously, networks of inhibitory neurons have been studied for their oscillatory dynamics [1], winner-take-all (WTA) properties [2], traveling waves [3], etc. Recently, network simulations [4] and experimental data [5-7] suggest that purely inhibitory networks could also support transient neuronal assemblies.

Here, we investigated the effect of spatial connectivity structure on the emergence and maintenance of spatially clustered activity in large-scale inhibitory networks of 10,000 leaky-integrate-and-fire (LIF) model neurons. We considered two different types of spatial connectivity structures in which the connection probability decreased as a function of distance, according to (1) a Gaussian and (2) a Gamma distribution.

In networks with Gaussian connectivity, the activity remained asynchronous irregular (AI), independent of the external input. However, in networks with Gamma function type spatial connectivity (gamma-nets), the activity dynamics changed qualitatively, depending on the input strength: weak external input induced AI activity; mid-range input organized the activity into unstable spatial clusters,  resembling the experimentally observed neuronal assemblies and winner-less-competition (WLC) [8]; and stronger external input induced stable WTA type dynamics. 

Next, we studied the effect of external stimuli on the spatial structure of ongoing activity in gamma-nets. We found that in the WTA state only very strong inputs could alter the structure of the network activity. By contrast, in the AI and WLC regimes, network dynamics were flexible and could be used for stimulus encoding. Finally, we discuss the implications of these different dynamics and their stimulus interactions for the function and dysfunction of the striatum.
title: Flexibility of inhibitory networks to external stimuli

text: The cerebellum is an important node of the neural network hosting inverse and forward internal models to generate the required motor commands for a desired movement and to predict sensory consequences of the applied motor commands, respectively. Therefore, cerebellar damage is associated with disability to adapt internal models, leading to deficient motor performance against perturbations. However, in recent studies, cerebellar patients showed some adaptation to gradually applied perturbations in reaching tasks. This residual motor learning ability has been linked to the remaining capacity of the central nervous system to learn the inverse model dynamics. Recently, we also showed that the cerebellar ataxia patients can re-optimize head movement kinematics during large gaze shifts when the head moment of inertia is 3.3 fold increased [1]. However, it is not clear whether and to what extent the residual optimizing ability is dependent on the adaptation of inverse or forward models of the head dynamics. Here, we present a control systems model on the head movements in order to identify the necessary mechanisms to be updated following altered effector dynamics, i.e. increased head inertia. With the model, we assessed the contributions of internal models on movement kinematics during large gaze shifts in 9 cerebellar ataxia patients and 10 healthy subjects. We found that, without updating the forward model, it is still possible to improve the head movement kinematics optimally. Specifically, by updating the inverse model, the system can decrease head oscillations, maintain optimal movement durations, and increase peak velocity towards the new optimum over the course of the trials with increased inertia, just as in our cerebellar subjects. These suggest that the extra-cerebellar motor control network can still implement the inverse models and re-optimize the desired trajectory based on the up-to-date inverse model even without a correctly adapted forward model.
title: Adaptation of internal models to altered head plant dynamics during gaze shifts in cerebellar ataxia

text: We investigate the problem of inferring interaction properties of coupled dynamical systems with phase based methods using an approximation of the underlying phase evolution equations in terms of a functional basis. A recently published modification promises wider applicability of these methods with better time resolution and same accuracy by using Bayesian inference and knowledge propagation. We investigate the capability and limitations of this new framework. Its performance is compared to well-established least square methods at the example of well-known linear and non-linear, structurally identical or dififferent model systems. We point out that care should be taken when interpreting obtained results, as inferred information about coupling directionality and strength are misleading if the investigated dynamics are not adequately approximated by phase based methods. Tracking of time-varying coupling parameters requires a limitation of knowledge propagation. We present an improved method for the time-resolved inference of interaction properties, which obtains comparable or better accuracy without sensitive dependance upon the choice of an internal parameter of the inference algorithm as the original algorithm. We apply this new method to intracranial, multichannel EEG recordings from epilepsy patients and present time-evolving interaction properties of different communicating brain areas, which allows tracking of the dynamics of epileptic brain networks at a priorly not accessible time resolution.
title: Time-resolved inference of interaction properties of coupled dynamical systems

text: Neuronal activity in the hippocampus and its relation to the encoding of space has mostly been studied in freely behaving rats and mice. Here, we report on data recorded in CA1 and CA3 hippocampal subfields of Mongolian gerbils in virtual reality (VR). Using a VR, we can study the impact of visual cues on place cells independent of self-motion cues. In both, real and virtual environments, we find hippocampal place cells that encode specific locations by their place fields. When the animal moves through such a place field, place cell spikes precess relative to hippocampal theta oscillations (phase precession). As in rats and mice, the local field potential (LFP) of Mongolian Gerbils has high power in the theta range (4-12 Hz). In virtual reality however we find that theta frequency reduces in comparison to theta recorded in real environments. During periods of immobility or slow wave sleep (SWS), place cells are taking part in population bursts that are temporally correlated to sharp wave-ripple (SWR) complexes. Our results show that firing patterns of hippocampal place cells in VR are largely similar to those in real environments.
title: Characterizing gerbil hippocampal activity in virtual reality

text:
We used nanostimulation, a technique which allows stimulation of identified single neurons in vivo [1] in order to drive pyramidal cells in anesthetized rat motor cortex.
Using this method we find that stimulating with fluctuating stimuli (frozen bandpass-limited white noise) results in increased spike timing reliability. Specifically, we report that parametrically increasing the noise level results in increased spike train synchronization.
We also explore how well the spike train in response to this stimulus can be captured by an exponential integrate-and-fire neuron [2], a simple model that has been successfully applied for reproducing spike times of pyramidal cells under noisy current stimulation in vitro [3].
In contrast to the in vitro situation, our model also includes an appreciable amount of intrinsic noise, accounting for fluctuating input from the surrounding network.
title: Spike timing reliability and information transfer under noisy juxtacellular stimulation - Experiment and theory

text: Population activity in the cortex shows alternating periods of collective, sustained firing and neuronal silence. We model these so called UP/DOWN states in an analytically tractable framework as dichotomous noise, a stochastic process that jumps between two states. This work studies the spike train statistics of a perfect integrate-and-fire neuron receiving such an input. Unlike previous studies, we consider asymmetric dichotomous noise with two different transition rates.  We derive the interspike interval distribution and serial correlation coefficient by solving a first-passage-time problem and check the analytical results by numerical simulations. Furthermore, we get approximations for a generalized model framework including additional weak leakage as well as additive white noise. The results may help to understand the influence of correlations in presynaptic signals on neuronal firing.
title: The perfect integrate-and-fire neuron driven by asymmetric dichotomous noise

text:
Firing patterns in cortical networks are often modeled by assuming Poissonian input spike trains. Imposing self-consistency at the level of firing rates (input rate of driving cells = output rate of driven cell) then yields an analytical description of network dynamics (see e.g. Brunel J. Comp. Neurosci. 2000). However, output spike trains are usually non-Poissonian, something a more coherent framework should account for. Here we present two iterative procedures that only employ repeated simulations of a single neuron and yield, over a sufficient number of generations of the procedure, the self-consistent statistics at the level of spike-train auto-correlations.

In the renewal approximation, presynaptic action potentials have the same interspike-interval distribution as output spike trains from the previous generation. In the Gaussian approximation, the synaptic input of a neuron is given by the mean and fluctuations of the previous generation. Both procedures are carried out until the power spectrum of the output spike train does not change anymore. We test both approximations by comparing the  resulting stationary spectra from the procedures to those obtained in simulations of a large sparse recurrent network of LIF neurons. Our results show that a self-consistent determination of the temporal structure of spike trains is possible for a recurrent network poised close to the balanced state.
title: Self-consistent determination of spike-train power spectra in sparse neural networks of leaky integrate-and-fire neurons

text:
Ocular dominance (OD) plasticity in the mouse primary visual cortex (V1) declines during aging and is absent beyond postnatal day (PD) 110 when mice are raised in standard cages (SC)(1). In contrast, raising mice in an enriched environment (EE) preserved a juvenile-like OD plasticity into late adulthood(2). EE-raising provides the mice with more social interactions (larger groups), more voluntary physical exercise (running wheels) and more cognitive stimulation (regularly changed labyrinths) compared to SCs, raising the question whether all components are needed or whether one of them is already sufficient to prolong plasticity. To test whether voluntary physical exercise alone prolongs OD-plasticity, we raised mice from 7 days before birth in slightly larger than normal SCs (27x43x19cm) with or without a running wheel (RW) and visualized V1-activities in adulthood (>PD135) before and after monocular deprivation (MD) using intrinsic signal optical imaging. RW-raised mice continued to show an OD-shift towards the open eye after 7 days of MD into adulthood (age range: PD135-260): the ODI decreased from 0.26±0.03 without MD to 0.05±0.03 after MD (t-test; p<0.01), while SC-mice without a RW did not show OD-plasticity (noMD: 0.32±0.02, MD: 0.25±0.03; t-test; p>0.05). In addition, the OD-shift of RW-mice was mediated by a decrease of deprived eye responses in V1, which was previously seen only in 4-week-old SC-raised mice(3), or in adult EE-mice(2). We thus conclude that voluntary physical exercise alone can extend the sensitive phase for OD-plasticity in mouse V1 into late adulthood.

text: In an excitatory presynapse, the signal transductions are executed by a complex cytomatrix of functionally streamlined proteins in the active zones. The inception of assembly of these molecules mark the genesis of the presynapse. Though investigations have provided insights about the various attributes of these molecules, there is still a need for a model which holistically integrates their pathways. In this work, we have devised a petri-net based framework to trace the morphological changes of the presynapse during different stages of genesis and development in 2D. We have envisaged feedback mechanisms involving the signaling cascades of the neurotransmitter wastage factor and retrograde signaling cues based on the activity and presynaptic release probability. The crux of our model is to interleave the feedback cascades, mechanisms of the active zones (endocytosis, exocytosis, vesicle re-uptake and refilling) and CAM with the actin cytoskeleton based morphological changes thereby linking structure with function. We have formulated the exocytosis model based on the “SNARE hypothesis” and have assumed that Clathrin and membrane and vesicular proteins mediate the endocytosis in a scenario well-endowed in vesicles. VMAT and H+-Glutamate transporter regulates the endosomal refilling process based on the proton gradient caused by the V-ATPase. Cannabinoid receptor's “lock and key” mechanism and activity dependent stimulation of cAMP pathway by autoreceptors are incorporated in the feedback mechanisms. We have attempted to model the actin-vesicle dynamics by coupling the Profilin, Cofilin, Arp2/3 and Gelsolin based Actin treadmilling process with Synapsin based control of readily releasable pools. Parameters like localization and distribution of CAM's which play critical role in morphogenesis of presynapse were also analysed as a part of our study. The synergic and fictile relationship between the pre and postsynapses is one that requires further study.
title: Activity based morphological changes of an excitatory glutamatergic presynapse: an integrated model

text:
The ability to recognize previously visited places is determined by the sensory information available at a place and possibly context from neighboring places. Waller, Loomis, Golledge and Beall (2002) showed that for places enclosed by a landmark configuration, where gaze shifts are required to perceive the entire surround, distance information is preferred over direction information. Only if all directions to landmarks at the goal location are orthogonal to each other, participants preferred the angles between landmarks as a cue. Still the role of landmark distance for place encoding remains unclear. The present study focuses on the influence of distance information by measuring position judgments for goals with different landmark configurations. 
One group of participants navigated in a configuration of four landmarks which build up a parallelogram and another group was tested in a non-regular quadrilateral configuration. In a virtual environment participants were asked to navigate on a plus-shaped bridge crossing a pond starting from all compass directions. In the learning phase each trial involved a 90 degree turn at the center of the bridge which was thus learned incidentally. In the test phase the whole environment was covered by ground fog. Participants were asked to recognize the crossing point via the four outstanding landmarks.
The results showed that the non-regular quadrilateral group was significantly biased from the crossing point and the error ellipse was elongated towards landmarks further away from the crossing point. In contrast the average decision points per participant in the parallelogram group were not significantly biased. Still, the error ellipse was again elongated towards more distant landmarks.
We conclude that the relative distances of the set of landmarks available at the goal location is relevant for place encoding. This may be related to the decreasing reliability of depth estimates for more distant landmarks.
title: Distribution of place recognition errors depends on eccentricity of landmark configuration

text:
There is enormous interest in creating autonomous walking robots that can efficiently navigate in complex environment. Up to date  such robots can perform a variety of complex behaviors including walking over rough terrain due to elaborate programming. However most of them still fail to handle or walk around in an environment with multiple obstacles. Existing approaches include reactive control like Braitenberg control [1] and minimal recurrent control (MRC) networks [2,3,4]. Typically, the MRC outperforms Braitenberg control but fails when facing complicated environments [2]. This is because it functions as reactive obstacle avoidance behavior control. According to this, in this work we extend the MRC with a synaptic plasticity rule (see Figure 1a).
The main difference between artificial agents and biological creatures has been so far adaptability and here we see the key point for better behavior control for our agent (see Figure 1b, 1c). Therefore we decide to use an adaptive synaptic scaling algorithm proposed by Tetzlaff et al. [5] as the plasticity rule, in order to solve also complex environments. This rule provides adaptivity and stability to the controller. 
Different variants of synaptic plasticity are evaluated, as well as environments with different levels of complexity. When applying the synaptic plasticity rule properly to the MRC, the obstacle avoidance mechanism becomes very robust and enables the robot to navigate in a very complex environment (see Figure 1d). Some of the evaluated environments are difficult enough and can be seen as realistic models of real environments. An example of the MRCs performance in a complex environment is given in Figure 1d. From the starting position (0,-1) the robot starts to avoid the obstacles in front of it and explores also the environment. Even the enclosure at (2,-2) is no problem for the algorithm and AMOSII escapes quickly.
title: Using synaptic plasticity in minimal recurrent networks for adaptive obstacle avoidance of a walking robot

text:
Reservoir computing refers to a class of recurrent neural network models, like Echo State Networks [1] and Liquid State Machines [2], which consist of an input layer, a large reservoir layer with random recurrent connections and a layer of trainable readout units, that is capable of performing nonlinear memory dependent computations. Given a sufficiently large reservoir or liquid computing network, these models possess universal computational powers [2] with the ability to approximate any nonlinear function. In principle, large reservoirs have the benefit of being very versatile in application as they are not specialized to a specific task. However, the downside of big, task independent networks is that they comprise a lot of units with relatively small influence on the readout, along with a high training complexity. By relinquishing the versatility of the network, task specificity can be exploited for much smaller networks. Previous work has shown that for a given problem small, manually created, non-random networks can reach the same performance as normal sized random networks [3]. Instead of creating problem specific networks from scratch, which can take a lot of time, this work presents a way of adapting random recurrent networks to a given task by reducing it to the most important subset of units.
This simple, information theoretic based algorithm for network pruning incrementally deletes the unit, which shares the least mutual information with the readout units. Using a rate coded neuron model, the algorithm was tested with different initial network topologies, including poisson random graphs, scale-free networks and small-world networks. The tasks, these networks were adapted to, ranged from purely memory dependent to purely nonlinear problems. Not only could the network size dramatically be reduced without impairing the performance, but also did the performance on nonlinear tasks improve after pruning.
title: Information theoretic pruning of recurrent neural networks for task specific adaptation

text: An integrative view of neural circuits and mechanical components has been developed by neuroscientists and biomechanical scientists [1]. This view argues that mechanical components (e.g., muscles) cannot be isolated from neural circuits in the context of substantially perturbed locomotion [2, 3]. Based on these findings, we developed a neuromechanical controller [4] consisting of a modular neural network (MNN) and virtual agonist-antagonist muscle mechanisms (VAAMs). The MNN basically forms complex sensorimotor coordination while the VAAMs generate variable compliant leg motions of a hexapod robot. Specifically, the compliant leg motions are achieved by only changing the stiffness parameters of the VAAMs without any passive mechanisms or torque and position feedback [5, 6]. The neuromechanical control can be modelled as a set of distributed and closed loops with feedforward and feedback pathways (see Figure. 1). For feedforward pathways, the controller consists of feedfoward control via descending commands (i.e.,$S$, $N_{i}$, and $O_{i}$) from a neural circuit to muscle-like mechanisms and body mechanics. In feedback pathway, there is force sensing (i.e., $F_{j}$ ) at the end effectors of the legs. In the controller, the MNN (see Figure. 1 (a)) generates signals for inter- and intra-leg coordinations of the hexapod robot. The virtual agonist-antagonist mechanisms (VAAMs) (see Figure. 1 (b)) are developed for simulating muscle-like behaviors (e.g., variable compliant leg motions). Specifically, each joint of the hexapod robot is driven by a VAAM consisting of a pair of agonist and antagonist mechanisms. Changing the stiffness parameters (i.e., $K_{i}$) of the VAAMs enables AMOS (see Figure. 1 (c)) to achieve variable compliant leg motions, thereby leading to adaptive and energy efficient walking on six surfaces (see Figure. 1 (d)). The video clip of the advanced walking behavior can be seen at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=odzf8iyt5y0 .
title: Neuromechanical Control for Adaptive Hexapedal Walking on Challenging Surfaces

text:
Sleep plays an active role in memory consolidation and especially slow wave sleep (SWS) seems to be important for the transfer of recently encoded memory representations into long-term stores.

Consolidation of declarative memory relies on a dialog between neocortex and hippocampus, where cortical slow oscillations, thalamic spindles and hippocampal sharp wave ripples are thought to be key players. However, their individual contribution is not fully resolved.

Recently, auditory closed-loop stimulation of slow oscillations has been shown to effectively enhance memory.

In this study we investigated the effect of phase-independent acoustic stimulation on declarative memory consolidation. Subjects were continuously presented groups of three click sounds (pink  noise of 50ms duration each) during slow wave sleep throughout the first half of the night. The first stimulus within a group served as a reset by triggering an individual slow oscillation event (K-complex).  The second and third stimuli were delivered such that they concurred in time with the predicted up states of the induced slow oscillations (P900 components). Between stimulus groups there was a pause of 5-9s.

Although the induced oscillations are comparable to the phase-dependent version reported by Ngo et al. (2013) stimulation was not effective in changing the performance of human subjects in a paired associate learning (PAL) task (p=0.11, N=15).

Spindle power was significantly enhanced in response to the first click (p<0.001, N=15), but it was decreased across the entire stimulation period (p<0.001, N=15). The latter was most pronounced in the 5-9s interval between tones. Contrary to spindle activity, power in the SO band (0.5-1.1Hz) increased during the stimulation period (p<0.05, N=15).

Our results indicate that auditory stimulation applied independent of the endogenous slow oscillation phase is not sufficient to enhance memory consolidation.
title: Effects of phase-independent auditory stimulation on sleep and memory

text:
Snake-like robots conventionally use undulation movements for locomotion [1], [2]. In contrast, a nonstandard snake-like robot having four screw-drive units which are connected serially by three active joints [3] uses propulsion by rotating its screw-drive units to move. Employing this screw-drive mechanism, undulation is not required for its locomotion. This helps it to move in narrow spaces. However, generating its goal-directed locomotion is a challenging control problem. In this work, we tackle the problem by using a reinforcement learning approach, called Policy Improvement using Path Integrals (PI$^2$) [4]. PI$^2$ is numerically simple and has an ability to deal with high dimensional systems. Here, it is used as a model-free learning mechanism to find a proper combination of seven locomotion control parameters (three yaw joint angles and four screw unit angular velocities) of the robot for moving towards a given goal. The learning process is achieved using simulation and the learned parameters are successfully transferred to the real robot.
Experiments show that the robot with different body configurations (like, straight-line, zigzag, arc, etc.) can effectively move toward any given goal (see supplementary video at http://www.manoonpong.com/BCCN$2014$/SnakeRobot.wmv). In this way, a large repertoire of robot behaviors are obtained and used as motor primitives for generating other new behaviors online. By selecting different primitives and properly chaining them along with parameter interpolation and/or sensory feedback techniques, the robot can successfully handle complex tasks like, reaching a single goal or multiple goals while avoiding obstacles and compensating to a change of its body shape. 
Taken together this study suggests how the PI$^2$ reinforcement learning approach can be used to solve coordination problem of many degrees-of-freedom systems, like the nonstandard snake-like robot, and to generate goal-directed locomotion in a complex environment.
title: A Reinforcement Learning Approach for Goal-directed Locomotion of a Complex Snake-Like Robot

text: Correlations in neural activity can severely impair the processing of information in neural networks. In finite-size networks, correlations are inevitable due to common presynaptic sources. Recent theoretical studies have shown that inhibitory feedback, abundant in biological neural networks, can actively suppress these shared-input correlations. For networks of spiking neurons, the decorrelating effect of inhibitory feedback has so far been demonstrated explicitly only for homogeneous networks of neurons with linear subthreshold dynamics. The underlying theory, however, suggests that the effect is a general phenomenon which should occur in any recurrent system with inhibitory feedback, irrespective of the details of the network structure and the neuron properties. In this study, we investigate the effect of network heterogeneity on correlations in inhibitory networks with conductance-based synapses, implemented in analog neuromorphic hardware (Spikey) [3]. The configurability and precision of the hardware substrate allows us to modulate the extent of network heterogeneity in a systematic manner, and to selectively study the effects of shared-input and recurrent connections on correlations in synaptic inputs and spike trains. We confirm that shared-input correlations are actively suppressed by inhibitory feedback also in highly heterogeneous networks with broad firing-rate distributions. This decorrelation becomes, however, less efficient with increasing heterogeneity. While cell and synapse heterogeneity leads to a decrease in shared-input correlations, active decorrelation is impaired as a consequence of a diminished effective feedback. Overall, with intact feedback, we observe increasing correlations with increasing heterogeneity. Finally, this study demonstrates that the configurability, speed and user-friendliness of the Spikey neuromorphic system qualifies this analog hardware substrate as a powerful research tool to address neuroscientific questions.
title: Decorrelation of neural-network activity on heterogeneous neuromorphic hardware

text:
In this work we experiment with velocity and direction predictions from visual information ("visual odometry") as a test­bed application for relational features, with potential applicability in automotive and robotics tasks.  

A simple approach to learning motion representations by relating frames in a video is presented in [1]. The approach is based on detecting "spatio-temporal synchrony" between learned features and the observed frames across time. The model resembles “complex cell” like units, also known as motion energy models, which encode correlations between pixels across image pairs. In contrast to the classic motion energy model, the synchroy-based approach is a single-layer module that allows for local, Hebbian-type learning to extract features from video data. An extension to learning depth and motion information at the same time using multi-camera video data was subsequently presented in [2]. 

Here we incorporate the synchrony-based depth-motion modules into a convolutional neural network (CNN) to learn local representation for motion and depth from higher resolution stereo sequences. We then learn to relate the extracted representations to local changes in velocity and direction, thus we train the model to perform "visual odometry" from the data. As a proof-of-concept, we evaluate our approach on the odometry dataset from the KITTI Vision benchmark [3], consisting of gray scale stereo sequences and real world pose information, collected from a driving vehicle. We train our model on local 3-D stereo patch pairs to predict local change in velocity and local change in direction. Preliminary results show that the architecture is capable of learning resulting mapping from video to ego­motion. Our work is a step towards a fully learning-based architecture, based on a single computational module and learning rule, to learn to extract motion, depth, and odometry information from raw data. Future work will focus on increasing the accuracy of the predictions.
title: Learning visual odometry with a convolutional network

text:
There have been several contributions on human motion detection and action recognition over the past two decades. However detection of abnormal and suspicious behaviors in video surveillance is currently one of the most interesting studies for many research groups in computer vision and artificial intelligence. There are two well-known models to detect suspicious behaviors; misuse detection model and anomaly detection model. Misuse detection model is related to definition of suspicious behavior while anomaly detection model measures the difference between the defined normal behaviors and the current behavior. 
We employed the first model to classify human behaviors into normal, abnormal and suspicious types according to trajectory and spatio-temporal domains. In the former we define some abnormal trajectories, like crinkle or loitering trajectories and then compare patterns of input trajectories for each person with the predefined abnormal trajectory. In the second domain some special regions on a scene which are not usual for walking are predefined. If a person stays there more than a threshold time, his behavior will be assumed as an abnormal one. Under some conditions abnormal type will be interpreted as a suspicious type. This is done by introducing a "normality level" which determines the commonality level of each behavior. If a behavior has a high "normality level" value, it is normal and lower values show abnormal and suspicious types of behavior. Employing both domains simultaneously provides high degree of accuracy in the proposed approach. In addition, introducing several level of abnormality according to the "normality level" parameter and having fuzzy approach led to differentiate between warning and alarm states. The above points plus on-line working of the system opposite of the complexity of its algorithms are positive points of our work. Our method detects abnormal and suspicious behaviors in the CAVIAR data set with an accuracy of 90% in real time.
title: Detection of Abnormal Behaviors Based on Trajectory and Spatial Analysis for Intelligent Video Surveillance systems

text:
The dynamics of highly parallel spike recordings can be characterized in terms of neural avalanches. The avalanche distributions reflect the correlations in activity across neurons, and across time. In vitro, avalanche size distributions $f(s)$ were found to approximate power laws [1]: $f(s) \sim s^{-\tau}.$ This indicates diverging correlation lengths, and is characteristic for self-organized criticality (SOC) [2], prompting the hypothesis that neural population dynamics may be  SOC. Moreover, SOC may provide a basis for optimal information processing [3]. However, evidence for the SOC hypothesis has been obtained only for coarse measures of neural activity (LFP, EEG, BOLD), but surprisingly not for spiking activity in vivo.
Therefore we analyzed highly parallel spike recordings from rats (hippocampus), cats (visual cortex) and monkeys (prefrontal cortex). Across all species, the avalanche size distributions $f(s)$ were similar (Fig. 1A-C), but differed fundamentally from $f(s)$ in critical spiking models (Fig. 1D), even when accounting for subsampling (Fig. 1E) (see [4–6]). The differences between in vivo $f(s)$ and model $f(s)$ could be overcome by decreasing the model’s excitatory synaptic strength, while increasing its external input (drive) concomitantly (Fig. 1F). Thereby the model became sub-critical and lost its separation of time scales (STS), which is fundamental to SOC. These results also held for intracranial depth recordings in humans.
Our findings indicate that the mammalian brain self-organizes to a slightly subcritical regime without STS. In this regime, avalanches are not temporally separated bursts as for SOC, but form a mélange. This regime may strike a balance between optimal information processing, which has been linked to SOC [3], and the need to avoid the supercritical regime, which has been linked to epilepsy.
title: Do Highly Parallel Spike Recordings from Rats, Cats, and Monkeys Indicate a Self-Organized Critical State?
