text:
Introduction
Hahne et al. (2012) [1] have shown that optimized spatial filters can significantly improve the performance and robustness of myoelectric control that is based on classification. Here we demonstrate that spatial filters obtained by the recently introduced source power correlation (SPoC) analysis can similarly boost performance in paradigms that allow for continous and proportional myoelectric control by means of regression.

Methods
SPoC is to optimizes spatial filters such that the power of the filter outputs maximally co-modulates with a continuous target variable [2]. This simplifies the task for the regressor and can therefore increase the estimation accuracy.

Experimental paradigm:
EMG signals were recorded from the forearms of 10 able-bodied subjects using a 192 channel electrode grid, while wrist angles were acquired for two degrees of freedom by a motion tracking system.

Data analysis:
As a baseline for comparison we use linear regression on log-var features extracted from non-overlapping 200ms blocks of the EMG channels to predict wrist angles, as was shown in [3]. In our proposed approach, log-var features are extracted from the outputs of spatial filters (optimized using SPoC) and subsequently used as input for linear regression. 
Both approaches are evaluated using the $r^2$ value between the predicted and the actual wrist angles. Training and testing are done using 5-fold crossvalidation and $r^2$ values are averaged over the test folds of all subjects. 

Results
The performance is shown for different uniformly distributed channel sub-sets. As expected the r² generally increases with increasing channel sets. Increasing the number of SPoC components leads to a higher performance. Importantly however, a small number of SPoC components suffices for our proposed method to outperform the baseline approach for all channel sets. 

Conclusion
Our results show the effectiveness spatial filters for simultaneous and proportional myoelectric control.

text:
Introduction:
Subjects with upper limb deficiency have often difficulties to generate combined movements for training of regression-based myoelectric control systems. In this work we investigate the generalization abilities of linear regression (LR) to combined movements that are not included in the training-set.

Experimental paradigm:
EMG signals were recorded from the forearms of able-bodied subjects using a 192 channel electrode grid. The subjects performed a large diversity of combined wrist motions for the two degrees of freedom (DoF) flexion/extension and radial/ulnar deviation. Wrist angles were acquired by a motion tracking system. [1]

Data analysis:
Variance, RMS, and log-var features were extracted from 200-ms intervals of the EMG to predict wrist angles with LR. The diversity of training movements was successively reduced from a dense coverage of combined motions to single DoF activations, while keeping the absolute amount of training data constant by increasing the number of repetitions. The performance was evaluated on independent test-data with the full motions-set in a 5-fold cross-validation and presented specifically for the entire range of motion.

Results:
For Variance- and RMS features the estimation error increases in the outer regions. With log-var features the wrist angels were estimated well in all regions. The diversity of the training data had almost no influence on the distribution of the error which was approximately uniform. Even if only single DoFs were used for training, the estimation error was low for combined movements as well.

Conclusion:
The results show that log-var features are not only linear with respect to the investigated wrist inclinations, but also that the DoFs are separable, i.e. the individual movements superimpose linearly to combined motions in the muscle space.
title: Separability of Wrist Motions in Simultaneous and Proportional Myoelectric Control

text:
How an ensemble of neurons wires together to form a functional unit is a fundamental problem in Neuroscience. The architecture of neuronal wiring, in fact, determines how neurons communicate and may be important for information processing performed by neuronal networks. However current knowledge is mainly limited to networks consisting of a small number of neurons, while the topological structure of biological networks remains still unknown. Primary neuronal cultures represent an ideal preparation to investigate the basic principles of network dynamics.  At the mature stage, they display network-wide synchronous bursting events (SBEs) . Interestingly, high-density MEA recordings have shown that SBEs actually correspond to propagating activities through the network. Typically, the simulated SBEs originated from a few and specific sites as in [1], but the nature and the role of such events is still under debate. In order to investigate the determinants of such dynamics, we developed a computational model that mimics the main features of the recordings obtained by a high density multi-electrode-array device (4096 electrodes inter spaced by 20um, [2]). With only a few topological constraints the model expressed realistic SBEs  along time and could be well clustered in only few groups that differed for the ignition sites and propagation directions (see Figure 1). 
Interestingly, cellular heterogeneity also showed to contribute to the ignition of these  propagations.   

In the end, our neural network model replicates most of the salient firing properties observed in experimental investigations, it clarified the underlying mechanisms that determined the neural propagations  and serves now as a ground true for the analysis and predictions of new experiments.
title: A computational model of hippocampal neuronal networks: the role of connectivity and cell properties in the appearance of synchronized bursting events.

text:
A multiscale physical model of Shaker-type K$_{\mathrm{V}}$ channels is used to span from atomic-scale interactions to macroscopic experimental measures such as charge/voltage (QV) and conductance/voltage (GV) relations. The model comprises the experimentally well-characterized voltage sensor (VS) domains described by four replications of an independent continuum electrostatic model under voltage clamp conditions$^1$$^{,2}$ and a hydrophobic gate controlling the flow of ions by a vapor lock mechanism$^3$, connected by a simple coupling principle derived from known experimental results and trial-and-error. The total Hamiltonian of the system is calculated from the computed configurational energy for each components as a function of applied voltage, VS positions and gate radius, allowing us to produce statistical-mechanical expectation values for macroscopic laboratory observables over the full range of physiological membrane potentials ($|V| \le 100$~mV, in $1$~mV steps).

The Shaker QV and GV relations seen in Seoh et al (1996) and the effects of pore mutations seen in Yifrach and MacKinnon (2002) are predicted by this model. With this approach, functional energetic relations can be decomposed in terms of physical components, and thus the effects of modifications in those elements can be quantified. We find that the total work required to operate the gate is an order of magnitude larger than the work available to the VS, and that the the experimentally observed bistable gating is due to the VS slide-and-interlock behavior.

The same model is systematically applied to VS charge mutants (Seoh et al, 1996). The QV and GV relations can be qualitatively predicted and the associated effects on functional domains determined. Additional features such as surface charges become significant for the pathological cases. Our engineering approach clearly elucidates that both normal function and mutant changes are electrostatic in nature.
title: Theoretical predictions of gating behavior for mutants of Shaker-type Kv channels from inter-domain energetics.

text:
A major challenge in computational neuroscience is to achieve high performance for real-time simulations of full size brain networks. Recent advances in GPU technology provide massively parallel, low-cost and efficient hardware that is widely available on the computer market. However, the comparatively low-level programming that is necessary to create an efficient GPU-compatible implementation of neuronal network simulations can be challenging, even for otherwise experienced programmers. To resolve this problem a number of tools for simulating spiking neural networks (SNN) on GPUs have been developed [1,2], but using a particular simulator usually comes with restrictions to particular supported neuron models, synapse models or connectivity schemes. Besides being inconvenient, this can unduly influence the path of scientific enquiry.

Here we present GeNN (GPU enhanced neuronal networks), which builds on NVIDIA's CUDA architecture to enable a more flexible framework. GeNN is based on the idea that much of this optimization can be cast into heuristics that allow the GeNN meta-compiler to generate optimized GPU code from a basic description of the neuronal network model in a minimal domain specific language of C function calls, which may also be obtained by translating variables, dynamical equations and parameters from an external simulator such as Brian 2 [3] and SpineCreator/SpineML [4]. The first release version of GeNN is available at http://sourceforge.net/projects/genn.

We have executed performance and scalability tests on an NVIDIA Tesla C2070 GPU with an Intel Xeon(R) E5-2609 CPU running Ubuntu 12.04 LTS. Our results show that as the network size increases, GPU simulations never fail to outperform CPU simulations. But we are also able to demonstrate the performance limits of using GPUs with GeNN under different network and simulation scenarios, confirming the that GPU acceleration can differ largely depending on the particular details of the model of interest.
title: Simulating spiking neural networks on massively parallel graphical processing units using a code generation approach with GeNN

text: The spiking activity of single neurons can be well described by a two-dimensional integrate-and-fire model that includes neuronal adaptation [1] caused by slowly decaying potassium currents [2]. For in-vivo like fluctuating inputs spiking model neurons exhibit stochastic dynamics which can be effectively characterized using the Fokker-Planck equation (see, e.g., [2 - 5]). This approach leads to a model with an infinite-dimensional state space and non-standard boundary conditions, however, the spike rate dynamics can be approximated by a low-dimensional ordinary differential equation in different ways [4, 6, 7]. Although these approximation techniques are interrelated it is not clear which reduced model best reproduces the spike rate of the original spiking model neurons, depending on the statistics of the input. In this study we first extend each of these reduction methods to account for neuronal adaptation and then evaluate the reduced models in terms of reproduction accuracy for a range of biologically plausible input statistics, computational demand and implementation complexity.
title: Deriving spike rate models from adaptive spiking neurons

text:
Depending on cognitive demands cortical networks exhibit different dynamical states, including asynchronous fluctuating activity and rhythms generated by distinct mechanisms [1]. It is, however, presently not well understood how switching between these network states occurs. One switching mechanism might involve slowly decaying potassium currents (so-called adaptation currents) because they strongly affect neuronal spiking dynamics [2, 3] and are directly controlled by (top-down) neuromodulatory systems [4]. 
Here we consider networks of adaptive spiking model neurons [5] receiving in-vivo like fluctuating inputs and characterize the role of neuronal adaptation in (de)stabilizing network states. From this network model we derive a low-dimensional description for the population-averaged instantaneous spike rates, thereby retaining a direct link between network activity and neuron biophysics. Additionally, this approach allows for the application of powerful methods to analyze the stability of network states, where, for example, stability bounds can be calculated for general coupling topologies [6, 7].
Using this framework we demonstrate how changes in neuronal adaptation lead to the (de)stabilization of asynchronous states, fast oscillatory activity originating from recurrent excitation-inhibition loops and slow oscillations for sufficiently strong recurrent synaptic excitation. We therefore identify network regimes where switching between different dynamical states can be mediated by brain intrinsic neuromodulatory signals that target adaptation currents.
title: Analyzing the spike rate dynamics of coupled adaptive model neurons

text: How neural circuits integrate sensory information to produce appropriate actions is a fundamental question in neuroscience. We aim to address this question using the optokinetic behavior (OKR), a response consisting of reflexive eye movements elicited by rotational whole-field motion1,2. Even such a simple response involves coordinated activity in hundreds of neurons distributed in areas throughout the brain, so mapping the underlying neural dynamics requires an unbiased approach to systematically sampling the responses of many neurons. Using two-photon imaging we recorded activity, with single-cell resolution, throughout the whole brain of zebrafish expressing GCaMP5G in most of its neurons, while the fish performed optokinetic eye movements. Here we present whole-brain maps of the average activity dynamics during these slow sinusoidal tracking movements. The network is sparse, broadly distributed and highly symmetric, with areas on opposite sides of the brain active at opposite stimulus phases. By aligning each imaged brain to an anatomical reference, we compared the spatiotemporal structure of activity during OKR across individuals, and found that, throughout a large portion of the network, it is highly stereotyped, down to the scale of single neurons. Using stimuli designed to dissociate sensory and motor aspects of the behavior, we systematically map which signals are represented in different brain areas, identifying areas that represent different aspects of the stimulus or motor variables such as eye position and swimming behavior3. These whole-brain functional maps provide a comprehensive view of brain dynamics during sensorimotor integration and are an important step towards the characterization of complete vertebrate neural circuits controlling behavior. Importantly, by identifying the areas related to particular aspects of the behavior, they allow us to single out small groups of neurons with specialized function and target them for more detailed analysis.
title: Stereotyped, distributed networks revealed by whole-brain activity maps in behaving zebrafish

text: Survival requires an organism to behave such that its vital sensory variables remain within healthy limits, a principle we refer to as Sensory Homeostasis (SH). The suggestion that SH is a driving force behind adaptive behavior can be traced back to the early days of cybernetics [1], and similar mechanisms have augmented evolutionary robotics for dealing with sensory perturbations [2,3]. However, unlike the well-established theory of Reinforcement Learning (RL) [4], no framework exists that formulates SH as a target for learning a goal-directed behavior. Here, we introduce such a framework, and the family of learning mechanisms resulting from it, which do not depend on finding the policy that maximizes future reward. Instead, target probability distributions of the vital sensory variables are defined such that they reflect the goal-directed demands of the agent, i.e., they are sharply centered around their healthy limits. The fact that goals are represented by target distributions, and not by a single scalar reward, makes the method applicable to the concurrent learning of multiple behaviors. The method is model-based, and necessary distributions, such as those of sensors and the internal world model are sampled and updated during learning [5]. Learning of an optimal policy is then achieved by minimizing the Jensen-Shannon divergence between the target distributions and the actual distributions of the agent's sensory signals, observed during behavior. The Jensen-Shannon divergence eliminates the asymmetry and non-smoothness the Kullback-Leibler divergence suffers from. Learning is sped up by updating the policy using the natural gradient [6] of the divergence. We demonstrate the viability of learning through SH on a simple discrete-variables two-choice operant conditioning task. We also discuss the potential of extending the method to continuous variables, and its implementation as a synaptic plasticity mechanism between sensory and motor neurons.
title: Learning Goal-Directed Behavior through Sensory Homeostasis

text: Precise spatio-temporal activity patterns are relevant for information processing in the brain. One example is the salamander retina where the relative spike times in different neurons carry more information about the stimulus than the latency of single neurons relative to stimulus onset [1]. Also, rats can be trained to differentiate between simultaneous and time-ordered electrical stimulation in two seperate locations in the brain, even when the difference in stimulus onsets is as low as one millisecond in time-ordered condition [2]. These findings raise the question which synaptic plasticity mechanism in the brain might establish precise spike associations. Curiously, the canonical Spike Timing Dependent Plasticity is not suited for this task. Here, we propose a simple Membrane Potential Dependent Plasticity rule (MPDP), which is based on experimental reports [3, 4]. Due to the stereotypical dynamics of the membrane potential, MPDP is also sensitive for spike times. Since the membrane potential is a non-local signal available at the synapse, it conveys information about the progress of learning. This allows MPDP to terminate synaptic plasticity as soon as the desired association is achieved, which is required for high capacity. We demonstrate the performance of MPDP in two paradigmatic neuronal networks, the perceptron and the chronotron. We show that MPDP can be mapped to the Perceptron Learning Rule and thereby inherits its highly desirable properties. For the Chronotron, we find that it achieves very high capacity, while also providing robustness against noise. We conclude that MPDP is a powerful plasticity principle that can be tested experimentally.
title: Learning Spike Times with Membrane Potential Dependent Plasticity

text:
Song birds learn to imitate tutor songs from sensory memories, which implies a precise sequence of motor activations to reproduce a specific sensory experience. It has been proposed that this is realized by inverse models that map desired sensory representations onto motor activations to produce the respective motor gestures [1].

The biological mechanisms that form inverses of non-linear forward mappings of spatio-temporal activity patterns in closed loop situations containing substantial delays are unclear. We propose a conceptually simple, functionally complete, and biologically plausible approach to learning such inverse models in networks of spiking neurons.
It exploits the interaction between a membrane potential dependent learning rule that keeps the membrane potential bounded and the afterhyperpolarisation of the neuronal membrane potential after each spike. The afterhyperpolarisation of motor neurons serves as a biological trace of earlier activations, which implies that it will take more input to drive the neuron above threshold than at resting state. We show that with these assumptions random motor explorations robustly lead to causal inverse models from sensory to motor representations which provides a plausible explanation for the remarkable imitation skills in song birds, as well as for experimentally observed mirror neurons.

However, for song learning, not only an inverse model is needed, but also a way to store the memory of the tutor song. Such a memory template consists of a specific temporal pattern of activity in the brain that can be learned and recalled. How neuronal networks can learn to store such temporally precise patterns is not known. We suggest that a variant of the learning paradigm used for generating the inverse model can also serve to store activity patterns of this type. Thus, we propose a fully functional model of the song bird that self-organizes with a single plasticity mechanism.
title: Membrane Potential Dependent Plasticity mechanism forms inverse models

text: There are theoretical reasons to think that the brain could be most efficient if operating in the near-critical regime [1,2,3], and experimental support for this has been steadily accumulating [4,5,6].  We view several apparently-strange neurological phenomena in the light of the working hypothesis that the brain hovers near the brink of criticality; that it devotes considerable resources to maintaining this; and that failures in which parts of the brain enter an undesired super-critical regime are not uncommon.  This basic idea seems to cast light on a variety of phenomena.  In essence, we posit that some pathological conditions are the result of inappropriate super-critical dynamics.  This naturally explains certain puzzling observations in a variety of apparently unrelated conditions.  In particular, we consider: (a) the closely related phenomena of sleep and epilepsy [7,8]; (b) tremor and deep brain stimulation [9]; and (c) non-psychotic hallucinations that follow from diminished sensory input such as Charles Bonnet syndrome, phantom limb, and tinnitus [10].
title: Critical Dynamics and Pathological Phenomena in the Brain

text:
Many computational properties of cortical networks can be faithfully reproduced by Winner-Take-All (WTA) networks (Douglas & Martin, 2007). Such networks, typically comprising ensembles of recurrently connected excitatory and inhibitory neurons, can implement a variety of non-linear operations including signal restoration, amplification, max-like winner selection, i.e. decision making, or filtering. However, in order to implement such operations the network connections need to be fine-tuned to satisfy certain constraints imposed by theoretical stability conditions (Rutishauser et al., 2011). It has been an open question whether and how WTA circuits can achieve this fine-tuning through biologically plausible synaptic plasticity mechanisms.
We show how the desired circuit motif can emerge autonomously through an interplay of plasticity mechanisms that operate simultaneously on all excitatory and inhibitory synapses of an initially random network. We analyze the stabilization properties of the proposed mechanism in a mean field model using contraction theory, and find constraints for the model parameters that ensure self-calibration of the network. Finally, we validate our theoretical results through computer simulations.
Our main result provides simple constraints on the plasticity rule parameters, rather than on the weights themselves, which guarantee stable WTA behavior. This work sheds light on the mechanisms responsible for the emergence of both local functional circuits and larger assemblies of interconnected WTA networks.
title: Emergence and Stabilization of Winner-Take-All Dynamics Through Interacting Plasticity Mechanisms

text:
Deep Belief Networks (DBNs) are state-of-the-art algorithms that can extract hierarchies of spatial features from input data. Although they are loosely inspired by cortical processing hierarchies, and can be trained as generative models for static data, they cannot capture the temporal characteristics of real-world inputs. Previous models have combined DBNs into spatio-temporal architectures by conditioning current visible variables on previous ones [1] or by using recurrent connections between hidden variables [2]. Here we present a novel architecture for a brain-inspired dynamic generative model for spatio-temporal input sequences, which combines the spatial processing hierarchy of a DBN with a short term memory in the form of a reservoir computing architecture.
We propose a new computational framework called Deep Temporal Networks (DTNs), which consists of a Self-Organized Recurrent Neural Network (SORN) [3] that processes high-level spatial input features coming from the output of the highest layers of a DBN. The reservoir of the SORN architecture adapts its inner weights using local plasticity rules such as STDP to learn temporal dynamics of different sequential inputs. Additionally, synaptic normalization and intrinsic plasticity are applied to maintain stable dynamics inside the reservoir. The combination of SORN and DBN creates a powerful computing architecture, which can not only classify temporal sequences, but via feedback from the SORN into the DBN also generate new sequences, e.g. complete a spatio-temporal pattern after seeing only part of a sequence. We validated the performance of this architecture for completing temporal sequences using noisy artificial data and gestures recorded with a DVS128 neuromorphic vision sensor [4].
title: Deep Temporal Networks : A Deep Learning Algorithm with a Self-Organizing Temporal Memory

text:
Different tasks in neural systems seem to be solved by similar anatomical motifs. This observation spawned interest in common principles of information processing implemented in such motifs. These common principles by definition cannot be cast in processing-task specific language. Thus, to formulate an information processing principle without recurring to task-specific semantics, we have to use a task-independent framework, such as information theory. Information theory has been used to formulate unifying neural information processing principles, such as the goal function of the Coherent Infomax Principle (CIP)[Kay&Phillips]. The CIP goal function prescribes that a neural processor fed by driving bottom up inputs and modulatory contextual inputs should pass on both, information that is shared by driving input and context and information that is only in the input, but block information only available in the context. 
However, classical information theory used in CIP does not cleanly separate these goals. A separation only becomes possible when using the recently introduced framework of partial information decomposition (PID)[Williams&Beer]. PID allows to decompose the mutual information between inputs and outputs of the neural processor into unique contributions from driving and modulatory inputs, as well as the information they share about the output (redundancy) and the mutual information they only  jointly have about the output (synergy).
Using PID, we show that the CIP goal function indeed implements the desired principles of information processing, but lacks the ability to use the context as a key in decoding inputs. Moreover, the CIP's focus on redundancy conflicts with the principles of hierachical predictive coding. In sum, CIP is ideally suited for information processing within a level in a hierachy. For processing between levels we suggest a goal function that reflects predictive coding ideas and provides decoding capabilities via synergistic information.
title: Using partial information decomposition to formulate unifying neural goal functions

text:
Highly parallel recordings can reveal avalanches of neural activity. In vitro, the sizes $s$ of these avalanches follow a power-law distribution $f(s) \sim s^{-\tau}$ [1]. Power-law distributions are a hallmark feature of a critical state, which has been linked to optimal information processing [2]. Therefore, it was suggested that criticality governs neural activity [1,3].
The comparison between neural population dynamics and critical models is hampered in two ways: First, it was up to now impossible to achieve a “truly critical” state in models due to finite size effects.  Second, in the experiments at most a few hundred neurons can be recorded in parallel. This unavoidable subsampling can distort the observed dynamics, and hampers inferences about the dynamics of the full model [4–6]. 
$f(s)$ of a classical stochastic branching model [7,8] shows a cutoff at around N=100, the number of model neurons, due to finite size effects (Fig. 1A, blue). To overcome the finite size effects, we added a rapid, activity dependent adaptation of the synaptic strength. The adaptation mechanism diminished the finite size effects, and allowed $f(s)$ to extend over more orders of magnitude, i.e. the model was much closer to critical (Fig 1A, red). When subsampling this novel model (sampling n=10 out of N=100 neurons) $f(s)$ hardly changed, while subsampling in the classical model lead to a strong deviations from power law (Fig. 1B). Nonetheless, $f(s)$ in both models could be inferred from the subsampled activity using a rescaling approach.  In addition, under subsampling the topology of the full network is reflected in $f(s)$, and hence inferences about the “connectome” can be drawn.
title: Highly Parallel Recordings, Criticality & Subsampling

text: The thalamus provides prominent input to the neocortex in sensory and motor systems. This input activates inhibitory local interneurons more intensely than excitatory neurons, providing a powerful feedforward inhibition (FFI) [1]. We studied the functional implication of the FFI on the dynamics of the balanced cortical network. We show the FFI plays a key role on levelling the co-variability in the recurrent network dynamics.  Our result suggests the FFI recruits inhibition to form the basis of strong correlations among local inhibitory neurons, while suppressing the noise correlations between pairs of excitatory cells. This founding explains how output activity of cortical circuits substantially uncorrelated and detrimental correlations due to input are eliminated.

text: The synaptic cleft is an EC domain that is capable of relaying a presynaptically received electrical signal by diffusive NTs to the postsynaptic membrane. The cleft is trans-synaptically bridged by ring-like clusters of pre-/postsynaptically localized calcium-dependent adhesion proteins of the N-Cadherin type and is possibly the smallest intercircuit in nervous systems [1]. The strength of association between the pre- and postsynaptic membranes can account for synaptic plasticity such as LTP [2]. By neuronal activity the intra- and extracellular calcium levels are modulated through calcium exchangers embedded in the pre- and postsynaptic membrane. Variations of the concentration of cleft calcium induces changes in the N-Cadherin-zipper, that in synaptic resting states is rigid and tightly connects the pre- and postsynaptic domain. By synaptic activity calcium concentrations are hypothesized to drop below critical thresholds which leads to loosening of the N-Cad connections and subsequently "unzips" the Cadherin-mediated connection. These processes may result in changes in synaptic strength [2]. To investigate the calcium-mediated N-Cad dynamics at the synaptic cleft, we developed a three-dimensional multi-scale model including cleft morphology and all prominent Ca-Exchangers and corresponding density distributions and molecular dynamics of the Ca-dependent N-Cads [3-6]. The necessity for fully three-dimensional multi-scale model becomes apparent, when investigating effects of e. g. spatial architecture of a synapse [7-8] or dynamics and effects of the conformational changes of the N-Cads. We see the localization of Ca-Channels w.r.t. the N-Cad ring has substantial effects on the time-scales on which the N-Cad-zipper switches between states, ranging from seconds to minutes. This will have significant effects on synaptic signaling. We see high-frequency AP firing can only  be relayed to the Calcium/N-Cad system at a synapse by precise spatial synaptic reorganization.
title: A three-dimensional detailed multi-scale model of time-dependent calcium dynamics within a synaptic cleft

text: Investigation of cellular and network dynamics in the brain by means of modeling and simulation has evolved into a highly interdisciplinary field, that uses sophisticated modeling and simulation approaches to understand distinct areas of brain function. Depending on the underlying complexity, these models vary in their level of detail, in order to cope with the attached computational cost. Hence for large network simulations, single neurons are typically reduced to time-dependent signal processors, dismissing the spatial aspect of each cell. For single cell or networks with relatively small numbers of neurons, general purpose simulators allow for space and time-dependent simulations of electrical signal processing, based on the cable equation theory. An emerging field in Computational Neuroscience encompasses a new level of detail by incorporating the full three-dimensional morphology of cells and organelles into three-dimensional, space and time-dependent, simulations. While every approach has its advantages and limitations, such as computational cost, integrated and methods-spanning simulation approaches, depending on the network size could establish new ways to investigate the brain.  In this poster we present a hybrid simulation approach, that makes use of reduced 1D-models -- using e. g. the NEURON simulator -- which couples to fully resolved models for simulating cellular and sub-cellular dynamics, including the detailed three-dimensional morphology of neurons and organelles. In order to couple 1D- and 3D-simulations, we present a geometry-, membrane potential- and intracellular concentration mapping framework, with which graph-based morphologies, e. g. in the swc- or hoc-format, are mapped to full surface and volume representations of the neuron and computational data from 1D-simulations can be used as boundary conditions for full 3D simulations and vice versa. Thus, established models and data, based on general purpose 1D-simulators, can be directly coupled
title: 1D-3D Hybrid Modelling - From Multi-Compartment Models to Full Resolution Models in Space and Time

text:
Dendritic spines as well as the dendrites they emerge from are filled with structure like actin filaments which, like the plasma membrane, carry static charges on their surfaces and will therefore have an effect on the local potential. It remains unclear, however, how strong this effect is and if it can influence the postsynaptic signal processing of incoming action potentials.
In order to investigate any possible effect, we have developed a numerical model applying the Poisson-Nernst-Planck equation for electro-diffusion to the context of neuronal ion dynamics, thus introducing a full-dimensional description of these dynamics that captures the local relationship between potential and charge carriers more physically accurately than a simple one-dimensional cable equation. The governing equations are:
$$\frac{\partial c_i}{\partial t}=\nabla\cdot\left( D_i\nabla c_i + D_i\frac{z_iF}{RT}c_i\nabla \Phi\right)$$
$$-\nabla\cdot\left( \varepsilon_0\varepsilon_r\nabla\Phi\right)=F\sum_iz_ic_i,$$
where $c_i$ are the ion species and $\Phi$ the potential.
Boundary conditions for the full-dimensional problem modeling the local dynamics of a spine and a small part of the surrounding dendrite are given by a 1D model reduction for the rest of the cell assuming a cylindrical dendrite with varying radius.
Simulations have so far only been carried out for the 2D case and turn out to be numerically difficult making further research on the treatment of the 3D case necessary.
title: Simulating neuronal ion dynamics as an electro-diffusive process

text:
An important challenge in neuroscience is to understand how networks of neurons are processing information. Chemical synapses are key players in this context as they define the interfaces that transmit signals between neurons and other cells. However, a quantitative assessment of the underlying processes is often hindered by the complexity of the experimental system and the physiological interrelationships at synapses. In this project we attempt to overcome these experimental limitations by an interdisciplinary approach that aims at mathematically reconstituting critical parameters of a well accessible and simple synaptic system, the Drosophila larval neuromuscular junction (DNMJ).

Towards this end we have developed a detailed 3d mathematical model of presynaptic processes based on realistic morphological and physiological data from DNMJs that includes the spatio-temporal vesicle cycle within presynaptic boutons as well as the detailed calcium dynamics at active zones that couples neuronal activity patterns with the properties of vesicle release machineries. The model comprises the description of 3d reaction-diffusion processes with non-linear (inner) boundary conditions. The resulting system of coupled partial differential equations is discretized in space and time and numerically solved with the help of multigrid techniques.

Based on this model and its verification by experimental data (see accompanying poster Leung et al.) we found that the two glutamatergic bouton classes of larval NMJs, type 1s and type 1b boutons, show distinct overall presynaptic calcium dynamics that correlate with the size of the bouton and the number of harbored active zones. The kinetics of the overall calcium buffering in both bouton types predicts that 1s and 1b boutons can only accommodate specific maximal stimulation frequencies without interferences. These estimates correlate well with experimentally observed natural firing patterns of both neurons.
title: Differential calcium dynamics determines vesicle release properties in different bouton types

text:
The Frankfurt vision initiative fuses insights from systems engineering and brain sciences to develop a platform for cognitive vision. In past work we have described our systems engineering perspective for visual cognition wherein the cognitive vision system configuration and parameters are viewed as a mapping from the cross-product space of “application domain contexts, sensor modality types and configurations, tasks, and performance requirements” to “dynamic system design configurations and parameters” [1, 2]. These dynamic system configurations mimic dual-system cognitive architectures that perform massively parallel hypotheses generation followed by deliberation/reasoning and optimization [3]. 
In order to do this systematic exploration of tradeoffs in visual cognition system design, we exploit a graphics simulation platform that allows rich scripting of application contexts and generation of large amounts of video sequences along with pixel level and meta-data ground-truth. Our simulation platform is built on top of graphics tools for domain specific scene creation and rendering. Key features of the module include, flexible scene graph to create domain-specific scenes, rendering the data with multiple annotations (include semantics, bounding boxes, tracks, scene flow, surface normal, edges, reflections, texture, Illumination, diffuse and specular componants, geometry of scene, camera and lighting etc.) for performance analysis and optimization, and flexible storage of data and distributions. The platform consists of (i) virtual reality tool, Vizard [5] to create scenes, (ii) GLSL [6] to annotate image data by GPU shaders, and (iii) HDF5 [7] to store the data and annotations. Concrete applications in video surveillance and driver assistance for automotive domains are currently being used as case studies for our platform. The work flow of the simulation process and sample frames generated by the proposed module, are shown in the Figure.
title: Simulation Platform for Cognitive Vision

text: In a large variety of situations one would like to have an expressive and accurate model of animal or human behavior. While general purpose mathematical models may capture successfully properties of observed behavior, it is desirable to develop computational models that answer the question why behavior was carried out and  to root models in biological facts at the implementational level. Because of ample empirical evidence for reward-based learning in visuomotor tasks we use a computational model based on the assumption that the observed agent is balancing the costs and benefits of its behavior to meet its goals. This leads to using the framework of Reinforcement Learning, which additionally provides well-established algorithms for learning of visuomotor tasks. To quantify the agent’s goals as rewards implicit in the observed behavior we propose to use inverse reinforcement learning, which quantifies the agent’s goals as rewards implicit in the observed behavior. Based on the assumption of a modular cognitive architecture, we introduce a modular inverse reinforcement learning algorithm that estimates the relative reward contributions of the component tasks in navigation, consisting of following a path while avoiding obstacles and approaching targets. It is shown how to recover the component reward weights for individual tasks and that variability in observed trajectories can be explained succinctly through behavioral goals. It is demonstrated through simulations that good estimates can be obtained already with modest amounts of observation data, which in turn allows the prediction of behavior in novel configurations. We infer implicit costs and benefits from measured navigation behavior from human subjects in a variety of tasks and show that subjects never fully followed the given tasks instructions but instead were also driven by additional intrinsic costs. Finally we show, that human eye movements during navigation are tightly linked to the inferred rewards.
title: Intrinsic costs in human navigation inferred with inverse reinforcement learning

text:
Heterogeneity is an intrinsic feature of complex biological systems. As it demonstrably affects robustness and reliability of network responses it should have great functional relevance [7, 8].  We have only recently begun, however, to study the phenomenology of heterogeneity, and the neuronal mechanisms underlying it [4, 5].  Of particular interest is the dynamic interplay between asymmetric spike train correlations and spike-timing dependent synaptic plasticity ( $\textit{STDP}$ ) [6].

Previously, correlation in the responses of spiking neurons with shared input were studied for weak correlations only [1].  In the strongly correlated regime, only limited theory is available [2, 3]. This regime was mainly studied numerically [4].  Here we have a semi-analytical look into the mechanisms of correlation asymmetry in different regimes.  We were able to identify two mechanisms that contribute to correlation asymmetry: $\textit{desynchronization}$ and $\textit{relative stretch}$. In the strongly correlated regime, inputs private to each neuron, as well as intrinsic heterogeneity, strongly influence the degree of $\textit{desynchronization}$ in short time windows.  On the other hand, the contribution of $\textit{relative stretch}$ to correlation asymmetry under similar conditions is more prominent in moderately and weakly correlated regimes. We study and compare roles of these two asymmetry mechanisms in heterogeneity of neuron interactions (EPSPs etc. ), as spike train correlations are integrated by a given $\textit{STDP}$ rule.
title: Mechanisms of Spike Correlation Asymmetry and Network Heterogeneity

text: The balanced state of recurrent networks of excitatory and inhibitory spiking neurons is characterized by fluctuations of population activity about an attractive fixed point. Numerical simulations show that these dynamics are essentially nonlinear, and that the intrinsic noise (self-generated fluctuations) in networks of finite size is state-dependent. Therefore, deterministic equations with additive stationary noise cannot provide an adequate description of the stochastic dynamics. Rather, the noise model should result from a self-consistent description of the network dynamics. Here, we consider a two-state Markovian neuron model, where spikes correspond to transitions from the active state to the refractory state. Excitatory and inhibitory input to this neuron affects the transition rates between the two states. The corresponding nonlinear dependencies can be identified directly from numerical simulations of networks of leaky integrate-and-fire neurons, discretized at a time resolution in the sub-millisecond range. Deterministic mean-field equations, and a noise component that depends on the network size, are obtained from this model. The resulting stochastic model reflects the behavior observed in numerical simulations quite well. In particular, a strong temporal correlation between the two populations, a hallmark of the balanced state in random recurrent networks, are well represented by the model. Numerical simulations of such networks show that a heavy-tail distribution of excitatory and inhibitory short-term spike counts is another property of such networks with fixed in-degree, and our model shares this statistical property. Furthermore, the reconstruction of the mean flow from simulated time series suggest that the mean-field dynamics of finite-size networks are essentially nonlinear. We expect that this novel nonlinear stochastic model of interaction between neuronal populations opens new doors to analyze the dynamics of multiple interacting networks.
title: Nonlinear stochastic mean-field dynamics of interacting populations of spiking neurons

text:
In order to develop models which describe the interplay of different components in the brain, it is helpful to estimate causal influences between these components from ongoing activity. Although the underlying anatomical structure provides constraints, it is not sufficient to determine the dynamics. Additionally, it is easier to evaluate activity than to access the structure directly.
With techniques like calcium imaging or functional magnetic resonance imaging, a large number of constituents can be observed, but it is still difficult to resolve dynamical processes both temporally and spatially. We present results on the extension and application of a recently proposed method which infers effective connections from a covariance matrix acquired from measured activity. An initially undirected estimate is converted to a directed network, by exploiting information from indirect connections under the assumption that the underlying network is relatively sparse. This can be done for covariance functions in the frequency domain, but also for zero-lag covariances caused by processes that are faster than the experimental time resolution. 
We apply the method to datasets which were acquired using the MR-encephalography technique, which measures full brain BOLD signals with a higher temporal resolution than conventional fMRI (frame rate 5 Hz). We compare information from different frequency bands in the datasets and discuss problems arising from high noise levels as well as shared input, for example from respiratory effects.
title: Inference of sparse effective connectivity from resting state fMRI

text:
In our research we investigate the role of haptic feedback for grasping and manipulating objects in a closed sensorimotor loop. In order to learn and improve manipulation behaviors, predicting tactile stimuli from efferent motor signals is a major step. For tactile predictions, a model of the object shape needs to be built and simultaneously an estimate of its location maintained, while manipulating the object. This requires to continuously match perceived tactile stimuli with the current object representation and to decide, whether the object representation or the estimated object location need to be adapted according to the input.

Inspired by findings of the neural processing in haptic and visual pathways, features such as position, surface orientation and surface curvature are computed from tactile contacts [1]. These serve as inputs to a neural-dynamic model, using dynamic neural fields (DNF) [2] for implementing this matching process. The object shape representation is learned within memory traces of these DNFs [3], capturing shape relevant aspects such as the position and orientation of detected surfaces and edges.

The model is evaluated in robot experiments, where two fingers of a Shunk Dexerous Hand 2 rotate cylindrical n-gon objects. Using the object representation, the model is able to compensate for errors and drifts in the estimated rotation of the object and its one-dimensional position. It is shown, that the model is able to lead to self-consistent object shape representations, within four full rotations of the object.

Future research will focus on the prediction of tactile stimuli from the learned object shape representation.
title: Extracting Object Shape from Haptics during Rotational Manipulations

text: Plasticity of ion channel distribution at the neuronal membrane is increasingly being recognized as an important factor in neural functioning. Groups of ion channels can be regulated on short time scales by the activation of membrane receptors for neuromodulators (NM). Each NM receptor can influence ion channels (including AMPA, NMDA and GABA-A channels) directly by local interaction in protein complexes, or by signalling into the cytoplasm and influencing ion channel activity and expression distally. The extracellular matrix (ECM) is sufficient to anchor G-protein coupled receptors (NM receptors) in specific places during recycling processes (deactivation, endocytosis, degradation), and therefore localize them permanently (1,2). Regulation by NM receptors may be part of long-term memory (3).  We suggest that NM receptors code for executable subroutines expressed by the membrane ion channel composition. We present a simulation model where the coding properties of a collection of neurons are changed simultaneously through the activation of one or more dominant NM receptors, leading to a different set of dendritic branches and synapses being active. For instance, Gi$\beta \gamma$ activated GIRK channels at spines introduce slow IPSCs (4) and voltage-gated potassium channels influence dendritic branch transmission (5), (Fig.1).This results in a regulation of the flow of information through the network by NMs, corresponding to state-dependent memorization and activation of memory content. Since NM receptors can be optically manipulated at the single cell level (5), simulation models may be developed together with direct experimental evidence.
title: Execution of different transmission codes by neuromodulators

text:
Hand grasping requires the transformation of visual object information into corresponding hand actions. In the primate brain these processes are linked to area AIP (anterior intraparietal cortex), F5 (ventral premotor cortex) and M1 (primary motor cortex). Although these areas demonstrate selective responses when hand movements are planned or executed, it is up to now unclear how visual and motor information is encoded on the neuronal population level.
To address this question, we trained two macaques to grasp up to 50 different objects in a delayed reach-to-hold task. In this, we measured the kinematics of hand and arm together with spiking activity recorded from up to 300 single- and multi-units using microelectrode arrays. The high variation of visual stimuli and motor responses in this task allowed us separating visual attributes of objects from motor features of the hand. Canonical variant and hierarchical cluster analysis demonstrated a dominant visual role of AIP during both the planning and execution epoch. The neural population separated the objects primarily based on their shape and secondarily on their size. Furthermore, we found indicators for the processing of object affordances relevant for grasping. In contrast to AIP, we could identify in F5 a distinct motor representation that encoded the objects in motor terms. However, the highest correspondence to the recorded hand kinematics was observed in the M1 population activity that closely matched the multi-joint space of the hand and arm. 
Together our results demonstrate distinct roles of AIP, F5, and M1 at the population level that are highly relevant for understanding how visumotor transformations are processed in the brain.
title: From vision to action: a comparative population study of hand grasping areas AIP, F5, and M1

text: Deoxynivalenol (DON) is a mycotoxin that contaminates frequently cereal grain and cereal-based food and feed worldwide and is thus becoming a serious health risk to humans. It is assumed that DON alters the neurochemistry of the brain, specifically the levels of biogenic monoamines in the central nervous system, causing feed refusal, emesis and anorexia. The FAO issued guidelines and regulatory limits for DON in cereals and food products. To keep the compliance with regulations, tools for fast and accurate DON estimation have to be developed. Aptamers for ligand binding are already known and are suitable as potential recognition elements for biosensors. Here, we describe the selection of DNA aptamers reacting on DON with different affinities. The selection is based on the formation of aptamer bacons upon DON binding. A single-stranded, random DNA library comprising 6.6 x $10^{14}$ different molecules was reversible bound to an affinity column. Sequences which underwent a conformational change consequently to the addition of DON were collected and amplified. After 12 rounds of selection, the enriched pool was analyzed on the included sequences. Out of 76 sequences, 39 were chosen for a detailed binding analysis, among which, 14 reacted to the application of DON.
title: Selecting aptamers against deoxynivalenol

text:
Two neuronal morphologies, distinguished by the position of the soma, have developed in the animal kingdom. In vertebrates, the soma is typically located in a central position between axon and dendrites. In higher invertebrates, the soma is externalized at the end of a so-called stem neurite, which connects the soma to axon and dendrites. We hypothesize that the position of the soma – central or externalized – fulfills a functional role. Commonly, the externalization of the soma in higher invertebrates is explained by spatial constraints. We suggest that, as an additional benefit, the soma position is optimized to enhance the energy efficiency of neuronal signaling.

Based on multi-compartmental models, we compare the signaling costs for both morphologies. The lower the passive attenuation of a dendritic signal along its way to the spike initiation site, the lower the amount of metabolic energy that needs to be invested in its propagation. We show that in this context, the energetically most favorable soma position depends on the relative diameters of the soma and the processes protruding from it (i.e. dendrite and stem neurite). Intuitively, a large central soma provides a current sink, while an externalized soma is partly “shielded” by the stem neurite. We predict that externalized somata are larger than central somata, when compared to the diameter of their processes. Indeed, an analysis of previously published morphological data from various cell types confirms a correlation between soma position and relative soma size. We hypothesize that for vertebrates, a central soma position serves as a central switching point for the control of neuronal output. In this case, small somata help to constrain the energetic costs. Accordingly, originally somatic organelles may have been shifted into proximal dendrites (such as the endoplasmatic reticulum) as a result of an evolutionary optimization process to decrease the relative soma size.
title: Soma position influences energy efficiency of neuronal signaling

text:
Pyramidal cell dendrites are endowed with active ionic conductances, which do not only foster dendritic signal propagation [1], but also play a role for synaptic plasticity. In order for Hebbian forms of plasticity to occur, synapses in the dendrites have to be informed about spikes elicited in the axon hillock. While backpropagating action potentials provide this information to synapses at medium distances from the soma, including those on apical oblique and basal dendrites [2,3], calcium spikes induce plasticity in the more distant apical tuft synapses [4]. Interestingly, these two dendritic regions  are also targeted by different interneuron populations. Parvalbumin-positive interneurons typically synapse onto the proximal dendritic and somatic parts of the neuron, while somatostatin-positive interneurons provide input to the apical dendrite. The matching compartmentalization in terms of the type of dendritic spikes and inhibitory control suggests that inhibition could differentially regulate dendritic spikes and hence introduce a compartment-specific modulation of synaptic plasticity.

We evaluated this hypothesis in a biophysical multi-compartment model of a pyramidal neuron, receiving shunting inhibition at different locations on the dendrite. Our analysis shows that inhibition could gate dendritic spikes in an all-or-none manner. Moreover, spatially selective inhibition could individually suppress backpropagating action potentials and calcium spikes, allowing for a compartment-specific, binary control of backpropagating dendritic signals, with compartment-specific consequences for synaptic plasticity. Finally, we suggest that disinhibition of calcium spikes can account for a change in a neuron's firing mode, which has recently been observed when silencing presynaptic inhibitory interneurons [5]. 
The proposed mechanism could implement a pathway-specific switch of cellular computation, a potentially useful feature for learning and the formation of memories.
title: Compartmentalized inhibition: a means to control dendritic spikes and neuronal firing modes

text: Chemical synapse defines the interface that transmit signals between neurons and their recipient cells, the ability to transmit signals in a dynamic and use-dependent manner make it an important player in the information processing of a neuronal network. Since calcium is the key regulator of neurotransmitter release, it is not surprising to learn that the dynamics of calcium in the presynaptic processes are spatio-temporally optimized to best serve their function. In this project, mathematical and experimental approaches are combined to quantitatively access presynaptic calcium dynamics in high precision. At Drosophila larval neuromuscular junction (NMJ), a three-dimensional mathematical model of presynaptic bouton is reconstituted (see accompanying poster Stepniewski et al.,) and then experimentally validated on critical parameters. Simulated results of the net calcium influx to the entire presynaptic bouton are first validated by data from the calcium imaging experiments using genetic calcium sensors, GCaMP3 and GCaMP6, of different sensitivity. The net calcium influx and its kinetics are then compared between two bouton type, 1s(small) and 1b(big), which are specialized in transmitting nervous stimulations at different frequencies. Furthermore, the kinetics of calcium efflux between the two bouton types were compared from electrophysiologically measured paired pulse ratio, which is an indirect indication base on the increased release probability results from presynaptic calcium build-up during temporally closely paired stimulation. Our combined results demonstrate that the architecture of the type 1s and 1b boutons, essentially the bouton size and number of active zones, are optimized to facilitate different calcium dynamics, which serves faithful transmission at lower and higher frequencies respectively.
title: Calcium Dynamics in Type Ib and Is Boutons of Drosophila Larvae Neuromuscular Junction

text:
One of the most typical properties of natural human movements is that one movement is not independent but involved in a sequence of other movements. A movement segment can affect its successor (carry-over coarticulation) or its predecessor (anticipatory coarticulation). In redundant motor systems coarticulation can be found in end-effector trajectories and in joint angles. As both kinds of coarticulation influence movements at different points in time, a comparison between them can help us to understand the generation of movement better.
To examine coarticulation in human arm movements, a cylindrical object was moved from a starting position to a position at the center and from there to a final position. To analyze carry-over coarticulation, six starting points and three final targets were arranged around the central target. To examine anticipatory coarticulation, one starting position and four final positions were used. To ensure complete attention to the task, the targets were given by visual cues that had to be memorized and were removed before each trial.
To uncover coarticulation in joint angle configurations, we applied an analysis of motor equivalence based on the concept of the uncontrolled manifold. We decomposed the difference between joint configurations in different conditions into components that leave the position of the transported object invariant (UCM) and those that affect the position of the object (ORT). Motor equivalence is observed when this difference lies more in the UCM than in the ORT (same spatial trajectory, but moving through different joint configurations).
Direction-dependent coarticulation was visible in the end-effector and in joint angles. However the preparation of a movement seems to be distinctly different from its post-processing. While carry-over coarticulation was mainly visible in the joint angles, it was different for anticipatory coarticulation. Here the influence on end-effector was more distinct.
title: Coarticulation in sequential human arm movements

text: In everyday listening situations, reverberation due to sound reflections in the environment is very common. However, in most cases the auditory system is able to adapt to the reflections and we are unaware of them. This is also expressed by an increase of the echo threshold, i.e. the minimum delay to hear a reflection as an echo becomes longer after hearing the echo repeatedly, which is not only the case for single echoes, but also for echoes that are part of a complex room impulse response. Changes in the directional pattern of sound reflections disturb the adaptation process and for a short period of time after the change, the reflections become audible. While many studies exist for single reflections or simple patterns, only few results have been produced for realistic reverberant environments. The present study addresses the question how changes in the reflection pattern of a reverberant environment are perceived. Realistic simulations of reverberation in different rooms are created using a high order image source model. By altering parameters of individual image sources, such as their direction, unrealistic reflection patterns are created which nevertheless maintain key  properties of the room such as the direct-to- reverberant ratio and the reverberation time. This study tests the hypothesis that, compared to realistic reverberation patterns, differences can be observed in the release from adaptation for unrealistic reverberation patterns.
title: Reverberation Perception in Virtual Spaces with Unrealistic Sound Reflections

text:
While neuroscience is one of the most dynamic branches of science it still has a lot of unsolved problems in the field of information processing principles. To solve these problems a great variety of computational neuroscience methods are applied. To reproduce the principles of brain dynamics in brain-inspired information processing devices, neuroprosthetics hardware or “silicon” neurons and neural networks are used.[1–3].
We investigated the dynamics of phase-locked loop with a specific bandpass second-order filter in the control loop. Phase-locked loops (PLL) are devices commonly used in radio technologies, telecommunication systems, electronic circuits, etc. to synchronize and stabilize controlled generator in accordance to the reference one [4,5]. The main working regime of PLL is synchronization between controlled generator and the reference signal. In this case, a constant signal exists in the control loop. When the loop is not able to compensate the differences between two signals it produces the oscillations whose complexity depends on the type of filter in PLL. PLL order is one greater than the order of the filter. It means that in the case of second-order bandpass filter PLL dynamics is described by the third-order ODE. Third order dynamical systems could demonstrate a complex behavior including the chaotic one. In our model regular nearly harmonic, regular and chaotic bursting oscillations have been found. The results of numerical simulations and analysis was presented in the paper [6]. The observed oscillations were qualitatively similar to some dynamic modes of the neuron membrane potential.
Due to the high prevalence of PLL, the technology of its creation is well established and suggesting the possibility to produce the designed PLL microcircuits. We have developed a prototype of the PLL with bandpass filter and have found the same modes as in the numerical simulation. The oscillogram of the chaotic bursting mode of the prototype is shown on figure 1.
title: Phase-locked loop based generator of neuron-like oscillations.

text:
As emerging technology reveals new data on neural connectivity, there is an explosion of interest in understanding the underlying network. Connectivity appears complex and departures from being purely random. One way of characterizing this is via connectivity motifs [1,2] (Fig. (c)). 

We give the first theory of how the statistics of such connectivity motifs can give rise to a basic network function. We consider a signal input to a recurrent network, and an output defined as a sum over the activity in all of its elements (Fig. (a)). We assume that the elements are identical, and that each is modeled by a linear input-output transfer function of its own. We then use tools from control theory to describe the network-wide transfer function, which characterizes input-output behavior of the network as a whole.

We find that the network-wide transfer function is determined by the statistical prevalence of chain motifs (Fig. (c)) along with the single-unit transfer function. We show this by developing a series expression of the transfer function that shows contributions of each motif in order. The prevalence of a motif is quantified by a graphical quantity we call the motif cumulant; importantly, in practical examples they fall off quickly with size of the motif [3,4]. The consequence is that measurements of prevalence of motifs involving only a few cells, when assembled through our expression, are often enough to predict the behavior of a network as a whole.

The way that motifs combine to determine the network-wide transfer function has an intriguing structure (Fig. (b)). This reveals how networks structure shapes the network transfer function to produce varied spectral and temporal features (Fig. (d)). We also provide examples where these features may be employed to sustain functions such as signal de-noising and extending the time constant with which signals reverberate in a network. Our theory is readily generalized to cases such as random input and output weights.
title: How connectivity motifs can shape signal filtering in recurrent neural networks

text:
How variable and noisy is the neural code arising from the joint activity of recurrently connected cells? Isolated neurons are known to respond to fluctuating input currents with reliable spike patterns, but variability in stimulus-evoked spike trains is increasingly pronounced in deeper, more recurrently connected brain areas such as cortex. What are the network-level sources of this variability, and how they might constrain spiking features relevant for coding remains an open question.
We focus on spiking model networks with sparse, random connectivity and balanced excitation and inhibition that reproduce the irregular firing that typifies cortical activity. In such models, activity is known to be chaotic, with extremely strong sensitivity of spike outputs on tiny changes in a network’s initial conditions. Nevertheless, when subject to temporally fluctuating driving inputs, networks can have chaotic attractors of limited dimension and geometric properties leading to reduced spiking variability at the single-cell level. As recent studies suggest that the impact of noise on network coding cannot be understood by single cell properties alone, we study mechanisms underlying the joint activity of entire networks.
We derive a bound for the entropy of joint spike pattern distributions in large spiking model networks in response to a fluctuating temporal signal. The analysis is based on results from random dynamical systems theory and complimented by detailed numerical simulations. We find that despite very weak conditional correlations between neurons, the resulting joint variability of network responses is surprisingly lower than what would be expected by considering only limited statistical neural interactions. Moreover, joint spiking variability is strongly constrained by the level of temporal features of input stimuli.
title: Structured chaos shapes joint spike-response noise entropy in temporally driven balanced networks

text:
Among the plethora of spatial and temporal activity patterns population bursting is observed in brain neuronal networks under various experimental conditions [1-2]. Being intensively investigated experimentally this phenomenon has found to be an essential feature for dissociated cultures of neuronal networks. However, dynamical mechanisms of population bursting still remain poorly understood. Computational modeling provides a comprehensive insight to the network level mechanisms of generating and propagating spiking activity[3-4]. Here we present a computational model of neuronal network composed of Izhikevich neurons interconnected with Tsodyks-Uziel-Markram synapses [5-6].
The network consisted from several neuronal populations reproducing the ratio between fractions of different neuronal types presented in the experiments with cultures. The model was implemented using CUDA technology, providing significant accelerations of the simulations.

Using computational modeling key characteristics of population bursts (i.e. period, duration) werere measured depending on various network parameters. Epileptiform seizure-like activity in the form of superburst discharges was observed in the model under certain values of the model parameters. The critical role of different parameters in generating superburst activity was investigated and the parameter ranges and conditions crucial for the presence of different types of superbursts were revealed.
We found that variation of single synaptic parameters didn't significantly change bursting period. Also altering most of the parameters slightly affected the bursts duration. The only parameter corresponding to decaying time of excitatory postsynaptic currents significantly influenced the burst duration. Increasing this parameter also led to superbursts appearing. Our results indicate that the superbursts emerges when the balance between inhibition and excitation shifts toward the higher excitability.
title: Computational modeling population bursts in dissociated cultures of neuronal networks

text:
Rats gather information about their environments with a numerous behavioral strategies and sensory sampling patterns. Traditionally, place-cell firing fields are derived from locomotive epochs, without differentiation of the diverse sensory sampling patterns (i.e. sniffing, whisking and head turns). Early studies of hippocampal place coding attributed variability of spatial tuning to either internal neural processes or behaviour-reward structure of the task (c.f. Fenton et al 2010). At the same time contribution of overt behavioral variables to spatial representation is poorly understood. Here we posited to demonstrate that much of observed variability of place-cell tuning stem from an incomplete behavioral characterization. 

We captured the complexity of exploratory behavior of a rat by means of marker-based 3D tracking of biological motion. With this technique we achieved high spatial (~100um) and temporal (~8 msec) resolution, which allowed accurate behavioral state segmentation. 

First, we used both empirically-derived and discriminant analysis based (QDA, trained on expert labeling) classification features to automatically segment and classify across sessions and animal such behavioral states as walking, rearing, head turning, head-bobbing and autonomic behavior.

Second, refined analysis of kinematic features of the rat’s head and body motion (height and pitch) allowed us differentiating two modes of so-far assumed homogeneous walking state, which we speculate correspond to random foraging and vision-based navigation. 

Third, we investigated spatial and temporal aspects of hippocampal place cell firing during different walking states. We found that majority of place cells exhibited complete change of spatial tuning properties between walking states, ranging from rate to place remapping. 

We argue that changes of spatial representation across newly discovered two patterns of walking are associated and result from distinct sensory sampling modes.
title: Behavioral state dependence of hippocampal place cell expression in the exploring rat

text: Information coding in the brain has been associated with precise timing of neuronal spike firing and internal oscillatory dynamics. This timing strongly depends on the presence of fast membrane potential fluctuations, which mostly rises from endogenous high frequency oscillations in the gamma range (30-150 Hz). Previous studies have shown that activation of local cortical networks is associated with the transient emergence of local gamma oscillations (Sirota et al 2008). To extend this work to all cortical layers we used multiple silicon probes to record extracellular field potentials and multiple single unit activity across all cortical layers in somatosensory cortex of rats during awake and sleep. Laminar analysis of neocortical gamma bursts, independently detected in time, frequency and space, revealed the existence of multiple putative gamma oscillators. These gamma bursts were spatially confined to superficial and deep layers, exhibiting distinct ranges of oscillation frequency and synchronized with local ensembles of neurons, suggesting the existence of several distinct circuits that generate these oscillations. In order to explore the mechanistic role of gamma oscillations across sleep and awake states, as well as the mechanisms responsible for the slow time scale dynamics of gamma oscillations, we characterized the modulating effect of cortical slow oscillations, hippocampal theta rhythm and optogenetic subthreshold AC modulation on gamma oscillatory dynamics. All identified neocortical gamma oscillators were temporally coordinated by the slow rhythms, but with notable difference depending on the laminar and frequency localization of the oscillator. We hypothesize that analysis of circuit-specific neocortical dynamics with respect to hippocampal theta and slow oscillations is instrumental for understanding the mechanisms of information flow via these circuits during learning and memory consolidation.
title: Laminar analysis of neocortical gamma oscillators

text:
Acetylcholine (ACh) modulates neuronal responses, leading to functional effects at the network level, including cortical desyncronisation and modulation of theta oscillations in the hippocampus. The complexity of ACh actions suggesting spatially heterogeneous dynamics demands for sensitive measurements in multiple brain regions with high spatio-temporal resolution.
In this work, we developed enzyme-based electrochemical biosensors to assess cholinergic activity with high spatio-temporal resolution and sensitivity. The approach was based on the amperometric measurement of H2O2 generated by choline oxidase (ChOx) in the presence of Choline (Ch) and O2. 
The electrodes consisted in two side-by-side disk shaped 50 µm diameter Pt/Ir wires. This design is inexpensive, scalable, provides high spatial resolution for hippocampal measurements and optimizes rejection of noise and interferents in vivo by sentinel channel subtraction. The Ch measuring site was coated with ChOx and chitosan cross-linked with benzoquinone. For the sentinel, ChOx was replaced by BSA.
Electrochemical measurements were done using a multichannel miniature head-stage (NPI). The biosensors had a detection limit of 10 nM Ch and a response time of ~2 s.
In anesthetized rats, local field potential features were extracted from the recording together with Ch dynamics. Sustained Ch increases during theta periods reached amplitudes up to 5 µM in cortex and 1 µM in hippocampus CA1. Brief theta/desynchronization were accompanied by Ch changes involving decreases followed by slower increases. Control experiments indicated that Ch responses were independent of physiological O2 changes, in agreement with the KmO2 of 2 µM determined in vitro.
The data supports the reliability of the biosensors to measure cholinergic activity in the brain. Spontaneous Ch changes suggest bidirectional modulation of cholinergic tone. We are currently combining these sensors with multichannel electrophysiology in freely moving rodents.
title: Joint analysis of cholinergic tone and network dynamics in cortex and hippocampus in vivo using enzyme-based electrochemical biosensors
