text: Although the importance of synaptic plasticity has long been recognized, the plasticity of the various forms of cortical inhibition has recently started to attract increasing experimental and theoretical attention [1,2]. Amongst its possible manifestations, it was suggested that plasticity operating directly on inhibitory synapses could establish both firing rate homeostasis and a state of balanced excitation and inhibition [3]. In recurrent networks, feedback inhibition is provided through a multi-synaptic loop, suggesting that excitatory firing rates might also be controllable via modification of synapses elsewhere in this loop. Among those, the excitatory synapses onto inhibitory cells have access to the excitatory firing rate as a presynaptic signal and are thus promising candidates to be homeostatic regulators thereof. Here we test this hypothesis in a variety of simple networks. When an homogeneous excitatory population provides the sole input to an inhibitory population, a rate homeostasis can indeed be obtained (Fig 1A). However, even small heterogeneities within the excitatory population cause neurons with high activity to take control of the inhibitory neurons, resulting in an over-inhibition of less active neurons (Fig 1B). Such competition arises because plasticity-induced changes in inhibitory firing, intended to control a particular excitatory cell, will ‘spill over’ to other excitatory cells due to the fanout of inhibitory feedback connections. Rate homeostasis of any excitatory neuron in the circuit would thus require a coordinated change in all excitatory-to-inhibitory synapses, indicating that such an “indirect” homeostatic plasticity rule must be nonlocal. Consequently, indirect inhibitory plasticity is unlikely to be sufficient for homeostatic rate control.
title: Indirect inhibitory plasticity is insufficient for robust homeostatic rate control

text:
We present recent results on the modeling, analysis and numerical analysis of spatially extended conductance based neuronal models subject to channel noise fluctuations, capable of describing realistic features in the nervous system. Such systems are described by a stochastic reaction diffusion equation with additive noise coupled to a control variable with multiplicative noise but no diffusion. It has been recently observed in the mathematical literature that noise in interplay with possibly super-linearly growing nonlinearities may result in numerical artifacts or even divergence of the numerical schemes.

We have shown in a couple of articles, [SaSt1, SaSt2] that the widely used finite difference approximations are consistent for any neuronal model with locally Lipschitz continuous and quasi-monotone coefficients, a natural assumption in the biophysical context. We also derive explicit error estimates for the approximate solution that are consistent with the best rates known in the literature.

As applications, we present the Hodgkin-Huxley and FitzHugh-Nagumo systems with noise, in particular the construction of explicit confidence intervals for statistical estimators of the underlying dynamics useful in the calibration of models to given data.
title: Analysis and Approximation of Stochastic Nerve Axon Equations

text:
We present a theory for a mathematical rigorous multiscale analysis of spatially extended neuronal models incorporating channel noise effects. Particular emphasize is put on pulse solutions  modelling the action potential travelling along the nerve axon. Within the theory, stochastic diffferential equations describing the wave speed of the action potential under the impact of noise, can be derived and further analyzed to quantify the statistics of time jitter, but also propagation failure and further secondary effects like backpropagation and annihilation of action potentials. 

Our analysis is based on a new mathematical approach to the stability properties of travelling pulse solutions of stochastic nerve axon equations, first introduced in the paper [1] for 1D-Nagumo equations, and subsequently in paper [2] for general stochastic bistable reaction-diffusion equations. 

The stability properties of travelling waves are intrinsically characterized in terms of the reaction potential without requiring further explicit knowledge on the specific shape of the wave profile nor its a priori unknown velocity. 

Our methods can be carried over also to wave fronts in stochastic neural field equations. The corresponding results concerning a mathematical rigorous multiscale analysis for stochastic neural field equations are containded in the paper [3].
title: Multiscale analysis for stochastic nerve axon equations

text:
The dynamics of networks with balanced excitatory and inhibitory activities have originally been examined in phenomenological models with fixed weights [1,2]. Those early studies have proposed that such a balance in large scale networks results in irregular firing of the neurons which enables the network to switch rapidly between different states. 
Stimulus preference and memory storage are thought to be encoded in excitatory and inhibitory synaptic strengths. The majority of more recent network models have focused on examining the role of excitatory plasticity rules [3,4], although some studies have also considered the potential impact of various inhibitory STDP rules [5,6]. 
The focus of the present work is on assessing the robustness of balanced activity in feedforward and sparsely connected recurrent networks with plastic excitatory and inhibitory connections. In our investigation, we find that the parameter space in which the overall activity neither disappears nor explodes is rather limited, and that the biologically plausible parameter space is limited further still. To resolve this problem, we introduce short-term facilitation and depression factors for disynaptic and monosynaptic connections respectively that account for the short-term EPSP and IPSP amplitude dependence on presynaptic frequency (implied by electrophysiological studies, monosynaptic [7] and disynaptic [7,8]). The goal of this modification is achieving individual neuron and whole population behaviour that is characterized by a stable limit cycle and results in a balanced network activity for a much wider range of biologically plausible parameter values. 
As an expression of this changed population behaviour, we measure the duration over which stimulus preference in feedforward and memory storage in recurrent networks are maintained.
title: Balancing activity in feedforward and recurrent networks with plastic excitatory and inhibitory connections

text:
Recent studies demonstrated that spontaneous brain activity can form clusters in space and time – neuronal avalanches – the statistics of which have been shown to follow a power law. This phenomenon has been observed in tissue cultures, acute slices, and anesthetized as well as awake animals (Beggs & Plenz, 2003; Petermann et al., 2009). Power law relationships may indicate a phase transition, therefore suggesting that some biological neural networks might be operating at a critical regime between order and chaos.
Several functional benefits of criticality in neural networks have been pointed out, such as maximum dynamic range of sensory input, optimized information transmission and larger information capacity (Shew & Plenz, 2012). However, it is not clear if such networks will be optimal in performing learning tasks. An attribute of the critical state is that the response to an input can be an avalanche of events of any possible size – implying that there is no characteristic emergent response. In the context of reservoir computing that we will consider, it seems rather unlikely for this property to be helpful in learning. Moreover, maintaining the network in a critical state may require particular fine-tuning of the parameters. The inputs into the reservoir might disrupt the balance that is at the heart of the critical state and thus the network could turn uncritical (Rajan et al., 2010).
By combining reservoir computing (Jaeger & Haas, 2004; Maass et al. 2002) with simple limiter control (Corron, 2000; Stoop & Wagner, 2003) we control the state of a spiking recurrent network which performs pattern recognition task, in stable, critical and chaotic regimes (depending on implemented parameters). We argue that for an optimal performance it is required to back away from the critical point to a more stable state. Additionally, the properties of the nonautonomous combined input/reservoir dynamical system and the influence of input on the network’s state is analyzed.
title: Learning in a recurrent neural network before, at and beyond the criticality

text:
The connectivity between neurons - i.e., the number of synapses and their synaptic weights - determines information processing and storage in neural networks. Thus, to understand the functionality of neural networks, we have to understand how they generate their connectivity. Along this line, there are two major mechanisms to modify connectivity: First, synaptic plasticity adapts the synaptic weights of existing synapses. Second, structural plasticity creates and removes synapses. Hereby, the main influence is the volume of the dendritic spine [1] hosting the synapse. This volume is, in turn, linked to the synaptic weight [2]. Both mechanisms are also  influenced by the activity pattern of the network. Thus, to understand how the connectivity in adult neural networks is generated, it is important to understand the interaction of neural activity and the different plasticity mechanisms. 
Here, we focus on a property of cortical connectivity: the characteristic, bimodal distributions of the number of synapses connecting two neurons [3-6]. To investigate how these distributions can emerge from the interaction between synaptic and structural plasticity, we use a probabilistic model, which captures the process of structural plasticity by abstracting it with weight-dependent probability functions. This allows us to analytically calculate the distribution of the number of synapses between two neurons. We then show that the bimodal synapse distributions from cortex will arise when using synaptic plasticity rules with synaptic weights growing with the postsynaptic activity. Given such a synaptic plasticity rule, the different biologically observed distributions for different cortical layers can be explained at corresponding activities with a single set of parameters. 
Surprisingly, albeit using a probabilistic model, the multi-synaptic connections are stable against overly fast activity changes due to a hysteresis, which also indicates a capability of information storage.
title: The formation of multi-synaptic connections by the interaction of synaptic and structural plasticity and their functional consequences

text:
Synaptic plasticity (Long-term potentiation LTP and long-term depression LTD) acts on different time scales [1,2]. The short-term plasticity (STP) lasts 20-30 minutes, while  early-LTP (E-LTP) lasts approximately 1-3 hours, and  late-LTP (L-LTP) lasts for more than 10 hours to days. Biological evidences show that late-LTP involves protein synthesis, while early-LTP and short-term plasticity do not. Importantly, the requirement of synthesis of cellular protein is not sufficient to induce synaptic late-LTP. A synaptic tag must also be marked during early-LTP [5]. According to this observation, a model on consolidation of synaptic plasticity[4] was proposed. 
On the other hand, for the short-time scales, postsynaptic calcium entry mediated by NMDARs and voltage-dependent calcium channels has been shown to be a necessary and sufficient signal to induce synaptic plasticity. A model was proposed in which the occurrence of synaptic potentiation or depression depends on the postsynaptic calcium concentration [3]. This model captures and reproduces many protocol patterns  experimentally observed in hippocampus and neocortex.
We combine the synaptic tagging model [4] with calcium-based synaptic plasticity [3] by linking the short-time scale synaptic plasticity to long-time scales.  With this combined model, amongst others, we analyze how early-LTP/LTD protocols as spike-timings induce late-LTP/LTD. Further, we are able to show effects of the tag-induced cross-talk between several pre-synaptic inputs dependent on input rate, correlation, etc.
In summary, our combined model is the first plasticity model capturing the synaptic dynamics from milliseconds to hours or rather days.
title: Connecting short-time scale of synaptic plasticity to long-time scale

text:
Coexisting attractor states in neural networks provide a possible mechanism for memory and classification [1,2]. It has previously been shown that firing-rate bistability in networks of excitatory and inhibitory neurons can arise from the interplay between the firing rate and the mean and/or the variance of the synaptic input [3,4]. In the variance-driven form of attractor dynamics the excitatory and inhibitory inputs on average cancel and the firing is generated by fluctuations in the input currents. This balanced form of attractor state potentially explains the highly irregular firing typically seen in experimentally recorded spike trains [5].

Here, we investigate the role of inhibition and synaptic timescales in variance-driven attractor states. Using a mean-field model, we study the minimal connection strength required for bistability and its dependence on synaptic and network parameters. We find that the variance-driven attractor is promoted by few but strong inhibitory synapses, thereby providing an additional rationale for the distributions of excitatory and inhibitory weights found experimentally [6]. In a cortical network where excitatory synapses outnumber the inhibitory synapses, the persistence of variance-driven attractor states is hardly affected by the time constant of excitatory synapses (in contrast to mean-driven attractor states [7]).
title: Conditions for fluctuation-driven attractor states and the role of inhibition

text:
Cell assemblies (i.e. goups of highly interconnected neurons) emerge due to correlated neuronal activity, for instance induced by external inputs. Thus, they represent features of the external inputs and are likely to play an important role in the formation of associative memory in the neocortex (Lansner 2009). Various models have been published demonstrating different ways of formation and functional usage of cell assemblies (Buzsáki 2010). However, in most of these models the subset of neurons forming a cell assembly is chosen purely randomly or artificially predefined. Here, we combine the principles of self-organizing maps (Kohonen 2013) as well as those of cell assembly formation to demonstrate the self-organized emergence of highly input specific assemblies. 

The simulated network consists of an input layer that projects via plastic synapses to a plastic recurrent neural network. Each network neuron receives excitatory inputs from other network neurons within a given radius. Inhibition is introduced by a global inhibitory neuron mutually interconnected with all network neurons via non-plastic synapses. All neurons are modeled by rate-based leaky integrator units. Synaptic plasticity is modeled by a generic combination of Hebbian plasticity and synaptic scaling (Tetzlaff 2011). 

Alternately, different subsets of input neurons are activated. Comparable to self-organizing maps, clusters of neurons tuned to one of the input patterns emerge. For disjunct or only slightly overlapping and temporal sufficiently separated input sets, cell assemblies are learned fast and reliable. In case of high overlaps, we find that only after a certain number of pattern presentations the system is able to discriminate them. Similar dynamics are observed for  patterns that are presented immediately consecutive or even overlapping. In general, our observations indicate an interesting interplay between inputs and the self-organized formation of cell assemblies.
title: Dynamics of self-organized cell assembly formation

text:
The ability to estimate time intervals in the range of seconds to minutes is critical to many of our cognitive abilities. However, the underlying neural mechanisms are still not well understood. To tackle this problem, we propose implementing timing tasks in virtual reality (VR) as an extension of classical approaches. VR setups for rodents recently became popular, since with them advanced neurophysiological recording techniques can be used in the behaving animal.
We designed two different tasks, based on well known interval timing tasks, to probe time perception in rodents in VR. Our tasks require estimating temporal intervals while running along a virtual hallway. Using VR we can ensure that the animals indeed perform time estimation. In VR the test environment can be designed without prominent spatial cues thereby preventing alternative solution strategies. In addition, movement speed and optical flow can be de-correlated, such that the animals can not learn a mapping between stimulus duration and running distance. The first task is a modified ready-set-go task in which the animals estimate the duration of a visual stimulus and reproduce it by running. This behavioral readout allows for responses on a continuous scale. In addition, specific intervals do not need to be trained beforehand. The second task is a time bisection task. Here, the animals are asked to estimate the time they run down the hallway until the projection switches to a Y-shaped maze. They then need to choose either the left or the right arm of the Y-maze to report if the interval was perceived as long or short, compared to previously trained reference intervals. 
We successfully used the above tasks in experiments with Mongolian gerbils and present data from experiments in which we tested timing of durations between 2 and 13 seconds. The results are consistent with reports from previous studies and hence demonstrate the applicability of our approach to probe interval timing in rodents.
title: Probing interval timing in rodents with virtual reality

reasonForTalk: Recasts a classic topic in cognitive neuroscience using an extremely simple concept of motor systems

text: A robust, yet curious phenomenon has almost single-handedly spawned modern-day cognitive neuroscience. If a cue is presented at a location, the efficacy of subsequent orienting towards that location is improved relative to other locations, but only immediately afterwards. A mere few hundred milliseconds later, orienting incurs large costs. These costs have been classically termed “inhibition of return” (IOR), alluding to voluntary, cognitive strategies avoiding perseverance at one location. However, despite this popular hypothesis, the origins of IOR remain elusive. Here we show that classic IOR can be fully accounted for by the simple fact that motor systems are intrinsically rhythmic. We developed and experimentally validated a model that only takes into account saccadic rhythmicity to fully replicate orienting dynamics, including early “attentional capture” and later IOR. In this model, based on one we recently published (Hafed & Ignashchenkova, 2013), cues reset the phase of ongoing saccadic rhythms through classic countermanding. Orienting efficacy towards subsequently presented targets simply depends on the phase of the saccadic rhythms at which these targets appear. Critically, the model only works if the entire gamut of saccadic activity, including tiny microsaccades, is taken into account, and only when known dynamic interactions in countermanding take place (Hafed & Ignashchenkova, 2013). The most striking property of the model is that it predicts that microsaccades can be extremely rare but still influence performance, consistent with our data. Thus, phase modulation of motor rhythmicity explains the facilitatory/inhibitory influences of cues independent of high-level cognitive strategies. More broadly, the strong explanatory power of simple resetting mechanisms in our model suggests that classic attentional modulations may be manifestations of existing oscillatory fluctuations in brain state – fluctuations that are merely uncovered when cues reset them.
title: Oculomotor system rhythmicity accounts for inhibition of return

text:
The first processing circuit of olfaction (antennal lobe or olfactory bulb) exhibits a number of surprising nonlinear features, but how these emerge collectively remains an open challenge. We stress three open puzzles. First, the antennal lobe of insects is capable of separating sensory input representations from two different odor signals. At the same time, our recent experimental work [1] suggests that the same circuit may also join representations of other pairs of odors. Second, studies on olfactory bulb have shown that gradual mixtures of two odors generate representations among projection neuron activities that split a large set of mixing ratios into two or three discrete representational classes. Third, the same circuit can simultaneously be robust against smaller concentration fluctuations, exhibiting concentration invariance, yet sensitive to larger average concentration changes. Taken together, these studies suggest that the same circuit processes information in distinctly different, nonlinear ways that depend on the input only. How do these nonlinear processing modes collectively emerge in recurrent circuits?

Here we propose [2] that first olfactory processing circuits actively use and combine the highly heterogeneous circuit connectivity [3] with the nonlinear local input-output responses. Ex-perimental evidence suggests that whereas some interneurons connect to only one or a few other glomeruli, others connect to many. We now show that heterogeneous connections of interneurons may selectively inhibit particular sets of sensory neurons, thereby translating a dense into a sparse coding scheme in a systematic way. As a consequence, specifically het-erogeneous inhibition may provide an integrating view on the debated role of interneurons by offering one simultaneous answer to (at least) all of the above three puzzling findings in sensory neuroscience.
title: Selective inhibition -- How do olfactory circuits compute?

text:
Despite the fact that feature-based attentional modulation is commonly observed in primate extrastriate visual cortex, little is known about the the underlying modulatory circuit. Specifically, how feature-based modulation is distributed when multiple features are attended simultaneously is not well understood.
We trained a macaque in a complex match-to-sample paradigm, designed to direct attention to different features. A random dot pattern (RDP) instructed the monkey which out of three matching rules to apply. The movement of the RDP, its color, or both combined had to be compared to a subsequently shown test stimulus. We recorded responses of single units from motion-sensitive area MT for 16 different test stimuli which occurred as targets and non-targets during each session.
We found that the firing rate increased for preferred target stimuli relative to non-target stimuli. This was regardless of which feature was attended or which rule was applied. Specifically, neurons which were modulated by the presence of target directions also fired more strongly when the motion of the RDP was irrelevant, but a target color was presented. Most notably, in the case in which a conjunction of two target features had to be detected, MT single units were already fully modulated when just one of the two target features was present.
An analysis of the time-courses of feature-based modulation revealed that in motion selective area MT, feature-based attentional modulation to motion emerged almost ‘in step’ with stimulus evoked activity. Attention evoked by target colors emerged later during stimulus presentation. In cases in which both features were attended simultaneously, we observed a complex interaction between the two types of modulations.
Our results are consistent with a theory of a unified, object-based attentional system, which is not selective enough to directly contribute to the behavioral choice of the monkey when a complex feature-matching rule has to be applied.
title: The time courses and interactions of feature-based attentional modulations in macaque area MT

text: Grid cells are a key component of the spatial representation in high-end cortices in the brain. Located in the medial entorhinal cortex (mEC), they merge information coming from the neocortex and establish a recurrent loop with the hippocampus, known to store spatial memories. During a critical developmental phase, grid cells gradually come to express a prototypical hexagonal pattern of activity as a neural correlate of the animal's position. These cells are thought to contribute to spatial cognition, to the formation of episodic memories and, ultimately, to have an important role in spatial navigation. However, which phenomena are responsible for this neural activity remains unknown and controversial. In a biologically plausible candidate model to explain the properties observed in grid cells, two factors control the self-organized development of grid-like activity: adaptation and associative learning. While adaptation determines the typical grid spacing, Hebbian learning strengthens the association between position and multi-peaked activity. In virtue of its dependence on exploration, this model predicts specific patterns in non-flat environments. In the special case of hyperbolic geometry of constant negative curvature, regular tessellations of space other than hexagonal ones are possible. In this work, we show that in a physical realization of this geometry, the so-called pseudosphere, grid activity derived from our model can be organized in a heptagonal array, for a specific range of the ratio between grid spacing and pseudosphere radius. Moreover, tessellations with larger coordination numbers or even more complex organizations can be obtained and characterized by controlling any of these two geometrical factors.
title: Representation of hyperbolic geometry in a self-organized model of grid cells

text: The neuroanatomical connectivity of cortical circuits has been shown to follow certain rules, the exact origins of which are still poorly understood. One such rule is that excitatory synaptic sizes (and, correspondingly, efficacies) follow a long-tailed, approximately lognormal distribution. A second such rule is the so-called common neighbor rule, which states that the connection probability between any two neurons increases with the number of shared neighbors. We show how both experimentally observed properties can arise as a consequence of the interaction of multiple plasticity mechanisms in a recurrent spiking network model. We additionally reproduce several experimentally observed elements of synaptic dynamics. Our model is a recurrent network of inhibitory and excitatory leaky integrate-and-fire neurons embedded in a two-dimensional sheet. The network combines spike timing dependent plasticity with two homeostatic mechanisms (synaptic normalization and intrinsic plasticity) and a structural plasticity mechanism for the pruning and creation of synapses. We show that this establishes a long-tailed, approximately lognormal distribution of synaptic efficacies consistent with previous modeling results and experimental data on synaptic strengths and sizes. Additionally, we demonstrate that the distance-dependent formation of new synapses can account for the some aspects of the experimentally observed common neighbor rule. Our results demonstrate that fundamental neuroanatomical features of cortical wiring can arise as a consequence of the interaction of multiple plasticity mechanisms and physiological constraints.
title: Self-Organization in Cortical Wiring: Long Tails and Common Neighbors

text: Vision is an active process involving different kinds of eye movements. How are these movements controlled and what are the underlying neural signals? How is this control learned during development? Biomechanical simulations can help us to better understand the underlying problems of visual perception and motor control. Here we introduce OpenEyeSim, a detailed three-dimensional biomechanical model of the human extra-ocular eye muscles (Figure 1) including a visualization of a virtual environment. The main purpose of OpenEyeSim is to serve as a platform for developing models of the joint learning of visual representations and neural control of eye muscles in the perception-action loop. The architecture and parameters of OpenEyeSim are based on measurements of the human eye [1,2] and it allows to simulate realistic types of eye movements. For our simulations we use the biomechanical simulator Opensim [3], an open source software that already implements a variety of muscle models and includes many musculoskeletal models. In order to allow modeling closed-loop interaction with the visual environment, we have extended OpenSim such that we can place virtual cameras into the rotating eyeballs and simulate visual processing. For the sake of simplicity, muscles are represented as solid objects and pulleys are fixed (passive pulleys). An interesting direction for future research will be modeling layered muscles that have orbital and global layers, as well as implementing the active pulley model presented by Miller [4]. Even without such extensions, however, the model is already suitable for studying the development of visuomotor control. For instance, current work is exploiting OpenEyeSim to develop a model for the joint development of disparity tuning and vergence control during infancy. We suggest that OpenEyeSim is a useful platform for studying many of the complexities of oculomotor control and learning during normal and abnormal visual development.
title: OpenEyeSim – a biomechanical model for studying the development of oculomotor control

text:
The locus of expression of synaptic plasticity has been hotly debated for decades (Padamsey and Emptage, 2014) . It is now clear that synaptic plasticity can be both pre- and postsynaptically expressed. Yet the functional role of this segregation remains entirely mysterious. Although it is known that long and short-term synaptic plasticity interact (Sjöström et al, 2003, 2007), most accounts treat these forms of plasticity independently. Here, we introduce a phenomenological model of spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) that unifies pre- and postsynaptic components.
Our unified STDP model captures the co-variation of short and long-term plasticity while being consistent with a wide range of experimental results. We find that the locus of expression — as determined by Coefficient of Variation analysis — depends on the timing and frequency of spiking. Functionally, unified STDP renders synapses more reliable and informative communication channels, as has been observed in vivo (Froemke et al, 2013). In addition, this learning rule implements a synaptic switch, which provides faster relearning of previously experienced stimuli, akin to memory savings theory (Ebbinghaus, 1885). Furthermore, a recurrent network governed by unified STDP yields synaptic dynamics that correlates with connectivity, and maintains a healthy firing regime even in the absence of homeostatic mechanisms. Finally, synapses in the network gradually shift from high to low release probability, similar to the widely observed shift of synaptic dynamics that occurs in development (Reyes and Sakmann, 1998), which suggests a potential causal relationship between unified STDP and maturation of synaptic release.
Taken together, our results suggest that there is a tight link between synaptic dynamics, connectivity, and function. This unified STDP learning rule provides neuronal networks with attractive computational features and helps explain several synaptic properties in the intact brain.
title: A unified model of pre and postsynaptic STDP

text:
The fMRI BOLD response to a spatially confined visual stimulus pattern extends over larger area on the primary visual cortex (V1) than could be expected from the receptive fields of individual neurons. The excitatory neurotransmitter glutamate has been found to play a major role in linking the neuronal activity to the hemodynamic response. We sought to explain the distinct spatial tuning of the BOLD response and the neuronal spiking from the spatial spread of excitatory input to individual neurons on V1. While a neuron responds with spiking only to stimuli within its narrow receptive field, it receives modulatory input from much larger region of the input space. Due to dendritic filtering properties, the inputs landing on distal and proximal regions of a neuron’s dendritic tree have distinct effects on the spike frequency of the neurons. Our hypothesis was that modulatory (subthreshold) neural input activation from distal sites, landing on distal parts of the dendrites, may result in a large spatial spread of activation as measured in fMRI, while the neural spiking output is tightly confined to the simulated region.
This hypothesis was studied in a two-dimensional recurrent spiking neuronal network with spatially realistic extent of lateral and intracortical feedback connections. Each pyramidal V1 neuron consisted of multiple compartments. The distribution of synapses among the distal and proximal compartments was separately varied for different inputs. 
The fMRI signal spread in the model, as proxied with the excitatory (glutamatergic) conductance, was commensurable with the fMRI response to a wedge oriented laterally along the horizontal meridian of the visual field. Supporting our hypothesis, a good fit to the data could be obtained only with nonisotropic landing of modulatory feedback to distal dendrites, when the requirement of the spiking response of the V1 neurons being limited to input within their narrow receptive fields was imposed.
title: Bridging spatial spread of fMRI and neural responses in a recurrent network model of the primary visual cortex

text: Sleep stages switch dynamically, following a deterministic part of the dynamics as well as stochastic switching. Stochasticity of sleep durations have been reported exponentially-distribted thus random, while wake periods appear power-law distributed in some studies, while deviations are observed elsewhere. We extend a sleep stage diffusion model (Lo et al, EPL 2002) to account for these deviations (Barkentien and Claussen, to be submitted). In future, more attention should be due to automatic scoring (Volkland and Claussen, in preparation) to remove scorer-dependent biases.

text: Neurons of a given type exhibit variability in fine spatial features while, usually, their gross features remain relatively consistent. When comparing neuronal morphologies based on such spatial features, inconsistencies such as linear spatial shifts, rotations and scaling have to be taken into account. Here, we outline a preprocessing method to spatially align morphologies of neurons.  First, a set of morphological landmark features are identified which are consistent across the available set of morphologies. These landmark features are usually gross spatial features like a portion of a thick axon or a major branching point. Each morphology is then linearly transformed so that these landmark features align. We apply this preprocessing strategy to a set of 3-D reconstructed morphologies of a vibration sensitive neuron (DL-Int-1) in the honeybee which is assumed to play an important role in waggle dance communication (Ai et.al., 2009). We find that, post transformation, all other regions of the morphologies also align well, as indicated by the close clustering of the principal axes of these morphologies. When the same alignment procedure was applied to a different neuron with the same gross spatial features, we found the resulting principal axes to significantly differ from those of the former group. This suggests that our method could be used in the classification of neurons whose morphologies differ only in fine spatial features. This preprocessing method could also be useful in analyses where fine branches need to be spatially combined across samples to determine target projection areas of the neurons.
title: Method for comparing and classifying morphologies of neurons based on spatial alignment.

text:
Scientific progress depends increasingly on collaborative efforts that involve exchange and re-analysis of previously recorded data. The German INCF Node (G-Node, www.g-node.org) aims at solutions for efficiently managing electrophysiological data and metadata, so that the researcher can focus on the scientific questions rather than on problems of data management.
The variety of data formats is a challenge in neurophysiology, and the Neuroshare API (neuroshare.org) is an attempt to unify data access. The G-Node Neuroshare Tools provide Python utilities to take full advantage of the Neuroshare API on various platforms [1]. To overcome the limitations of the Neuroshare standard in the long term, in the context of the INCF Data Sharing Program we are developing a common data format capable of integrating various types of neuroscientific data and metadata [2]. Efficient data selection for analysis requires that all metadata describing the experimental conditions are available with the data. The odML metadata format facilitates automated metadata capture and management and enables consistent data annotation [3]. odML Tools include libraries, a graphical editor, and an app for mobile devices for convenient metadata entry during the experiment [4]. The G-Node GNData platform [5] achieves integration of neurophysiological data and metadata by combining data representation according to the Neo data model for electrophysiology [6] with odML metadata. Programmatic data access is enabled by an API with client tools for popular frameworks (Matlab, Python) for seamless integration with the scientist's data analysis [7]. The G-Node data sharing services enable researchers to access their data from anywhere in the world and to share data with colleagues or the public. In addition, G-Node supports scientists in making resources and data available, by hosting databases, services, and published data, and offers training courses on a regular basis.
title: Neuroinformatics for efficient data management and reproducibility in electrophysiology

text: The resolution of spatial position, spatial-frequency and orientation encoding decays with distance from the fovea. Furthermore, when the area surrounding a target is cluttered, objects become even more difficult to identify and discriminate ("crowding"). We investigated the coding of position and orientation information by measuring human sensitivity to spatial distortions applied to letter stimuli. Spatial distortions offer a useful method to probe sensitivity to position and orientation because they can be applied to arbitrary images. Observers identified which of four peripherally-presented letters was distorted (4AFC task). We varied the amplitude and frequency characteristics of two band-limited distortion techniques: radial frequency distortion patterns [1] and bandpass noise distortion [2]. In a second condition, target letters were surrounded by four flanking letters to induce crowding. We characterise the change in sensitivity across the spatial scale of distortion for both distortion types and under crowded conditions. We will present an image-based metric of contour change that quantifies the size of the distortions on the same physical axis, and discuss the degree to which sensitivity to spatial distortions can be accounted for by early visual mechanisms.
title: Human sensitivity to spatial distortions in the periphery

text:
Spontaneous cortical activity -- the ongoing cortical activity in absence of intentional sensory input -- is considered to play a vital role in many aspects of brain functions. We use a Gaussian-binary Deep Boltzmann Machine (GDBM) for modeling the activity in early cortical visual areas and relate the random sampling in GDBMs to the spontaneous cortical activity. Our work demonstrates the GDBM is a meaningful model approach for basic receptive field properties and the emergence of spontaneous activity patterns in early cortical visual areas.

As an extension of a DBM[1] to real-value inputs, a GDBM is an undirected graph with units organized into layers. The inference in a (G)DBM incorporates both the top-down and the bottom-up messages, which gives (G)DBM an advantage in propagating the input uncertainties. 

After training a GDBM on natural image patches, we show that the samples collected from the model's probability distribution encompass similar activity patterns as found in the spontaneous activity[2]. Specifically, filters having the same orientation preference tend to be active together. 

We collected the responses of the hidden units to the stimuli of grating bars. The average response over all the stimuli of each orientation was calculated and considered to be the model’s response to the specific orientation, which corresponds the single-condition orientation map (SCM). 

Afterwards, we sampled the states of the model starting from a random initialization. This procedure generated samples from the model’s distribution, which were considered as spontaneous frames (SFs). By calculating the spatial correlation coefficients between the SCMs and the SFs, we established the similarity between them.

To further verify the activity patterns in the spontaneous frames, we used SOM to project the SFs onto 40 nodes that were arranged on a circle. After training, the correlations between the weight vectors of the nodes and the SCMs support our hypothesis.
title: Modeling correlations in spontaneous activity of visual cortex with Gaussian-binary deep Boltzmann machines

text:
The axon initial segment (AIS) controls the transformation of dendrosomatic synaptic input into spike output and the backpropagation of action potentials into the dendrites due to its lower spike initiation threshold.  Channel density and kinetics can both contribute to this low threshold. However, the nature of such threshold differences is unknown and topic of current debates.

Dynamical response properties give a constraint on the AIS function. Here we study the dynamical response properties of multi compartment models with different levels of anatomical and biophysical detail. To study these properties, we inject Gaussian noise currents into the soma and its vary mean, variance and the correlation time $\tau_I$. We then calculate the dynamic firing rate response of a population of independent neurons. This is described at linear order by a filter function with frequency dependent gain as done by Higgs and Spain 2009.

We studied the frequency dependent gain function of the models to see whether they reproduce two experimental observations from cortical pyradmidal cells a) the high cut-off frequency in the range of 200 Hz  b) the increasing cut-off frequency for increasing $\tau_I$ which we call the Brunel effect (Brunel, et al. 2001).

Two models were tested. 1) Fleidervish, et al. 2010, a detailed model that reproduces the sodium currents in the AIS and soma of pyramidal cells. 2) Brette 2013, a ball and stick model where action potential onset sharpness is a consequence of a decoupling of AIS voltage and somatic voltage beyond a bifurcation point.

We find that for 1) and 2) the gain function is dominated by a low pass filter around the membrane time constant. The influence of morphological and kinetic parameters on the high frequency tails is currently investigated. 2) is highly suited to study the influence of the decoupling bifurcation on the gain function.
title: Which cell properties determine the dynamic gain of a population of independent neurons?

text:
In higher mammals' primary visual cortex, orientation selectivity of neurons is arranged in a spatially continuous fashion composing an orientation preference map (OPM) [1,2]. 

OPMs are aperiodic patterns containing topological defects named pinwheels, which were modelled by means of non-equilibrium pattern formation theory [3]. Cortical pinwheel statistics [4,5] are in good agreement with the pinwheel statistics of this model and only this model. Most intriguingly a pinwheel density of pi, which is consistent with the experimental value 3.14(6). Commonly, it is believed that neuronal activity mechanisms cause the formation of OPMs. Recent evidence for ocular dominance maps, however, indicates that precursors of maps might already be encoded genetically [5], which can also be reasoned by genetic assimilation [7].

Here, we introduce an extension of the seminal model devised in [3]. Our extension models the development of OPMs from a genetic point of view. Long-range interactions, which are a prerequisite for stable OPMs formation, are modelled by retro- and anterograde axonal signalling. Local interactions are modelled with biologically plausible gene regulatory mechanisms. Our model shows that genetic features alone can shape the design of OPMs, while belonging to the same universality class and therefore exhibiting the same pinwheel statistics. This might cast doubt on the idea that neuronal activity alone shapes OPMs.
title: A model for genetically encoded orientation preference maps

text:
Neural systems show a wide variety of complex dynamics on different time scales. Specifically, on the short time scale of neuronal activations (ms-sec), several theoretical models demonstrate that complex transient dynamics enables neural circuits to process a broad range of nonlinear problems [1]. This approach, amongst others, is based on the inherent diversity (randomness) of neural systems. On the other hand, the slower mechanisms of synaptic plasticity (minutes to hours) adapt synaptic efficacies to form ordered structures as neural cell assemblies [2]. This type of dynamics is in stark contrast to the needed randomness of connectivity for transient dynamics. However, contrary to expectations, several theoretical studies show that synaptic plasticity enhances the performance of networks solving nonlinear problems [3-5].
In this study we analyze how and why synaptic plasticity supports the transient dynamics needed for solving nonlinear tasks.
We investigate a random neural ntwork with connections adapted by a generic combination of Hebbian plasticity and synaptic scaling [6,7]. A subset of neurons receives repeatedly a time-varying input and forms a cell assembly [7]. Further repetitions of the input lead to a gradual growth of the cell assembly by incorporating more neurons. In parallel, the network is required to compute a desired nonlinear version of the input. To test whether this computation is successful, the connections between the neurons of the network and a linear output neuron are adapted by a supervised learning algorithm [8]. Remarkably, the performance of the computation increases with the growth in size of the cell assembly. Thus, the slow, ordering dynamics of synaptic plasticity supports the computational capability of the fast transient by integrating more neurons and, therefore, more diversity into the computational system.
Our work shows that both concepts are not mutually exclusive but they interact with each other in a positive way.
title: The Role of Synaptic Plasticity in Reservoir-like Networks

text:
To relate the functionality of large-scale neural networks to the level of single cells, it is a key requisite to uncover the spike trains of a large number of simultaneously recorded neurons from extracellular recordings. Silicon-based arrays with thousands of electrodes allow to simultaneously image the electrical activity of hundreds to thousands of neurons at sub-cellular spatial and high temporal resolution.
However, existing spike sorting algorithms are only practical for up to about 500 electrodes. Probabilistic and real-time methods do not work in unsupervised manner, as they need to be initialized with a traditional sorting. Furthermore, all algorithms are designed for a fixed number of electrodes.

Here we propose a framework for spike sorting algorithms that deals with the unsupervised problem in the case of thousands of electrodes and makes use of the spatial information of dense 2D arrays. Regions of interest (ROIs) with boundaries adapted to the electrical image of single or multiple neurons are constructed automatically. All ROIs can be processed in parallel. Within each region of interest an upper bound for the number of neurons can be estimated from the local data matrix alone. We deploy a simple ICA based algorithm to solve the local spike sorting within ROIs. Redundantly identified units across different ROIs are fused by automatically identifying the best representative. An information theoretic measure is used to assess the isolation quality of units. The framework was implemented in MATLAB and includes a graphical user interface for semi-automatic post-processing and visualization.

We evaluated the framework with recorded and surrogate data (1141 neurons/mm$^2$, 4356 sensors, 27 % spatiotemporally overlapping spikes). 81% of all ground truth units could be identified with error rates below 2%. In conclusion, we provide the first tool to solve the unsupervised spike sorting problem for data from thousands of densely intergrated sensors.
title: A generic divide-and-conquer approach for unsupervised neural spike identification from large and dense array data

text:
Path integration refers to the ability to navigate in an environment using self-motion cues derived from the vestibular and proprioceptive systems. This form of navigation depends on a near continuous estimation of the distance and direction of movement, and is especially important when reliable external landmarks are absent. Because of the iterative nature of path integration, error in the calculation of position is cumulative.
The directional component of path integration likely depends on the activity of head-direction (HD) cells. HD cells fire when the animal's head points in a specific direction, independently of the behavior or location of the animal. Here we developed a protocol to investigate how error accumulates in the activity of HD cells during path integration. We performed in vivo multiple single-unit recordings of HD cells from the anterior dorsal thalamic nucleus of behaving mice. The mice were trained to run on a circular platform during 30 2-min trials. In half of the trials, one light source located at the periphery of the platform was turned on. The remaining trials were performed in darkness. During some recording sessions, the surface of the platform was covered with water to eliminate olfactory cues.
Preliminary results showed that the tuning curves of HD cells were wider during trials performed in  darkness. Moreover, the selectivity of HD cells deteriorated progressively within the 2-min trials in the dark, consistent with the hypothesis that error accumulates in the HD system during path integration. We now plan to investigate which behavioral variables (path length, number of head turns, time elapsed, etc.) contribute to the accumulation of error in the activity of these neurons.
title: Error in head direction signal during path integration.

text: The superficial layers of the medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) contain a variety of spatially selective cell types that are thought to generate a metric representation of space. A prominent cell type there are grid cells that exhibit a regular, hexagonal firing pattern when an animal runs in an open environment. Anatomically, excitatory neurons in the MEC show a high degree of variability ranging from stellate cells to pyramidal cells, and including several intermediate types. Here we investigated whether principal neurons recorded extracellularly in the superficial layers of the MEC can be separated into distinct groups based on their spike patterns at a millisecond time scale. Cluster analysis of spike-time autocorrelations revealed at least two groups, labelled bursty and non-bursty neurons, which also exhibit different spike waveforms. Bursty neurons were twice as likely to be classified as grid cells compared to non-bursty neurons. Moreover, 70% of the detected monosynaptic excitatory connections between principal cells and interneurons originate from bursty neurons. Together, these results suggest that bursty and non-bursty neurons form distinct neuronal populations differing in biophysical properties and network functions.
title: Spike-time autocorrelation reveals functionally distinct cell groups in the medial entorhinal cortex

text:
The widespread use of neuromodulation by nervous systems presents several important computational consequences which are often ignored by computer models. Somehow these circuits must preclude dysfunctional states but at the same time remain flexible and robust.
The activity of the central pattern generating pyloric circuit is known to be influenced by several chemicals including dopamine which acts by differentially modulating the intrinsic cellular (ionic currents) and synaptic properties of each neuron. To date, experimentalists have accumulated a considerable body of evidence detailing dopamine’s effect on each kinetic and voltage sensitive parameter of the circuit but lack a unified conceptual framework for studying these effects systematically. One approach is to embody the experimental data in a highly detailed computer model and use this as a bridge to establish a link between the low level cellular and synaptic changes and the higher level systems dynamics and functionality. Through this prism, the underlying mechanisms of neuromodulatory control can be unravelled. This study uses once such model to access the impact of dopamine on the phase, frequency and synchronisation of the pyloric circuit.
Here, dopamine was found to advance or delay the phase of each neuron by differentially modulating each cell’s complement of ionic currents in a manner consistent with in vivo observations. In agreement with dynamic clamp experiments, the models phase response diagram indicated that early synaptic inhibition onto PD decreased the circuit’s frequency and late synaptic inhibition enhanced it. The dopamine enhanced PD to AB electrical coupling accounted for the observed decline in circuit frequency, with stronger coupling promoting lower frequencies and vice versa. The dopamine induced disruption of PY electrical coupling was quantified in terms of slow wave plateaux and rapid spiking synchrony using the spike distance metric.
title: Modelling the Pyloric Circuit under Dopamine.

text:
Our aim is to predict personality from the resting state EEG. We have collected an extensive dataset of 388 subjects, which consists of eyes open and eyes closed resting state EEG recordings (32 active electrodes) together with five factor personality scores. Validated questionnaires were used to assess five personality traits, which are: openness to experience, conscientiousness, extroversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism. 
After artefact rejection and computation of power spectra, we use a half of the data to find the best technique for predicting the personality scores and then we test the true accuracy of the prediction on the other half of the data.
In particular, we use a 10-fold cross-validation for a half of the data in order to find the best combination of hyper-parameters for machine learning where a predictive model is trained in order to classify previously unseen data points. We tested different techniques to pre-process the data by normalizing, pooling and reducing dimensions; we also use different machine learning algorithms (linear and non-linear support vector machines) with different parameters.
The accuracy of the best model is estimated on the other half of the data using leave-one-out cross-testing. 
The procedure was also validated on the task of classifying eyes open and eyes closed trials where the cross-testing resulted an error of $10\%$ ($p<10^{-60}$).
title: Predicting personality from the resting state EEG

text: Lamination is a landmark feature of cortical architecture but the role played by interlayer connections in shaping the dynamical responses of a cortical column has not yet been fully elucidated. Here, we analyze a mean-field model of a cortical column with realistic interlayer connections (the one-column "connectome" of Binzegger & al. 2004). Systematically varying efficacy of excitation and inhibition in the model we find phase diagrams showing a great diversity of possible dynamical regimes. Due to the presence of delayed inhibition and the interaction of layers, oscillations can be generated. Oscillations in different layers may be phase-locked or phase-precessing and have different frequencies. For some parameters high frequencies (gamma-like) predominate in L23 while low beta-like frequencies predominate in L5. Remarkably, while this experimentally observed tendency is usually attributed to the different cortical sources to different layers, here it arises spontaneously in an isolated model column, resulting from the multilayer connectivity. The column is thus intrinsically predisposed to communication-through-coherence processes over multiple frequency bands. Furthermore, we find that horizontal or top-down currents, mediating context information, are non-linearly amplified and that vertical inter-layer interactions alone already contribute to contextual modulations of the column response, besides other interactions not explicitly modeled. Our model predicts inter-layer competition behaviors which could be probed experimentally by selective optogenetic (in)activation techniques. The robustness of our findings is discussed by comparison with alternative wiring diagrams. We plan to use our multi-layer model to provide a neural mass description of the activity of local brain regions in a whole-brain scale network model, exploring the self-organized emergence of multi-frequency coherence networks and their role in attentional modulation of functional connectivity.
title: Layered architecture shapes context-dependent response and input integration of a cortical circuit

text:
Oscillatory coherence has been revealed to be a key feature of the rhythmic activity of involved areas in visual attentional tasks. It has been hypothesized that the particular phase relationship between the rhythms of the pertinent areas, allows for a window of directed and precise communication. This hypothesis, known as communication through coherence, provides a framework to understand the mechanisms that mediate fast, flexible and precisely targeted switching between communication pathways. 
Much of the experimental work aimed to show inter-areal coherence or phase coherence  in a context of assumed communication, but a thorough analysis of a suitable measure for quantifying the inter-areal information flow (communication), in a framework of controlled phase relationship has not yet been achieved. 
In this work we investigated through a mechanistic modeling how small motifs of two interacting local populations of conductance-based inhibitory and excitatory neurons connected by long range excitation, set their population mean activity in temporally-restricted synchrony-regulated hierarchical configuration (leader-laggard), despite symmetry and reciprocity of structural connections between them.
We show that the information flow between them, as measured with transfer entropy, is determined by this dynamics. In a model with an output comparable in its synchronization level and statistics with Local Field Potential signals of in vivo recordings, we show that the direction of the information flow is defined by the phase relationship, and that the effective directionality can be uni or bi-directional depending on the level of long range excitation and the synchrony of the system, but always following the structure introduced by the phase dynamics.
title: Directed informtion in synchronous transients

text: High density microelectrode arrays (MEAs, [1]) provide extracellular recordings from thousands of closely spaced electrodes and with sub-millisecond resolution. These devices offer thus novel capabilities to investigate the interplay between ongoing and evoked electrophysiological signaling within networks in-vitro. However, to effectively take advantage from the spatiotemporal resolution of these MEAs, adapted analysis tools are needed. Here we report on our recent advancements toward this goal. A novel high density MEA with on-chip stimulating electrodes was used to record from 4096 electrodes and electrical stimulation was delivered alternatively through one of the 16 equally spaced electrodes on hippocampal primary cultures. From the second week in vitro these cultures display synchronous like events, also called synchronous burst events (SBEs), propagating across the entire network. Notably, these propagations are quite stable along time and emerge in a random fashion from few specific sites of the network. Former attempts in classifying SBEs considered simplified descriptors of neural activity (e.g. center activity trajectory [2]) while here we have adopted a more rigorous approach by applying dimensional reduction techniques (PCA) that takes advantage of the robustness (i.e. high signal to noise ratio) and reproducibility of the cell culture recordings. Interestingly, the PCA classification allowed us to characterize both intrinsic and electrically evoked network-wide SBE propagations with only few PC components (see Fig.1). The PCA methodology also allowed us to finely track the changes of activity in cell cultures treated with synaptic blockers.
title: Investigating cell culture dynamics by dimensional reduction techniques and high-density MEAs

text:
In the mammalian visual system, a hierarchy of cortical areas processes in-
creasingly complex features of stimuli, with an increase in spatial scale. Recent
observations suggest that the increase in spatial scale is accompanied by an
increase in temporal scale, with neurons in higher areas showing slower
dynamics [1]. However, the underlying physiological mechanisms are not un-
derstood. We explored the hypothesis that variation of ion channel expression
across cortical areas determines the change in temporal dynamics of the corre-
sponding neural circuits. We analyzed the freely accessible set of microarray and
RNA-sequencing transcriptome data on human brains, provided by the Allen
Brain Atlas [2]. We tested a set of 70 ion channel-related genes for changes
in expression across the dorsal visual stream. The dataset encompasses genes
coding for the α-subunits of voltage-gated sodium-, potassium-, calcium- and
hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) ion channels, as well
as ionotropic glutamate and GABA receptors (AMPA-, NMDA- and GABA-
receptors). After testing for differential expression across lobes, we used single-
compartment Hodgkin-Huxley models to assess how the resulting subset of chan-
nels influences the timescale of neural dynamics. Preliminary results suggest
that the change of temporal scale across cortical regions is not due to variations
in ion channel expression, but the result of network effects.
title: Channel mechanisms of a hierarchy of timescales across the cerebral cortex

text:
Sharp-wave ripples (SPW-Rs), transient episodes of neural activity combining a sharp wave of dendritic depolarization and a high-frequency oscillation, are a major feature of the cortico-hippocampal communication. Experimental evidence relates these episodes to offline consolidation of memory traces. However, the circuitry dynamics that governs these episodes remains poorly understood. Using multi-site extracellular recordings of the hippocampal CA1, we have previously provided evidence for the existence of differentiated SPW-Rs, whose LFP signatures come in four types that suggest a dynamical coupling between SPWs and ripples[1] (Figure 1a).

Here we develop a methodology to extract dynamical components from peri-event activity of the CA1 stratum radiatum (SR) and stratum pyramidale (PL). We hypothesize that SPW-Rs can be approximated by an instantaneous linear superposition of independent sources with different spectral signatures that account for their dynamics. Inspired by the second order blind identification (SOBI) algorithm[2], our approach estimates the spatial spread and spectral signature of these dynamical sources by implementing a Joint Approximate Diagonalization of the cross-spectral density matrix between recording sites.

Our analysis reveals that dynamical components with distinct spatial signature can be isolated: a broad-band-spectrum component spanning the gamma and ripple bands, originates in SR; and a second component, with clear spectral peak in the ripple band (80-200Hz), originates in PL (Figure 1b c). Differences between SPW-R subtypes are reflected in the spectra of the second component (ripple). We suggest that differences between SPW-Rs are related to local recurrent dynamics within PL, endowing both pyramidal cells and interneurons. Our preliminary findings illustrate the convenience of our approach for extracting meaningful dynamical components from multi-site LFPs during neuronal events and for unraveling their underlying mechanisms.
title: Dynamical source analysis of hippocampal sharp-wave ripple episodes

text:
The study of saliency, here defined as a spatial combination of image features that can capture fixation patterns, is important for both human perception and for computer vision research. However, human fixations are not only determined by the image presented on the screen but also by myriad behavioural biases, including a tendency to look at the centre of the screen and mechanistic temporal effects [1]. The influence of these biases is large [2] and strongly task dependent [3]. Any comparison of saliency models must take these biases into account. 

Here we separate the contribution of image-based saliency and several behavioural biases using a probabalistic framework and information theoretic evaluation. We compare several prominent saliency models to a nonparametric gold standard, in which we capture all the spatial structure that can be explained in the data set. We model fixations using point processes [4], and compare models using mutual information. Using a popular data set [5], we show that the total amount of mutual information that can be extracted from an image about the spatial structure of fixations is 2.1 bits/fixation. The best performing model explains 59% of this total information. Remarkably, a model that ignores image content altogether but captures the observers' centre bias explains 42% of the total information. Once the effect of spatial behavioural biases are removed, saliency models explain only 29% of the mutual information. Thus, purely spatial saliency remains a significant challenge.

Finally, we extend the point process framework to capture temporal dependencies between eye movements, revealing that including a tendency to fixate near to the previous fixation [see also 6] increases the likelihood by more than the best saliency models. If we are interested in understanding how people look at images, focusing on only spatial information ignores important structure that is easily accounted for.
title: How close are we to understanding saliency?

text: Brain research and quantum technology are at the focus of 21st century science. Although theoretical and experimental studies have provided some insights regarding the mechanisms of how the brain acquires, represents and stores information, a comprehensive theory of the brain and the underlying neural information processing is still missing. Experimental techniques to study brain processes on different levels of description, notably the sub-neuron (synaptic, dendritic and axonal), single neuron and neural network level, are therefore of fundamental importance for brain research. Recently, a new promising technique in solid state physics has emerged for measuring electric and magnetic fields at the nanometer scale with unprecedented spatiotemporal resolution (sub-micron and sub-ms range). The nitrogen-vacancy (NV) defect in diamond is a unique ultra-sensitive quantum device that can sense external magnetic and electrical fields via its spin states, which can be read-out optically using electron spin resonances. I will present the efforts undertaken in the NeuronQ project that combines both disciplines, brain research and quantum technology, in a multidisciplinary research effort and aims towards the development of an NV center based neuroimaging system for real-time recording of neural activity on the sub-neuron, neuron and neuron network level under ambient conditions.
title: Quantum magnetic sensing of neurons using nitrogen-vacancy centers in diamond

text:
The neural principles by which vibrotactile frequencies are encoded, memorized, and compared have been well studied in monkeys (reviewed in [2]). More recently, neural correlates for the working-memory aspects of these processes were also identified in human oscillatory EEG activity (cf. [3, 4]). The goal of the present study was to extend these findings by characterizing to what degree comparisons between vibrotactile frequencies may be reflected in the time-frequency spectrum of human EEG recordings.
We asked 21 participants during EEG acquisition to indicate which of two sequentially presented brief vibrotactile stimuli (f1 and f2) was higher in frequency. Single-trial time-frequency maps were analysed to identify correlations of stimulus frequency differences with power changes of the whole frequency spectrum over time.
After the presentation of f2, we found the power of beta-band activity (~15 – 30 Hz) recorded over medial prefrontal and lateral parietal areas to reflect the emergence of the upcoming decision. Crucially, the beta-band power was modulated by the signed frequency differences of the stimuli before responses were given. This modulation exhibited a characteristic spatio-temporal trajectory (from prefrontal to parietal electrodes), and was localized to sources of the premotor areas and primary and secondary somatosensory cortices.
In sum, we show that decision-related signals that were previously only recorded invasively in non-human primates can also be captured with non-invasive EEG recordings. Given the exhaustive empirical evidence that describes the involved neural processes on a microscopic (cf. [2]) and mesoscopic [1] level in monkeys, the frequency comparison task might serve as an exciting new framework to study perceptual decision-making in humans. Moreover, the paradigm seems to be eligible to investigate how neural processes can bridge the scales from microscopic single neuron activity to the systems level.
title: Oscillatory EEG activity in the beta-band reflects tactile decision-making

text:
Neural field models (NFMs) provide an alternative to networks of enumerable neurons by describing the collective activity of neural ensembles as excitations of a continuous medium [1]. NFMs are a natural match for the extended and coherent dendritic activations driving local field potentials (LFPs), and thus the electroencephalogram (EEG). However, so far NFMs have typically collapsed the radial dimension of cortex with its intricate layer structure, describing instead a 2D cortical sheet. This corresponds to assuming point neurons, even where different neural ensembles are supposed to reside in different layers [2], since there is then no explicit representation of the spatial extent of the dendrites. However, dendritic trees of single neurons play a fundamental role in synaptic integration and the generation of EEG signals [3], and incorporating diffusive dendritic structure can change NFM dynamics [4].
We implement here a 3D cortical NFM, i.e., we include a spatially extended dendritic dimension in the neural field dynamics. Our starting point is a well-known 2D NFM [5-7]. We explain which biological hypotheses and mathematical approximations are necessary to introduce dendritic properties to this NFM, and demonstrate software capable of simulating the resulting set of equations. We then investigate the influence of dendritic properties, such as the synaptic connectivity and their distribution in the dendritic trees [8], in order to understand the effect of local circuitry. Finally, we provide an outlook on comparing such 3D-NFMs with recordings from epileptic tissue before and after pharmacological treatments. While we focus here on a specific model, the techniques and methods used generalise to any chosen NFM. We expect that 3D-NFMs will become the method of choice for many applications, due to their ability to incorporate experimental data on microcircuitry and their direct applicability to depth electrode recordings.
title: Implementing a Dendritic Dimension in a Cortical Neural Field Model

text:
During an epileptic seizure a wave of population activity is moving through neural tissue. To understand its development it is crucial to know whether or not the neurons are going to be recruited into the wave. We derive an indirect indication for how easy it would be for the neurons to be recruited, by estimating their entrainment ability to periodic pulsatile stimulus, and how the entrainment ability is modified when intrinsic properties of the cell are altered, particularly properties of the currents that have been implicated in certain kinds of epilepsy.

In this study we investigate the effects of periodic stimulation on two (noisy) neuron models: including an M-type potassium and a hyperpolarizing cation (H-) current, respectively. The (over/under)-expression of these channels has been associated with epileptogenesis. Varying the maximal conductances of the M- and H-currents qualitatively changes the shape and magnitude of the model neurons’ phase resetting curves (PRCs).

We begin by representing the neurons by their noisy phase resetting curves (PRCs). From these data we create stochastic phase map, taking careful account of the possibility of multiple inputs per cycle. The stochastic phase map takes phase of a spike relative to the periodic stimulus and maps it to the phase of the subsequent spike. We compute and analyze the spectrum of the Markov transition operator for this stochastic circle map. Pathwise dynamic properties, such as stochastic periodicity (phase-locking), stochastic quasi-periodicity, and chaotic behavior, can be distinguished using the geometry of the transition operator’s spectrum [1]. As a result, a measure of neuron's ability to entrain is obtained.

The procedure is repeated for a number of parameter combinations (M- or H- current maximal conductance, noise level, stimulus strength, stimulus frequency) to explore the dependence of the phase maps’ spectral properties (and resulting entrainability) on intrinsic and input parameters.
title: Modulation of neuronal entrainability by epilepsy-associated currents and noise: a spectral approach

text:
Brian 2 is a fundamental rewrite of the Brian [1,2] simulator for spiking neural networks. It is written in the Python programming language and focuses on simplicity and extensibility: neuronal and synaptic models can be described using mathematical formulae and with the use of physical units[3]. The same formalism can also be used to specify connectivity patterns (e.g. spatial connectivity), using mathematical expressions to define connections, probabilities of connections, number of synapses between neurons, and synaptic delays.
Brian 2 offers two modes of operation: a “runtime mode”, where executable code is generated from the model descriptions on the fly and executed from Python and a “standalone mode”, where a set of source code files is generated that can then be compiled and executed with no dependency on Brian or Python. The runtime mode is ideal for rapid prototyping and interactive exploration, e.g. from a Python console. The standalone mode on the other hand is designed for maximum of performance and for simulating models on a variety of hardware and platforms.
We show a number of example applications for the standalone mode, generating code for a wide range of devices:
- C++ code that is completely independent of Brian, Python or Python libraries. Optionally, this code can be parallelized over multiple CPU cores using the OpenMP libraries.
- Java/Renderscript for Android-based devices, enabling Brian to run neural models on commodity hardware (e.g. phones) for robotic applications[5].
- The GPU enhanced Neuronal Networks (GeNN) framework[6,7], a neural simulator using GPUs to accelerate neural simulations.
- The same approach would also allow the generation of code targeted at neuromorphic computing architectures such as the SpiNNaker platform[8] for which we have started preliminary work.
Brian is made available under a free software license and all development takes place in public code repositories [9].
title: Brian 2: neural simulations on a variety of computational hardware

text:
Understanding neural dynamics requires network models which are physiologically valid yet at the same time analytically tractable. On the one hand, there are biologically realistic neural networks which often lack systematic insights into the underlying dynamics. Moreover, these time-consuming network simulations often fail to link single neuron properties with the network level, which is highly desirable to achieve a deeper understanding of physiological and functional correlations. On the other hand, mean-field networks (MFN) of very simple neuron models are too removed from the reality to address detailed questions about physiology. Thus, MFN based on physiologically realistic yet at the same time mathematically tractable neuron models may be an important step towards this goal. 
Here, we extend the theory of MFN by computing the firing rate of the adaptive exponential integrate-and-fire neuron (AdEx) with spike-triggered adaptation in the presence of Gaussian synaptic noise. Despite the just two dimensions and a handful of parameters, the AdEx can reproduce plenty of spiking patterns observed in-vitro [1]. Hence, it presents an excellent compromise between Hodgkin-Huxley like neuron models and very simple leaky integrate-and-fire neurons (IF) [2]. For computing the firing rate, we use two approaches: 1) We solve the full 2D Fokker-Planck equation (FP) that describes the probability distribution of the membrane potential V and an adaptation current w. 2) We retrieve the solution of the FP of the exponential IF by incorporating w by either its mean or distribution. All approaches were tested with simulations and show a remarkable agreement for different neuron types and layers from the rodent mPFC. Extensions of the equations to incorporate synaptic kinetics, and results for a MFN based on AdEx neurons are also provided. Hence, the present work provides one of the central steps for analytically tractable MF approaches of physiologically realistic model networks
title: Data-driven approximations of the firing rate of the adaptive exponential integrate-and-fire neuron in the presence of synaptic noise
