text:
A large body of experimental evidence shows that place cells in the CA1 region of the hippocampus generate temporal sequential activity during sleep or immobility awake states. Some of these sequences have been shown to correlate with the previous (replay) or the future (preplay) spatial ordering of the corresponding place fields. Because of the abundant recurrent connections, these sequences are thought to originate in CA3 and trigger neuronal sequences downstream, e.g., in CA1. We previously showed that a continuous attractor model for the CA3 network can reliably generate long neuronal sequences (Azizi et al., 2013)⁠. These sequences were generated as a result of bump of activity moving through a preconfigured multi-chart network. Here we extend on this work by incorporating plasticity in the network and studying replay and preplay in CA1. First, we studied how learning in the recurrent connections of the network would affect movement dynamics of the bump. The weights were changed according to non-linear temporally asymmetric Hebbian protocol (Gütig et al., 2003) $$W = dW_p W_{max} + W(1-dW_p)^\mu,$$ for potentiation and $$W = W(1-dW_d)^\mu$$ for depression. The weights change according to $$dW_s = a_se^{\frac{\Delta t}{\tau_s}},$$ in which s = p for potentiation, and s = d for depression. We found that despite the potentially destabilizing effect of synaptic plasticity, a parameter regime can be found in which a bump of activity forms and moves across the networkin one of the charts Figure 1A. This behavior can account for preplay.
Second, we examined the plausibility of the assumption that sequential activity can be transferred from CA3 to CA1 via random feedforward connections. We found significant preplay sequences in the CA1 region for both plastic and rigid connecting weights Figure 1B.
In summary, our results show that stable sequences can originate in a continuous attractor network model of CA3 with plastic synapses, and propagate to CA1.
title: The effect of STDP on the generation and propagation of sequential activity in multiplex neural networks

text: Experimental studies have found that episodic memory in humans is unreliable, often preserving little more than the gist of the experienced episode, but none of the details. We hypothesize that this property of the episodic memory system results from the fact that episodes are stored only in terms of higher order information, i.e., semantic representation, not their underlying sensory inputs.  This hypothesis is similar to Tulving's SPI (Serial-Parallel-Independent) model (Tulving, 1995), in which sensory information is first processed by the semantic system before being stored in the episodic system. Here, we use a computational model to study the interrelation between the semantic and episodic system. In our model, the semantic system is trained by an algorithm called slow feature analysis (SFA) that extracts slowly-varying features from time-varying sensory inputs (Wiskott and Sejnowski, 2002). The semantic system thus compresses the high-dimensional sensory inputs to a lower dimensionality both in space and time, i.e., the semantic representation can be represented by fewer neurons and varies at a lower rate than the sensory input stream. In our model, episodic memories are represented as sequences of semantic representations, which are stored in and retrieved from a memory network. We examine how the quality of episodic memory retrieval is affected by prior semantic knowledge about the content of the episode. We first train two semantic networks each on different objects. Then we store and retrieve episodes containing either the same or the other object. Thus, episodic memory is based either on an appropriate or inappropriate semantic representation, respectively. Our results indicate that episodic memory is more accurate if the underlying semantic representation has been optimized for the object that is being stored in episodic memory, suggesting that the semantic representation plays an important role in episodic memory.
title: The importance of semantic memory for episodic memory

text: Developmental models of neural mechanisms for multisensory information processing use sensory experience to establish an alignment of representations between cross-modal cues [1]. Depending on the correlations between such different sensory cues, the resulting alignment can shape multisensory organization and processing simultaneously at both, structural and functional levels [2]. In this work we present a model of multisensory development, which learns correlations between different sensory streams, by enhancing the interaction between strongly correlated cues and weakening the interaction between uncorrelated cues. Combining Self-Organizing-Maps, to represent sensory data, and Hebbian Learning, to support correlated co-activation in each map, our model demonstrates enhancement and suppression of interactions between sensory cues as shown in [3]. This learning scheme, which combines local cooperation and competition at map level with adaptive interactions between maps, is suitable to model the developmental process of multimodal interactions. The resulting connectivity pattern between maps encodes the correlation between sensory cues (e.g. a mapping from one cue to another) and can be used in the integration process. The proposed model is attractive for robotics applications in which sensor fusion schemes are usually hand crafted and dedicated to particular scenarios; thereby lacking flexibility and adaptation to new settings. The inherent learning/adaptation capabilities make the proposed model a promising candidate for sensor fusion applications targeting real-time robotics.
title: A model for development and emergence in multisensory integration

text: A key requirement for any system, including biological or man-made systems, is their ability to estimate physical properties of the real world through uncertain and partially reliable observations, to properly interact with their environment. The human brain can combine such noisy and partially reliable pieces of information to optimally estimate the state of the world and to consequently handle cognitive tasks efficiently [1]. Sensory cues do not have equal distributions of reliability over sensory space [2]. A less investigated issue in multi-sensory integration is how to encode and learn reliability of cues into spatially registered form of neural activity. In this work, we suggest a recurrent attractor network capable of learning arbitrary relations between one of the encoded sensory variables as a function of other variables using Hebbian Learning. In another point of view the attraction surface of the network’s dynamics is the same surface of the relation function through which the network realizes a relation satisfaction. We demonstrate that after constructing plastic weights, the network is able to perform inference and reasoning, de-noising, reliability based cue-integration and decision making [3]. This framework is well scalable for scenarios with higher order of modalities with acceptable flexibility to a wide range of smooth functions. Another important feature of the network is the possibility of spatially distributed reliability representations in form of neural activity. In fact, we can strengthen the encoded activity of stimuli according to their relative reliability; so that the network converges to the point on the relation surface closest to the initial points of more reliable cues. This reliability-based encoding biases the network’s dynamics in favor of more reliable cues, and realizes a near optimal sensory integration mechanism. To evaluate proposed network a multi-modal weighted cuing for a realistic heading estimation scenario is presented.
title: Multi-sensory cue integration with reliability encoding, using Line Attraction Dynamics

text:
We present a novel method for implementing Factor Graphs in a SpiNNaker Neural Computing System. The SpiNNaker (Spiking Neural Network Architecture) framework is a distributed computing system designed to simulate large spiking neural networks in real-time [1]. It is composed of multiple SpiNNaker chips in a toroidal network, allowing the simulation of thousands of artificial spiking neurons in real time. In this work however, we do not use SpiNNaker’s native mechanisms; but instead we use the abundant resources to implement population coding principles over a fully connected homogenous network for a different application: computing believe propagation on a Factor Graph [2]. We present a framework which utilizes available SpiNNaker resources to implement a discrete Factor Graph (FG); a graphical model for probabilistic inference. In a FG, each variable represents the current belief about a specific dynamic system's state, and exchanges information by sending messages to each other, to update the overall belief. In our view, this mechanism resembles brain style information processing, where overall performance emerges from concurrently communicating local computation of many individual units.
In this work we implement a FG on a SpiNNaker computing system and demonstrate its promising performance, especially compared against a PC-based implementation. Note that conventional PCs are particularly poor hardware matches to instantiate such distributed graphical networks. Our framework allows mapping and routing a FG on the SpiNNaker hardware using SpiNNaker’s event-based communication system. We provide an example application of the proposed framework in a real-world robotics scenario, resulting in 26.14 MFLOPS computation in only 30.5ms. We demonstrate that the framework seamlessly extends to map larger FG networks onto bigger SpiNNaker systems; turning it suitable for complex and challenging real-time cognitive intelligence tasks.
title: Discrete Factor Graph Using Simplified Population Coding on the SpiNNaker Neural Computing System

text:
Autonomous mobile robots need to incorporate a significant number of sensors to reliably plan and securely follow trajectories in partially unknown or dynamically changing environments. Rodents, in contrast, navigate remarkably well with a limited number of sensors, outperforming state-of-the-art engineered systems in terms of adaptability and employed computing resources. Consequently, the recent discovery of grid cells in the Entorhinal Cortex, assumed to perform path integration (Hafting et al. 2005), and of the pre-play of future Place Cells (Pfeiffer 2013) raise the question if understanding these mechanisms helps to improve navigation for autonomous robots.

A basic mechanism that is still not properly understood is grid realignment. The periodic spatial response of grid cells changes when place cells undergo remapping, which itself indicates a significant change in the animal’s environment. As the grid cells are one synapse upstream, they are assumed to be one source of inputs to place cells, and thus the cause for such remapping (Monaco 2011).

On the one hand, we assume that imposing a grid orientation based on visual cues is a key source of realignment. On the other hand, we assume that realignment itself is crucial to translate idiothetic motion information into a reliable allothetic path. In this work we demonstrate a model which is able to compensate for different idiothetic head direction estimates and compute an allothetic path integral. We adapted a recently published model (Couey et al. 2013) to incorporate various such idiothetic signals and validated the performance using simulations of virtual rats, closely resembling the movement statistics of real rodents.

The required connectivity from head direction cells to grid cells can be acquired using Hebbian Learning. The integration of different velocity inputs in the grid cell network may help to understand the parallel conduction of sensory integration and alignment for robotic real-world systems.
title: Grid cell realignment based on idiothetic head direction cues

text: The orienting response is an organism’s reaction to changes in its environment. It includes changes in gaze, attention, pupil dilation, and head-orienting circuits, in order to heighten perception and prepare for action. The frontal eye fields (FEF) are a part of the oculomotor system, and are known to be involved in the generation of voluntary saccadic eye movements and covert shifts in visuo-spatial attention. While microstimulation of the FEF can evoke saccadic gaze shifts, lower levels of stimulation current can evoke components of the orienting response, such as covert shifts in attention or neck muscle responses, without saccades. Based on recent results showing that pupil dilation can be evoked by such subsaccadic stimulation of the superior colliculus in primates or optic tectum of owls, we investigated the effects of subsaccadic FEF microstimulation on pupil dilation. A non-human primate performed a gap saccade task with a variable fixation epoch, in which we stimulated the right FEF with biphasic pulses (200ms, 300Hz). Pupil diameter of the left eye, as well as EMG activity in head turning neck muscles were measured throughout the task. In blocks of stimulation currents from 5-60 µA, we were able to evoke contralateral saccades ranging from 5-20° as well as saccadic and subsaccadic neck EMG responses. For subsaccadic stimulation trials, we found an increase in pupil dilation after stimulation, starting 200-250ms after stimulation onset. In addition, the level of the induced pupil response was positively correlated with increasing stimulation currents that were still below saccade threshold. Such increases were in line with the magnitude of evoked neck muscle activity. Our results imply a contribution of FEF to pupil dilation, presumably mediated through the superior colliculus. This suggests a potential substrate for linking high-level cognitive states to pupil dilation.
title: Subsaccadic microstimulation of the primate frontal eye fields induces pupil dilation

text:
Auditory stream segregation is the process whereby a complex sound mixture is perceptually partitioned into ‘streams’ that ideally reflect the individual signals making up the mixture. Signal elements that contain similar properties are typically grouped into the same stream while elements with different properties are assigned to different streams. Differences in each signal between the ears (binaural cues) provide one such set of properties, which are particularly valuable to unimpaired listeners when competing signals do not directly overlap in time (sequential segregation). The present study psychophysically investigated whether bilateral cochlear implant (BiCI) users can achieve similar sequential segregation benefits from binaural cues.

Six BiCI users were presented sequences of alternating ‘A’ and ‘B’ bursts that had either a ‘regular’ uniform timing structure, or an ‘irregular structure that was generated by applying delays to each ‘B’ burst of the regular sequence. 'B' burst delay thresholds that enabled rhythm irregularity detection were determined. The task was assumed to be more difficult if ‘A’ and ‘B’ were perceived as part of different streams. Therefore high thresholds were assumed to reflect increased stream segregation.
 
‘A’ was presented monaurally to a fixed mid-array electrode in the left ear. The ear of stimulation for ‘B’ was varied to be ipsilateral or contralateral to ‘A’, or diotic. The electrode of ‘B’ was also varied across the array. Results showed that thresholds for all three ear conditions were significantly different, and were lowest for the ipsilateral condition and highest for contralateral case. For the ipsilateral condition, average delay thresholds also increased as electrode separation between ‘A’ and ‘B’ increased. The results from the present study indicate that differences both across and within ears can be used to promote sequential separation of multiple auditory streams in bilateral CI.
title: Sequential Stream Segregation in Bilateral Cochlear Implant Users

text:
Phase-amplitude coupling (PAC) in field potential signals has received a great amount of attention recently. PAC represents the coupling between the power of high frequency oscillations (30-100 Hz) and the phase of low frequency oscillations (<12 Hz). However the measure by which it is calculated has some shortcomings.
Several methods have been proposed to measure PAC among which the Modulation Index (MI) (Tort et al., 2010) and the Mean Vector Length (Canolty et al., 2006) are the most frequent used approaches. They both normalize the PAC calculated for real signals to the PAC calculated by disrupting any phase relationship between low and high frequency oscillations. This is based on the assumption that random noise signals contain no PAC. We found this assumption incorrect and therefore propose a correction in the normalization process.
We calculated the probability distribution function (PDF) of the high frequency power (100-120 Hz) relative to the low frequency phase (5-13 Hz) in a large number of white noise signals. The resulting PDF was not uniform, i.e. there was a significant difference between the peak and trough of the PDF (p<<0.01). Therefore we propose a correction: in order to normalize the PAC value for a given real signal, one should first calculate the distribution of PAC values for a large number of random signals with the same length as the original signal and then normalize the real signal’s PAC to the distribution of random signals’ PACs using z-scoring.
We applied this new Coupling Index (CI) to a series of noise signals. The result did not contain any significant difference with 0 (p>0.05) suggesting that the new measure controls for any default PAC existing in real signals. However applying the original MI on noise signals leaded to values significantly greater than 0 (p<<0.01).
We proposed a new method for calculating PAC that allows to measure the physiological component of PAC by controlling for any PAC that is found in noise signals.
title: Normalization and correction of phase-amplitude coupling (PAC) in field potential signals

text:
Neural-network models of brain function often rely on the presence of noise [1,2]. To date, the biological origin of this noise remains unclear. In computer simulations and in neuromorphic hardware [3,4], the number of noise sources (random-number generators) is limited. In consequence, neurons in large functional network models have to share noise sources and are therefore correlated. In general, it is unclear how shared-noise correlations affect the performance of functional network models. Further, there is so far no solution to the problem of how a limited number of noise sources can supply a large number of functional units with uncorrelated noise.

Here, we demonstrate that the performance of two functional architectures, attractor networks [5] and neural Boltzmann machines [2], is substantially impaired by shared-noise correlations resulting from the finite size of the ensemble of noise sources. Further, we show that this problem can be overcome by replacing the finite ensemble of independent noise sources by a (finite) recurrent neural network. As shown recently, inhibitory feedback, abundant in biological neural networks, serves as a powerful decorrelation mechanism [6,7]: Shared-noise correlations are actively suppressed by the network dynamics. By exploiting this effect, the network performance is significantly improved. Hence, recurrent neural networks can serve as natural finite-size noise sources for functional neural networks, both in biological and in synthetic neuromorphic substrates.

title: Neural networks as sources of uncorrelated noise for functional neural architectures

text:
The theory of correlations in asynchronous networks of identical randomly connected neurons has been previously developed for both binary and spiking networks [1,2,3,4,5]. The theory for binary networks without delays predicts that, given mean activities and population sizes, average pairwise correlations are uniquely determined by the population-level effective connectivity matrix. Thus, diagonalizable effective connectivity matrices can in principle be reconstructed from the correlations [6]. Here, effective connectivity is the product of structural connectivity and susceptibility, which depends on the mean and variance of inputs. We show that under certain conditions a one-to-one relationship between effective connectivity and correlations also exists for networks of leaky integrate-and-fire neurons with exponential current-based synapses and delayed couplings. We verify theoretical predictions for both binary and spiking networks using NEST [7] simulations.

Our findings have implications for network scaling, i.e., the reduction in neuron and synapse numbers that is often performed to ease the computational burden of simulations. Correlation sizes scale inversely to network size, but their shape and population structure may be preserved. If these properties are important for the phenomena considered, e.g., in studies of spike-timing-dependent plasticity, the effective connectivity matrix should be invariant under downscaling. If neuronal susceptibility is unaltered, this means that synaptic weights must be inversely proportional to in-degrees. As stronger synapses increase the variance of intrinsic inputs, maintaining mean activities is achieved by reducing the variance of the external drive. This only works up to the point where the extrinsic variance vanishes, limiting the range of in-degrees and network sizes over which mean activities and correlation structure can simultaneously be preserved. Therefore, network size can only be reduced within narrow bounds.
title: One-to-one relationship between effective connectivity and correlations in asynchronous  networks

text:
A current challenge in neuroscience is identifying how and when brain areas coordinate to generate representations from sensory input, process them and eventually define actions. To find relevant epochs, it is customary in electrophysiology to relate behavioural state information (e.g. waking/sleep states, locomotion, or task execution phases) to LFP power in specific bands, occasionally supplementing this information with multi-unit activity. The relevant LFP spectral bands are generally pre-established according to prior knowledge. In the multivariate case, a growing number of combinations of LFP band power across recording points has to be considered, and it is unclear how to proceed in a structured manner.
 
Here, we segment multichannel LFP recordings using a fully unsupervised machine-learning approach: A hidden Markov chain with a multivariate autoregressive observation model. This HMM-MAR approach provides a full spectral (and cross-spectral) characterisation of the LFP, including Granger causality and phase information. It therefore enables multivariate automatic, unsupervised brain state discovery and characterisation of LFP recordings, and provides a segmentation mechanism to test hypotheses about circuit function. We show first promising results on multichannel data from the behaving mouse brain.
title: Automatic brain state discovery from multivariate LFP time series

text:
A major challenge in computational neuroscience is to derive neuronal network models that are on the one hand physiologically realistic, thus allowing reasonable inferences on their biological counterparts, yet on the other hand are still computationally tractable in terms of simulation time, fitting effort and mathematical analysis. Towards this goal, we constructed a computational network model of the PFC based on simple single neuron elements [1], yet equipped with highly realistic anatomy and close fitting of cellular and synaptic parameter distributions derived from an extensive data base of prefrontal in vitro and in vivo recordings. The resulting model was reasonably fast to simulate and fit to data, amenable to mean-field approaches, yet exhibiting a high degree of physiological validity, even in a predictive sense. 

Even without any tuning, the network model manages to reproduce a number of statistics extracted from in vivo data from awake behaving rats [2]. We tested to which extend this result is affected by the parameters of the model. The network showed robustness against small changes in all tested parameters, but the comparison with the in vivo data also allowed to constrain their range of admissible values. Most notably, it turned out to be important to use the full variability observed in the neuron parameters from the in vitro recordings. Using more homogeneous parameter distributions, as often assumed in network models, impaired the transmission of transient inputs to the network, which may contain information from other brain areas. These results highlight the importance of the diversity of neurons for the generation of realistic network dynamics.

In summary, we have generated a PFC network model which is biologically highly valid, yet still reasonably fast to simulate and fit, and can now be exploited to probe the impact of pharmacological or genetic conditions on network dynamics, and to model performance in PFC-dependent tasks.
title: Probing the limits of a detailed prefrontal cortex model based on physiologically derived cellular parameter distributions

text: Localization of function is a central tenet of neuroscience supported by years of lesion, imaging, pharmacological and electrophysiological experiments. One plausible derivative of this assumption is that neurons in a given brain area should exhibit different spiking statistics during tasks in which this area is assumed to be involved compared to tasks where it is not. Here we analyzed this idea in simultaneously recorded rodent medial prefrontal cortex (PFC) neurons during simple behaviors that are traditionally not considered PFC dependent versus the quintessential rat PFC dependent task, delayed alternation. We examined both various statistics and properties of the single-unit interspike-interval distributions (like measures of irregularity or auto-correlations) as well as measures of their joint activity (cross-correlations), using spike trains either as they were, or applying strict statistical criteria for separating stationary from non-stationary periods[1]. While under non-stationary conditions several statistics appeared to show a systematic dependency on task complexity, under stationary conditions the single unit statistics did not reveal any differences between delayed alternation and the other tasks considered to be PFC-independent. On the contrary, correlational patterns among units did significantly change with task context. After eliminating the delay period from the delayed alternation task, however, these differences disappear, suggesting that the correlational structure is changing primarily during these periods.
title: Statistical analysis of spiking activity in rat prefrontal cortex under stationary and non-stationary conditions

text:
Brain-computer interfaces (BCI) are mostly realized using the P300, motor imagery or steady-state visually evoked potentials (SSVEP) measured with the electroencephalogram (EEG) to control external devices. The EEG is measured non-invasively with electrodes mounted on the human scalp using conductive electrode gel for optimal impedance and data quality. But the usage of gel has also some disadvantages: long montage time, abrasion of the skin, need to clean the skin after the recording,… The gel based EEG acquisition limits also the frequent usage of BCI systems on a daily basis. Furthermore the usage of EEG electrode cables has disadvantages: pulling of cables on electrodes produces movements and artifacts, heavier load on head leads to tiredness and more electrode movements if the head is moved, longer experimental preparation time because the cables must be plugged in.
Therefore a wireless dry active electrode system and wireless gel based active electrode system were developed and compared to a wired gel and dry active electrodes based system. A total of 10 subjects performed BCI experiments. For the P300 BCI system the P300 response and the accuracy, for the SSVEP based BCI system the power spectrum and accuracy and for the motor imagery based BCI reactive frequency components, event-related desynchronization and accuracy were compared. 
The study showed that the new wireless dry and gel electrodes are able to pick up the corresponding frequency ranges of the EEG data for all three BCI approaches and to achieve better accuracies. The major advantages of the wireless systems (both gel and dry) are the fast montage, less movement artifacts, easier to use and higher comfort of the cap. The major additional advantages of the wireless dry system are that no abrasion and no need of cleaning the skin is required. Nevertheless dry electrodes are more sensitive to noise and therefore a careful montage is necessary which is much easier with the wireless system.
title: Brain-Computer Interfaces: Comparison of dry and gel based wireless EEG electrodes

text: Contour integration is an integral part of visual information processing requiring the combination of aligned edge configurations into coherent percepts. Human observers are efficient in detecting contours, reaching peak performances for stimulus presentation times of  ~100ms. Studies depicting these findings used flashed static stimuli, however, in nature we rarely encounter this situation. Rather, we observe visual scenes over time and develop a coherent picture taking into account dynamic changes. We investigated contour detection in dynamic stimuli comprising Gabor elements rotating at unique speeds and directions. Contours formed at a predefined time when a number of rotating Gabors reached a configuration of perfect alignment. Since contour integration is believed to be a pop-out process, we expected similar performances for brief and extended presentations. However, performance dropped from 83% to 65% for extended presentations, indicating that contour detection in prolonged dynamic scenes is more demanding. We quantified to what extent a location cue, a shape cue, and a combination of both, facilitates detection. For brief presentations single cues, and their combination, improved performance by 13%. For long presentations, single cues did not aid performance, but their combination led to an 11% improvement. These result patterns may be caused by physiological or cognitive mechanisms: Neural adaptation reducing activity in prolonged presentations may explain the lower performance in non-cue and single-cue conditions. Cognitively, the visual system might undergo a transition from a predominantly stimulus-driven analysis of a scene to a phase where attention is captured by particular features in a stimulus, thus making it difficult to focus on, and to detect, a newly emerging contour. Currently we are testing these hypotheses by comparing the experimental results to simulations of a contour integration model including attentional modulation.
title: Contour integration in dynamic scenes and selective attention

text: Once its development is completed the wiring of the peripheral nervous system cannot be modified anymore (Goldberg, 2003).  It is therefore of utmost importance that neurons form the correct connections during axon growth and yet variability can be observed experimentally during this developmental process. In order to find their targets axons react to specific combinations of guidance cues in their environment via cell receptors located on their growth cone, a highly dynamic structure at the tip of the axon.  Numerous of these cues have been characterised individually but their interactions and the mechanisms behind growth cone movement and its variability remain unclear (Mueller, 1999). We have created a stochastic model of growth cone navigation that simulates the cellular processes guiding growth cone turning and progress in response to guidance cues and that also captures its variability. We model each filopodioum as a membrane protrusion of the cytoskeleton with receptors that can measure the relative signal strength of his environment. Based on this input the filopodium grows or shrinks modelled by a stochastic linear kinetic reaction. We model stoichiometry of each receptor and assume it only influences the growth of the closest filopodium. Our growth cone models the stochastic nature of the path-finding mechanism and can therefore be used to analyse variability in axon growth. The parameters are fitted with biological data obtained from cortical and spinal commissural neurons in mice and rats that were cultivated on controlled nano-dot gradients of the signalling cue netrin-1. This experimental setup allows for a quantitative analysis of the neuron’s environment as compared to the usual gradients with diffusive cues.
title: Stochastic model of growth cone navigation and variability

text:
Most of our classical understanding of axons comes from large, easy to study axons such as the squid giant axon. However, basic physical principles dictate that as axons become thinner, the effect of each process happening over their membrane becomes larger. Recently, advances in both theoretical [1, 2] and experimental [3] methods have permitted us to gain valuable insight into the world of small axons. 

Active propagation of spikes requires an enormous amount of energy [4, 5, 6], which comes from the potential energy stored in ionic concentration gradients across cell membrane. This pool of energy is fuelled by ionic pumps and depleted by action potentials. In the many thin axon of the nervous system e.g. C-fi bres [7, 0.1 μm to 0.3 μm diameter], the amount of charge displaced could result in a noticeable change in concentrations and hence affect cell activity [8, 9].

We developed a Hodgkin-Huxley model where ionic concentrations are no longer constant by using Nernst Equations. Na+ and K+ currents due to ion channels and ionic pumps are used to update ionic concentrations inside and outside the cell. We show that, counter-intuitively, the rate of  firing at which an axon can  re indefi nitely is independent of diameter. Sustainable rates of  firing (for a given duration), however, do depend on axonal diameter. Using fi rst principles, we relate pump density, sustainable fi ring rate, fi ring duration, and diameter of axons. ATP supply also constraints the anatomy of axons, as the diffusion of ATP is dependent on the diameter. Using data from the resting state energy consumption several axon types, we derive an upper limit on the spacing of source of ATP.

Metabolic constraints limit miniaturization of nervous systems by imposing a lower limit on axonal diameter based on their function. Furthermore, the fi nite diffusion rate of ATP imposes constraints on the placement of sources of ATP, and suggests that glia cells may supply neurons with ATP.
title: Axon structure-function relationships from homeostatic constraints

text: Both common and independent synaptic inputs are delivered to α-motorneurons (MN) which discharge synchronously during isometric contractions [1]. In particular, the common synaptic input to the MN determines correlated output spike trains and, thus, significant peaks in the coherence spectrum at specific frequency bands [2]. This correlation has been demonstrated to be useful for the coordination of MN and for the optimization of motor performance especially for low contraction forces [3]. We hypothesize that the strength of correlation between MN spike trains should increase with force because of the greater number of synaptic projections involved at higher forces [4]. The aim of this study was to verify this hypothesis by estimating the strength of common synaptic input to MN via coherence analysis of motor unit spike trains. Ten healthy subjects performed isometric non-fatiguing contractions of the tibialis anterior muscle at two force levels: 20% (LL) and 75% (HL) of the maximal force. Surface EMG signals were recorded with a 64 electrode grid and decomposed into MU spike trains [5]. A total of 220 MU (LL: 24±6.3, HL: 19±5.7) were identified. The degree of correlation between spike trains was calculated by coherence analysis of the composite spike trains (CST) and the values obtained were converted to standard z scores. The coherence values increased with force in the δ-band (1-5 Hz) (P=0.04) and α-band (5-10 Hz) (P=0.01) but not in the β-band (10-30 Hz) (P=0.39).The coefficient of variation of force increased significantly and the EMG amplitude level increased significantly with the force level (P=0.001 and P==0.0004 respectively). These results indicate that the relative proportion of shared synaptic inputs with respect to the independent inputs to MNs is increasing as a function of the total synaptic current received by the MN pool. We believe that this phenomenon is due to the increased number of active shared projections among MNs at higher force levels.
title: The relative strength of common synaptic input to motorneurons increases with force.

text:
AIM: The aim was to improve the detection performance of movement related cortical potentials (MRCP) in EEG traces for brain-computer interface (BCI) applications. For this purpose, we apply a discriminative manifold learning method.
METHODS: Experimental data were collected as described in [1] on 12 healthy subjects. The subjects performed brisk ankle dorsiflexions in a cue-based paradigm in 4 conditions combining two speeds (slow and fast, S and F) and two force levels (low and moderate, 20% and 60% of maximum force). The EEG data were segmented into two classes: 1) signal intervals that contain MRCPs during motor imagination; and 2) noise signal intervals. We extract discriminative and locality preserving features of these two classes via a discriminative manifold learning method, called Locality Sensitive Discriminative Analysis (LSDA) [2]. A nearest-neighbor classifier was then applied to these features. The detection performance was evaluated on the experimental data and compared with the previously proposed Locality Preserving Projection (LPP) method [3].
RESULTS: Compared to LPP, LSDA achieved similar true positive rates (TPR) (F20:0.79±0.15 (LSDA) vs. 0.80±0.16 (LPP); F60:0.84±0.12 vs. 0.85±0.13; S20: 0.78±0.17 vs. 0.78±0.18; S60: 0.76±0.15 vs. 0.76±0.16). However, LSDA significantly reduced the false positive rate (FPR) (F20: 0.27±0.14 (LSDA) vs. 0.37±0.18 (LPP), p=0.007*; F60: 0.26±0.10 vs. 0.33±0.14, p=0.025*; S20: 0.36±0.18 vs. 0.41±0.18, p=0.013*; S60: 0.25±0.22 vs. 0.27±0.24, p=0.117). Fig. 1 provides the results for each subject averaged over the 4 conditions.
CONCLUSION: The results showed that the proposed application of LSDA for feature extraction outperformed LPP in MRCP detection because of a reduction in FPR. The method can be a promising candidate for developing closed-loop BCI neurorehabilitation systems based on MRCP detection.
title: Discriminative Manifold Learning Based Detection of Movement-Related Cortical Potentials for BCI Applications

text:
Alpha motor neurons (MNs) receive common synaptic inputs (CI) from spinal and supraspinal structures [1]. This generates significant level of correlation between motor unit (MU) spike trains (STs). The correct estimation of the CIs may provide information about the connectivity in the spinal cord [2]. Several indexes of correlation have been proposed, but they rely on correlation extracted from pairs of MN output STs, which is not linearly associated to the one in input [3,4].
In this study we propose a new index of correlation based on the estimation of the ratio between the strengths of the common and independent (IN) synaptic inputs to a population of MNs. Under the assumption of a weak CI, we estimated this ratio using the coherence values calculated from composite MN STs (CSTs) [4]. The performance of the method was tested using numerical simulations and experimental data.
The model had 300 MNs receiving CI and IN Gaussian synaptic inputs. Mean and variance of the current injected in each MN were selected to generate variable discharge rates and CoV for ISI (~15 %) [6] in a physiological range. In the experimental part, MN spike trains were extracted from iEMGs [7] recorded from the ADM muscle of 5 healthy subjects during an isometric contraction at 10 % MVC. Mean coherence values (1-5 Hz) were fitted using least squares method.
Results showed a linear association between the simulated and estimated proportions of CI ($Y=1.1*X–0.1$,P<0.0001). Conversely, the CIS [5] values were non-linearly related to the simulated proportion of CI. The sensitivity of the proposed index to changes in discharge rate was minimal, whereas the CIS showed a strong dependence on this factor. The experiments also showed a lower variability for the estimates provided by the new index compared with the CIS (~15 % vs 45 %).
In conclusion, our new index of correlation between populations of MN STs provides a more reliable estimate of the strength of CI than previously proposed methods.
title: A new index for the reliable estimation of common synaptic inputs to a population of  motor neurons in humans

text:
The recognition of body motion requires the temporal integration of information, which might be accomplished by recurrent networks that are composed from neurons with selectivity for body shapes in particular views [Giese2003]. The fact that body motion perception can be multi-stable [Vanrie2004] and shows adaptation [Jordan2006] suggests that such networks have non-trivial interesting dynamical properties. In order to study these properties mathematically, and as basis for the development of a unifying model for dynamic phenomena in action processing, we propose a neurodynamical model for action recognition. 

Methods: The model is based on a two-dimensional neural field [Amari1977] that encodes body postures and their corresponding views. A lateral interaction kernel that is asymmetric in the posture dimension results in a competition between different stimulus views, and makes the field selective for the temporal order of stimulus frames in action movies. The model includes a Gaussian noise process and a linear adaptation dynamics for each point of the field. The adaptation dynamics was fitted quantitatively to electrophysiological data from area IT [deBaene2010].  

Results: The model reproduces multistable perception for action stimuli that are consistent with multiple stimulus views [Vanrie2006]. It also accounts for the fact that repetition suppression effects in action-selective neurons are rather weak [Caggiano2013; Kilner2013]. The neural field predicts an interesting bifurcation dependent on the deviation of the rotation of a walker stimulus relative to the side view: for rotations angles below certain small degree the mutistablity of such stimuli should disappear, which is presently tested in psychophysical experiments.   

Conclusions: The proposed model captures a number of dynamic phenomena in action perception which cannot be accounted for by the existing models. In addition, it provides an elegant mathematical framework for their analysis.
title: Neurodynamical model for visual action recognition

text:
One of the most important subjects in neural science is to understand neural mechanism underlying in cognitive function. As neural activities of a large number of neurons can be recorded simultaneously during cognitive tasks, it is observed that not only stationary activated neural activity pattern, but also collective motion of neural activities that changes dynamically emerges during the tasks. These observations suggest that dynamic neural activity pattern, which is represented as trajectory in neural state space, underlies the decision-making process, motor control and other cognitive processes. It is believed that such neural trajectory is shaped through learning process during task training, however, how the trajectory is formed is not uncovered well. 
In this study, we analyze the formation of neural trajectory during training in a decision-making task, motivated by a characteristic and sequentially activated neural pattern recently observed in an auditory-motor decision making task, in which an rat has to push a different lever according to different frequency tone after some delay time.
For understanding such behavior, here, we adopt reservoir network, which corresponds to neural circuit in the cortex. Especially to implement learning process with delay time, we also recruit eligibility trace and reward-modulated Hebbian rule for biological plausibility, while ordinary reservoir computing modifies the synaptic efficacy in on-line way. 
Under this setting, we analyze the neural behavior that is formed through the learning process and demonstrate that log-normal distribution of synaptic efficacy and multiple time-scale in synaptic change play an important role in stable learning. Further, distinct sequential neural activity patterns depending on the external inputs emerge during the learning process, which are similar to the neural behavior observed in the experimental study.
title: A reservoir computing model for prefrontal activity during sensory-guided probabilistic decision-making

text:
Signal processing in the brain is performed by interacting groups of spiking neurons. Most neuron types show spike-frequency adaptation, and finite group size gives rise to fluctuations of the averaged population activity. We have recently developed a theory for the population dynamics of such systems [1, 2]. Here we apply this theory to study how input signals are passed through a chain of populations of excitatory and inhibitory neurons.

The mutual information rate between input signal and network response is related to the spectral coherence of the two. We derive the coherences of population activities and inputs in a multi-population network of adapting neurons, where the inputs are injected to an arbitrary subset of neural populations. 

Contrary to the case of a single population we find that network interactions and adaptation do shape the spectral coherence as the inputs are propagated through the network. Our results show how, at the population level, both neuronal adaptation and the gross anatomical organization of cortical networks into layers and modules contribute to information processing.
title: Signal processing in coupled populations of spiking neurons with adaptation

text:
Recurrent neuronal networks with bistable dynamics have been proposed as a plausible implementation for short-term memory and decision-making [1,2]. External stimuli can put the recurrently connected population into either a persistent high-activity or into a low-activity state. Here we analyze the response of bistable networks to time-dependent inputs.

Most previous modeling studies used simple step inputs. However, spike-timing has been shown to be relevant in the prefrontal cortex during memory-demanding tasks [3]. Although a few simulation studies show that temporal input modulation influences the dynamics of bistable networks [4], a more thorough understanding of their response properties -- and of how the network's response relates to the single-neuron characteristics -- could be reached through mathematical analysis.

We studied the response of bistable networks of adapting neurons to temporally modulated stimuli with a mean-field approach and found that these networks can behave like damped oscillators. Therefore, such networks are sensitive to periodic inputs in a specific frequency range, depending on the adaptation properties of single neurons and on the firing history of the network. Hence the temporal structure of the input is a functionally relevant feature determining how efficient and selective the stimulation is.
The employed mean-field equations describe recurrent networks of Generalized Linear Model neurons, which can be fitted to data and can predict the response of cortical neurons to time-varying input [5]. Therefore, our results rely on plausible neuronal dynamics under certain assumptions, and can lead to testable predictions of the adequate input frequency provided prefrontal cortex parameters are used. Our work argues for the relevance of temporal codes for  cognitive function, which had been challenged given the chaotic dynamics of recurrent spiking neural networks, and explains how time-dependent inputs can enrich network function.
title: Control of adapting bistable attractor networks by temporally structured inputs

text:
Perception of own actions is influenced by visual information and predictions from internal forward models [1]. Integrating these information sources depends critically on whether visual consequences are associated with one's own action (sense of agency) or with changes in the external world unrelated to the action [2] and the accuracy of integrated signals [3]. Attribution of percepts to consequences of own actions depends thus on the consistency between internally predicted and actual visual signals. 
However, is the attribution of agency rather a binary decision (‘I did, or did not cause the visual consequences of the action’ [4]), or is this process based on a more gradual attribution of the degree of agency? Both alternatives result in different behaviors of causal inference models, which we try to distinguish by model comparison.

METHODS. We used a virtual-reality setup to manipulate the consistency between pointing movements and their visual consequences. We investigated the influence of this manipulation on self-action perception. 
We compared two Bayesian causal inference models to the experimental data, one with a binary latent agency variable [2], and one with a continuous latent agency variable [4]. 
Here, subject-specific regions for stimulus conditions that maximally differentiate between the two models were identified online using Active Sampling methods [6] to evaluate relative model evidences with a small number of samples. 

RESULTS/CONCLUSION. Both models correctly predict the data, and specifically empirical agency ratings showing high attribution of agency for small deviations between sensory and predicted feedback. Some participants show signatures of a binary internal representation of agency. In addition, relationships with other inference models [5] are discussed.
title: Agency Attribution in Goal-Directed Actions: Active Sampling Improving Bayesian Model Comparison

text:
There are numerous algorithms for detection and classification of spikes in extracellular recordings [1]. However, it is still a demanding task to detect spikes in low signal-to-noise ratios (SNR). We design a spike detection algorithm based on fractal properties of extracellular signals and name it fractal detector. We show that it is an efficient detector in low SNR regimes.
In fractal detector, the extracted segments of the signal are normalized and then, fractal dimension of each segment is evaluated. Fractal dimension is an extension of Euclidean dimension which measures the irregularity of the signal and has found many applications in signal processing [2,3]. Here, we use it to distinguish between spike and noise segments in extracellular signals.
In order to evaluate the performance of a spike detection algorithm, prior knowledge of spike timings is required. Therefore, instead of using experimental data, we simulate extracellular signals using proper spike and noise models. The performance of fractal detector is compared with three common detectors: threshold detector [4], wavelet-PCA detector [5], and average matched filter detector [6]. 

In the following, we summarize the results of this study:

1-	It is shown that extracellular signals are fractal signals and can be used for fractal analysis. 
2-	We evaluate the histogram of fractal dimension for spike and noise segments and prove that the average of fractal dimension for spike segments is significantly smaller than that of noise segments. Therefore, fractal dimension is an efficient feature for spike detection.
3-	In low SNR regimes, it is demonstrated that fractal detector results in the highest detection probability among the 4 detectors (see the attached figure). 
4-	We show that the performance of fractal detector is independent of inter-spike noise power, while the performance of other detectors degrades rapidly by increasing the power of inter-spike noise.
title: Application of Fractal Geometry to the Detection of Spikes in Low SNR Extracellular Signals

text:
Reinforcement learning (RL) has become the predominant model for predicting a subject’s decision based on the expected reward value (EV) of each cue, which is adjusted during learning in proportion to a reward prediction error (PE). Common experimental setup utilizes value-neutral cues to study EVs in isolation. However, most environmental cues representing decision options are not neutral but exhibit values intrinsically (e.g. attractive faces), which may interfere with the acquisition of new EVs. This project investigates how such inherent cue value affect the learning of new EV. One possibility is that congruent cue-outcome association with similar inherent value and EV yields faster learning rate (LR) than incongruent pairing.
We tested the hypothesis in a 2x2 factorial design, using facial attractiveness (high/low) as a proxy for inherent value and reward probability (0.7/0.3) as a target for learned EV. Subjects were shown  attractive and unattractive face pictures of the opposite gender. Each picture was paired with monetary reward or penalty either congruently or incongruently. Subjects were instructed to select the pictures with the goal of maximizing the overall monetary reward. RL models were fitted to behavioral data using hierarchical Bayesian analysis to derive cue-specific LRs. Concurrent fMRI data were correlated with these LRs, EVs, and PEs.
Behavioral results indicated both faster response time and faster LR for the congruent cue-outcome pairing. Model-based fMRI analyses revealed that several signals derived from the RL model (LRs, PEs, outcomes) populate the ventral striatum (vStr) in distinct locations. An additional connectivity analysis revealed a functional link between the vStr (encoding LR and PE) and the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (encoding EV). These findings suggest that value congruency leads to a distinct advantage in learning new reward associations and uncover the functional neural architecture supporting this learning process.
title: Congruency between inherent and learned expected values facilitates the acquisition of new reward associations

text:
It is well known that the human brain carries two separable, but interacting learning systems: A Pavlovian system learning stimulus-outcome associations, and an instrumental system learning response-outcome associations. The interaction of these systems is demonstrated during Pavlovian-to-Instrumental Transfer (PIT), in which instrumental behavior is increased or reduced depending on the presence of a stimulus learned through Pavlovian association. It is assumed that the neurotransmitters serotonin and dopamine modulate the processing and behavioral influence of stimuli with appetitive or aversive valence. However, it is largely unknown how they affect the interaction of Pavlovian and instrumental learning systems. 
To investigate the effects of serotonin and dopamine on appetitive and aversive motivation, we developed a novel general PIT task which separately assesses the motivating and demotivating role of previously learned Pavlovian associations on independent instrumental behavior in humans. We reduced central serotonin and dopamine levels by using dietary depletion of tryptophan (n=34) and tyrosine/phenylalanine (n=35), respectively, and compared this to a control group (n=34).
We found both appetitive and aversive general PIT, i.e. subjects responded more vigorously in a positively associated context and less vigorously in a negatively associated context. Aversive PIT was stronger in the serotonin group, and appetitive PIT was reduced in the dopamine group.
These results demonstrate that serotonin and dopamine are differently involved in motivated behavior: While serotonin serves to reduce the motivational influence of aversive stimuli, dopamine seems to enhance the influence of appetitive stimuli. Together, the results shed light on the involvement of serotonin and dopamine in guiding motivated behavior.
title: The appetitive and aversive motivational impact of serotonin and dopamine on instrumental behavior

text: In the brain, interaction among neurons lead to complex patterns and collective behaviors such as phase transitions, brain rhythms, self-organization, and neuronal avalanches. However, despite a significant progress, understanding of collective phenomena and bifurcation mechanisms of phase transitions in the brain still remain elusive. Using an exactly solvable cortical model of neuronal networks with stochastic excitatory and inhibitory neurons, we study collective phenomena and precursors of phase transitions observed in vitro or in vivo brain. We find that, with increasing the intensity of shot noise (a flow of random spikes bombarding neurons), the neuronal network undergoes nonequilibrium first- and second-order phase transitions. Spontaneous neuronal activity preceding the transition is a characteristic property that can be used to identify the type of the transition and the bifurcation mechanism in real neuronal network. We show that bursts, sharp spikes, spindles, and avalanches of neuronal activity are precursors of the transitions. Our most interesting result is the observation of the paroxysmal-like spikes, which are strongly nonlinear events in neuronal activity generated by fluctuations, similar to epileptiform EEG activity. We demonstrate that the power spectral density (PSD) of spontaneous neuronal activity gives a rich information about the kind of bifurcation and the closeness of the network to the critical point. Recent studies of the stochastic resonance, bandpass filter, and berger effect are discussed for practical applications of PSD. Our analysis also shows that above a saddle-node bifurcation, sustained network oscillations appear with a large amplitude but a small frequency in contrast to the network oscillations near a supercritical Hopf bifurcation that have a small amplitude but a large frequency.
title: Phase transitions and critical fluctuations in neuronal networks

text: Cortical neurons in vivo fire irregularly. Previous studies about the origin of such irregular neural dynamics have given rise to two major models: a balanced excitation and inhibition model, and a model of highly synchronized synaptic inputs. To elucidate the network mechanisms underlying synchronized synaptic inputs and account for irregular neural dynamics, we investigate a spatially-extended, conductance-based spiking neural network model. We show that propagating wave patterns with complex dynamics emerge from the network model. These waves sweep past neurons, to which they provide highly synchronized synaptic inputs. These waves only occur when there is a balance between excitatory and inhibitory inputs, reconciling the two major models of irregular neural dynamics. The resultant distributions of membrane potential are shown to be non-Gaussian, which is consistent with recent experimental data obtained by using whole-cell recordings. We further demonstrate that the collective dynamics of propagating wave patterns provides a mechanistic explanation for "doubly stochastic" slow firing rate fluctuations in addition to fast spike timing variability. Our work therefore relates the propagating waves that have been widely observed in the brain to irregular neural dynamics. These results demonstrate that neural firing activity, while appearing highly disordered at the single-neuron level, can form dynamical coherent structures such as propagating waves at the population level.
title: Propagating waves as a mechanism for irregular neural dynamics in mammalian cortex

text: Recent studies have reported layer specificity of dynamical properties of ongoing neuronal activities in various cortical areas [1-3]. A common observation is that activities in the infra-granular layers exhibit pronounced slow oscillations (< 20 Hz). Among visual cortices, the layer specificity has been extensively studied for the primary visual cortex but remains largely unknown for other areas. To elucidate the laminar organization of ongoing neural activities and its functional relevance in visual object recognition, we examined spatio-temporal patterns of local field potentials (LFPs) recorded from the inferior temporal cortex of analgesized macaques using linear electrode arrays (32 probes spanning 1.55 or 3.1 mm across cortical layers). During the recordings the animals were presented with 128 visual objects (shapes, gratings, faces, fruits, etc.) on a gray background. Stimulus duration was 0.5 s with an inter-stimulus interval (ISI) of 1 s. We found that during the ISIs the LFPs showed strong oscillatory fluctuations in the alpha-beta frequency band (10 – 20 Hz). These oscillations had the strongest power in the lowermost probes, supposedly located in infra-granular layers. These LFP oscillations were considerably suppressed during the stimulus presentation period. In the initial ~0.3 s of stimulus presentation the LFPs showed a stimulus-evoked excitatory modulation that first occurred in deep layers and then propagated to the superficial layers (see Figure). The spatio-temporal patterns of the LFP modulations were specific to the presented stimuli. The observed suppression of ongoing oscillations during stimulation period is consistent with the reported quenching of inter-trial variability by stimulus onset [4], which was argued as a mechanism to enhance reliability of stimulus processing. We will discuss the role of such a mechanism in IT cortex and its implications to the object selective activities that propagate across cortical layers.
title: Layer specificity of ongoing and evoked neuronal activities in the inferior temporal cortex of macaque monkeys

text:
Background
The GPU enhanced Neuronal Networks (GeNN) framework [1,2] was introduced in 2011 to facilitate the efficient use of graphical processing units (GPUs) as accelerators for neuronal network simulations. GeNN is based on code generation for the NVIDIA CUDA application programming interface. Code generation provides decisive advantages: (i) code can be optimized both for every individual model and for the specific GPU hardware detected at compile time, and (ii) code generation allows to support a practically limitless number of pre-defined models, as well as user-defined models, while the generated simulation code remains as small and efficient as possible.
While GeNN is an important step towards facilitating the use of GPU acceleration for computational neuroscience applications it has been designed with expert users in mind. In this work we are aiming to make GeNN also available to non-expert users by providing two new interfaces from SpineCreator [3]/SpineML [4] and the Brian 2 simulator [5,6] to GeNN.

Results
We have created prototype interfaces from SpineCreator using the SpineML markup language and from Brian 2 by modifying the code generation facilities within Brian 2 to generate valid GeNN input files. In both cases, a middleware was created that takes the model descriptions that were either available in SpineML (as generated by SpineCreator) or the internal representation in Brian 2 and translate them into code parts necessary to run a GeNN simulation. The SpineML interface is in alpha testing while the Brian 2 interface is at the stage of proof of concept.
We believe that when the new SpineCreator and Brian 2 interfaces will have been fully developed, tested and released we can make a decisive difference in the uptake of GPU acceleration for neuronal network simulations. The completed prototypes show sufficient flexibility and ease of use to be appealing to a wide range of future users.
title: SpineML and Brian 2.0 interfaces for using GPU enhanced Neuronal Networks (GeNN)

references.text: Bernacchia, A., Seo, H., Lee, D. & Wang, X.-J. Nature Neuroscience 14, 366-372 (2011)

text:
It has been proposed that one fundamental task accomplished by the brain is to encode sensory stimuli efficiently. This view is supported by the observation that neural activity in sensory areas maximize information transmission. However, most of those observations have been obtained in subjects that are anesthetized, passive, or engaged in tasks that do not require cognitive functions such as memory and decision-making. It remains unclear whether the principle of efficient coding applies to higher brain regions, such as the prefrontal cortex, while subjects are involved in cognitive tasks.

We study the response of 681 (non-sensory) cortical neurons to reward events during strategic decision-making in primates. We showed previously that the dynamics of those responses is highly heterogeneous and spans two orders of magnitude, from 100ms to 10s [1]. We hypothesize that this variety of responses is a consequence of efficient coding. We build a model of a neural circuit, and we compute the synaptic matrix that maximizes information transmission. We show that the model matches the experimental observations in terms of both the marginal and the joint statistics of timescales and amplitudes of the neural responses.

Our results suggest that the efficient coding hypothesis predicts not only the spatial properties of neural response (e.g. receptive fields), but also its temporal properties, on a broad range of timescales, and it can be applied to non-sensory areas. While the efficient coding hypothesis predicts maximum information, it does not address the question of how this information is used. Future work will focus on the question of how efficient coding of reward is used for decision-making, with the overarching goal of bridging the gap between sensory coding and behavior.
title: Efficient coding of rewards in strategic decision-making

text:
Maximum information has been proposed as a principle for neural coding. A few neural circuit models that implement maximum information have been proposed, but most of them are biologically implausible or they are unable to reproduce basic physiological observations. 

Among the many facets of maximum information, we focus on decorrelation, the reduction of correlations across neuron pairs. Several mechanisms have been proposed for decorrelation in neural circuits. One mechanism is inhibitory feedback, which is well supported by experimental testing [1,2]. However, it does not explain the development of neural coding for sensory stimuli. Another mechanism is anti-Hebbian plasticity, which explains neural circuit development but is not experimentally supported [3] and it cannot maintain any memory of the input stimuli [4].

We introduce a biologically realistic synaptic plasticity rule based on STDP. We show that this rule can enable the system to sense both the spatial and temporal properties of inputs and decorrelate the sensory inputs. Furthermore, it maintains the memory of those inputs on arbitrary timescales. The model is able to account for a wide range of physiological observations, including balanced excitatory and inhibitory currents, the long-tailed and non-random distribution of synaptic strengths [5,6]. Interestingly, both the distribution of synapses and the balanced state have a strong influence on the decorrelation process. The simultaneous properties of maximum information and multi-scale memory make the model a candidate for efficient neural computation.
title: Synaptic plasticity maximizes information in recurrent neural circuits

text:
The information of the stimulus variable $S$ in a population of $n$ observed neurons $R_0 \ldots R_n$ can be measured using the mutual information $I(S:R_0 \ldots R_n)$. In order to gain a deeper understanding about the stimulus encoding in the neural population the question arises how to decompose the mutual information. A decomposition may reveal sets of neurons that share the same information about the stimulus, or sets of neurons that encode information synergistically or a single neurons that may encode information about the stimulus that is not present in any of the other observed neurons.

There are several properties that seem obviously necessary to hold for a mutual information decomposition. But these properties alone do not provide enough constraints to result in a unique solution and it is not clear how to resolve for this ambiguity. Several approaches have been suggested recently ([Williams2010], [Harder2013], [Griffith2014]) but we find that all of them suffer from certain caveats.

Here, we introduce a new approach how to decompose the mutual information of two different neural populations with a stimulus into independent, unique, and synergistic components. We demonstrate its strength compared to previously proposed decompositions and present several examples that corroborate its usefulness. In particular, we believe the decomposition can serve as a useful relaxation to the problem of causality estimation.
title: Information theoretic analysis of neural populations

text:
How do sensory systems extract meaningful information from complex signals in the environment? To address this question, one can start from the observation that sensory signals tend to vary at a fast timescale compared to the source of these signals in the environment. For example, the physical location of a sound source varies more slowly than the acoustical pressure. This has led several authors to propose statistical learning algorithms that extract slowly varying features of sensory signals [Wiskott et al, 2002], which is also related to psychological theories according to which the basis of perception is the “invariant structure” of the sensory (or sensorimotor) signals [Gibson, 1986]. Sprekeler et al. [Sprekeler et al, 2007] have shown how Slow Feature Analysis (SFA) can be implemented with rate-based neuron models, in a way that is consistent with known experimental facts on synaptic plasticity. However, no practical implementation of this concept has been made with biophysical neuron models.

	In this work, we show both mathematically and with simulations of spiking neurons how an optimization criterion derived from slowness can be implemented by neurons, and we apply this in the context of auditory signals. Using the post-synaptic voltage as a target for the slowness criterion, and similarly to what has already been done in [Rozell et al, 2008] for sparseness, we used the internal dynamics of integrate-and-fire neurons to perform an on-line optimization of our objective function. We show that spiking neurons can encode, in their subthreshold dynamics, the slowly time-varying components of their inputs, with synaptic learning rules compatible with known experimental facts on plasticity.
title: Slow Feature Analysis with spiking neurons

text:
Interaural Level Difference (ILD) provides an important cue for the location of a sound source in the azimuthal plane. ILD coding in the brainstem is usually modeled using a rate code in the lateral superior olive (LSO) [1–3]. In these models, the number of inhibitory post-synaptic potentials (PSPs) over a given period of time is effectively subtracted from the number of excitatory PSPs over the same period.  The spike rate of the LSO cell is then proportional to the result. 

Recent experimental evidence from the medial superior olive shows that inhibition may play a role in modulating the delays of excitatory post-synaptic potentials [4]. LSO cells in mammals receive inhibitory input from the same source. We hypothesize that inhibition may play a related but different role in LSO cells, modulating the amplitude of excitatory post synaptic potentials, delaying the production of action potentials. This would provide a spike timing cue for ILD at the level of the inferior colliculus. It is important to note that these spike-timing cues would be initiated in the ILD encoding cells, and timing cues for sound level may be absent from the inputs to the LSO.

In this study, the auditory periphery was modeled as a gammatone filterbank which provided inputs directly to a leaky integrate-and-fire model representing the cells of the cochlear nucleus. These cells are known to lock to the envelope of the sound stimulus, and this behavior was recreated by low-pass filtering of the gammatone filterbank inputs to the cells, and use of a dynamic spike threshold mechanism [5]. The LSO cells and IC cells were both modeled as simple leaky integrate-and-fire neurons. The model was able to recreate the modulation of spike timing by inhibition in the LSO and the variation of this effect with sound source intensity. The model also recreated the potential ‘decoding’ of this cue by cells of the IC.
title: Inhibition influences the timing of action potentials in a model of the lateral superior olive

text:
In primary visual cortex (V1), fast-spiking parvalbumin positive interneurons (PV+ INs) constitute the largest neuronal population mediating GABAergic inhibition and modulate tuning properties of excitatory cells, such as selectivity for stimulus orientation, contrast and size. Like pyramidal cells, PV+ INs receive excitatory input through glutamate receptors, the disruption of which has been implicated in impairments of visual feature integration and figure-ground segregation. Here we examined the impact of NMDA-glutamate receptor ablation in PV+ INs on visual information processing.

We generated transgenic mice lacking NMDA receptors in PV+ INs (NR1-PVCre-/- Korotkova et al., 2010). We recorded V1 extracellular activity of head-fixed, transgenic and littermate control mice placed on a Styrofoam ball. We assessed spatial integration by measuring size tuning curves with gratings of different diameters, and we measured selectivity for orientation and contrast with full-field gratings.

We first compared overall neural activity, and found that both baseline and peak firing rates were largely similar between genotypes. We next tested the role of NMDA receptors in PV+ INs for spatial integration. Compared to control mice, V1 cells in NR1-PVCre-/- mice had smaller receptive field center sizes and stronger surround suppression. This difference in spatial integration persisted even after equating for differences in locomotion parameters.

Since previous studies suggested that PV+ INs might shape spatial integration via contrast gain control mechanisms, we also investigated whether NMDA receptors in PV+ INs contributed to contrast sensitivity. Compared to control mice, V1 cells in NR1-PVCre-/- had higher sensitivity for stimulus contrast, which could, at least partly, mediate sharper tuning for stimulus size.

We conclude that NMDA transmission in PV+ INs shapes selectivity of neighboring pyramidal cells for stimulus size, possibly via mechanisms of contrast gain control.
title: NMDA receptors in parvalbumin interneurons contribute to visual information processing in mouse V1

text:
Neuroscientific researches on information processing in the brain have gained sufficient knowledge to build simple computational models, which simulate neuronal behaviour. Especially visual attention has been focus of investigation to a lot of research areas. 
However, there are still only a few applications that make use of the potential of neurobiological findings, although this could lead to a new generation of technical systems, which can exceed the capabilities of state-of-the-art systems. We aim to close this gap by focusing on the functional body of the neuronal information processing to enable fast and efficient technical applications.

Recently, we presented sampled template collation - a novel method for generating saliency maps. The salient regions are calculated comparing randomly sampled templates over an image using a higher order metric. A templates' saliency score is calculated comparing light and color in the Lab* color space using a L2-norm and the template's entropy. Our method showed similar results as state-of-the-art visual attention systems yet being scalable for real-time applications.

We enhanced our method for object segmentation by following the neural mechanism of object-based selection in the visual cortex. The activity patterns in early visual areas are strongly biased in favor of the attended object [Cohen et al, 2013]. We are using the same underlying principles of sampled template collation for enabling object-based attention in our system. At the maximum salient point in the image, we sample a seed template to which all later sampled templates are compared to using a similar similarity metric as for the visual attention step. The response is a object-based attentional map which is highly biased towards the original seed template and can be used for further processing as segmentation or object recognition.
title: Sampled Template Collation for Simulating Visual Attention and Object-Based Selection.

text:
With only 302 neurons [1], C. elegans exhibits remarkably rich learning.
In particular, its sensory neurons exhibit distinct forms of associative and non-associative learning that depend on the neuron in question, on the stimulus and on the protocols used [2-5]. Such extensive processing inevitably leads to a filtering of information about the environment. We ask how the animalʼs natural environment is encoded in the nervous system and how this encoding generates appropriate responses.
C. elegans senses attractive NaCl concentrations predominantly with one pair of neurons, ASEL and ASER, that respond to NaCl concentration increases and decreases respectively. We measured these responses using calcium imaging and found distinct forms of adaptation in the left (ASEL) and right (ASER) neurons: ASEL desensitized following pre-exposure to sodium chloride; ASER sensitized with pre-exposure.
To explore the behavioral consequences of this sensory adaptation, we created a computational model and simulated animals with and without adaptation in ASEL and ASER in a variety of different virtual environments. We found that ASEL adaptation is best described by an additive form of threshold modulation. We demonstrate the advantages and disadvantages of such a mechanism in navigating smooth gradients; complex spaces including steep gradients separating large homogeneous areas; and regions with fluctuating concentration fields.
In contrast, we found that a multiplicative function best captures physiological data on ASER adaptation. Consequently, the rate of adaptation encodes the stimulus history including the pre-exposure concentrations and durations. Simulating worms in virtual arenas with salt patches of varying size and concentration, animals spent more time in larger, high concentration patches while ignoring smaller regions of salt.
Thus we predict that cell-autonomous adaptation in the ASER sensory neuron has the potential to underpin a rudimentary form of spatial memory.
title: Sensory neuron adaptation as a proxy for spatial memory in the nematode C. elegans
