text: Sensor fusion is crucial for all physical systems, given noisy and possibly conflicting sensory data. Such sensory fusion allows extracting reliable information from the local environment and building an internal spatial representation [1]. Amongst other quantities the estimation of ego-motion is important to keep the external state (i.e. environmental information) and the organism’s internal state coherent [2]. Due to the multimodal nature of incoming streams of sensory information, ego-motion estimation is a challenging sensor fusion problem. In this work we present a distributed cortically inspired processing scheme for sensor fusion [3]. It processes various sensory inputs, maintains simple relations defining inter-sensory dependencies, and ultimately relaxes into a solution which provides a plausible interpretation of the perceived ego-motion. Without precise modeling and parametrization of the system, our model is able to combine information from multiple sensors into a globally consistent estimate, which is more precise than individual  estimates. Balancing contributions of external sensors with its internal belief, our network is able to detect and compensate for sensor inconsistencies. The proposed model has been implemented for ego-motion estimation on an autonomous mobile robot. We demonstrate that the model provides a precise estimate of both robot position and orientation, comparable with optimal state-of-the-art sensor methods [4].
title: Multimodal sensor fusion network for mobile robot egomotion estimation

text:
Motion detection is an essential and basic feat of any natural vision system. The speed and efficiency found in natural systems is hard to match by engineered artifacts. The limiting factors are slow frame-based cameras on the one hand, and computationally costly data-processing on sequential computers on the other hand. We circumvent both by utilizing novel, neuromorphic technologies. 

We construct biologically inspired motion detectors using a silicon retina and a neuromorphic computer. The silicon retina (DVS[1]) is an event-based camera in which each pixel asynchronously reports a locally perceived change in luminosity. A specially developed interface [2] processes these events and passes them as virtual neural spikes into SpiNNaker [3]. A spiking neural network on SpiNNaker receives these spikes and detects motion based on the Barlow-Levick or Reichardt-Hassenstein schemes, which are considered to be the basis for motion detection in both insects [4] and mammals [5]. 
The perceived motion can be used to visualize an optic flow map on a host PC or to control a mobile robot, on which the DVS is mounted.

The unique combination of an asynchronous event-based vision sensor (DVS) with microsecond accuracy and a massively parallel neuromorphic computer (SpiNNaker) enables high estimation precision and low latency for possible high-speed closed-loop control of engineered systems. 

Future algorithmic developments will interpret the perceived optic flow vector field in real time to (a) reliably extract ego-motion, to (b) perform object/background segmentation, and to (c) recognize gestures in man-machine interfaces for robot control.
title: Bio-inspired optic flow detection using neuromorphic hardware

text:
For many decades cell assemblies have been suggested as the crucial neuro-computational or representational unit underlying behavioral processes as diverse as memory retrieval, planning, decision making, or object recognition. Multiple hypotheses have been advanced on the exact nature of neural activity organization within assemblies. Assemblies have been defined by the exactly synchronized spiking times within a collection of neurons, by precise temporal relations within sequences of spiking patterns, by temporally ordered patterns of firing rate or bursting activity, or much more generally just by a common increase of the firing rates within a set of neurons. 
Thanks to recent advances in electrophysiological techniques for recording multiple single units (MSU) simultaneously, it is now possible to test and investigate this key concept from an experimental point of view. In our work we propose a novel, simple, and comparatively fast method for detecting cell assemblies from MSU recordings at various levels of organization, i.e. accommodating different of the cell assembly definitions that have been advanced. It is based on the occurrence frequencies of firing, or spiking, patterns with different temporal resolutions whose significance is assessed through simple chi-square-based statistics. 
Compared to other detection methods present in literature, which are often designed based on a specific definition of cell assembly structure, our method is able to detect assemblies according to different possible definitions, and within relatively short time. It returns information on both the precise composition of the detected assemblies as well as their temporal structure. Here we present its validation on simulated data as well as its application to experimental data.
title: Detecting Cell Assemblies In-Vivo

text:
Olfactory Receptor Neurons (ORNs) respond to odor stimuli with temporal patterns of activity that depend on odor identity, odor concentration and receptor type. We performed measurements of the activity of single ORNs in Drosophila and analyzed these temporal patterns taking in account a precise quantification of the time dependent stimulus. We found that the dynamics of the odor stimulus itself depends on odor identity and concentration and that it strongly modulates the ORN response. We were able to assign a single response function to a single ORN and to predict the response of this ORN to two different odors solely from measurements of the stimulus. We also found that ORN adaptation capabilities maintain response dynamics remarkably similar across a large range of stimulus and background intensities (Martelli, 2013). 
These results suggest that ORN response properties enable the olfactory system to capture information about stimulus independently from its intensity. In order to investigate this hypothesis we developed a computational model of the Drosophila Antennal Lobe (AL), the first synaptic processing center of olfactory information. Our simulation includes three neuron populations: ORNs, inhibitory Local Neurons (LN) and output Projection Neurons (PNs). The model reproduces known static properties of the AL (the divisive normalization, Olsen 2010) while providing temporal resolution on the activity of the single neurons. We investigate how dynamical properties of the input ORN activity affect the encoding of single odorants and odor mixtures in the population of PNs.
title: Temporal processing of odor stimuli from Olfactory Receptor Neurons to Projection Neurons

text: Sensory signals are known to be selectively routed throughout the brain. This is particularly evident in the visual system during selective attention. In area V4 of the visual cortex, neurons with several stimuli in their receptive field exhibit behavior as though only the attended stimulus is present. A possible explanation for this effect revolves around gamma rhythm (60-80Hz) phase-locking between lower and higher visual areas. When the attended stimulus activates one V1 site, its gamma oscillations synchronize to the pertinent site in V4, thus facilitating information transfer ("communication through coherence", CTC). However, it is still not certain whether this synchronization is in fact causally involved in the information gating mechanisms. To explore the CTC hypothesis, a model has been developed that reproduces these experimental results. It consists of populations of excitatory and inhibitory, conductance-based quadratic integrate-and-fire neurons, structured into a two-layered (V1 and V4) network with distance-dependent lateral connectivity and converging feed-forward connections. The model produces gamma rhythms that arise inherently from the network’s structure and exhibits synchronization of V1 gamma-band activity to activity in the V4 layer. In the present study, we explore the model further by introducing outside electrical stimulations to the local populations, exploring their effect on the phase coherence. The simulations go over a comprehensive set of electrical stimulations applied to multiple subsets of neurons within the populations of the model, resulting in a set of phase-response curves that can be used to causally shift the model's “attention” between the presented stimuli. These results will be used in future electrophysiological experimental studies allowing us to critically test whether gamma-band synchronization serves as the gating mechanism for attention driven routing of information.
title: Guiding attention: phase-response curve analysis of a communication through coherence model

text: Recent experimental and theoretical work established the hypothesis that cortical neurons operate close to critical states describing a phase transition from chaotic to ordered dynamics [1-2]. Such states are suggested to optimize neuronal information processing [3-4]. However, although critical dynamics have been demonstrated in recordings of spontaneously active cortical neurons [5], little is known about how these dynamics are affected by task-dependent changes in neuronal activity when the cortex is engaged in stimulus processing. We explore this question in the context of visual information processing modulated by selective attention: It has been shown that local field potentials (LFPs) in macaque area V4 exhibit an increase in gamma-band synchrony and a simultaneous enhancement of object representation with attention [6]. We reproduce these results using a model of integrate-and-fire neurons where attention increases synchrony by enhancing efficacy of recurrent interactions. In dependence on excitatory and inhibitory coupling strengths, we investigate the role of synchrony in enhancing stimulus processing and information transmission using information theoretical measures. We identify regions in which the diversity of activation patterns in response to different stimuli is maximized. Additionally, we compute information entropy and analyze the separability of activation patterns for different stimuli in the space of all possible activation patterns. We find that the maximum network repertoire as well as entropy maxima are associated with the emergence of synchrony near the critical points. Strikingly, only a narrow region in phase space at the transition from sub- to supercritical dynamics supports the experimentally observed discriminability increase. We therefore suggest that cortical networks operate at such near-critical states, allowing minimal attentional modulations of network excitability to substantially augment stimulus representation.
title: Marginally subcritical dynamics explain enhanced stimulus discriminability under attention

text: We investigate how neuronal networks process odor representations resulting either stimulus categorization or discrimination. We use Drosophila to examine the spatio-temporal representations of different monomolecular odors and their binary mixtures in the first olfactory neuropil, the antennal lobe. Flies perceive odors with olfactory sensory neurons (OSNs) that project into the antennal lobe, which consists of anatomically discrete subunits (glomeruli). OSNs expressing the same receptors converge to the same glomeruli where they synapse onto local interneurons (LNs) and projection neurons (PNs). PNs convey olfactory information to higher brain regions. We express the genetically encoded calcium sensor GCaMP3 in order to monitor calcium activity patterns evoked by different concentrations of odors in both OSNs and PNs. Glomerular activity patterns were found to change substantially with increasing odor concentrations in OSNs. However, PNs showed a higher degree of invariance over a broad concentration range. To further test whether different sensory inputs are processed in a way such that they are discriminated or categorized, we varied both the concentration as well as molecular identity of odors by gradually shifting the concentration ratios of binary odorant mixtures. Changing the concentration ratios of the odorants in the mixtures resulted in abrupt transitions between the odor representations in PNs. The neuronal circuit of the antennal lobe causes a categorization of the odor representations into discrete and distinct output patterns, enabling the flies to generalize and categorize different odors. We will further continue to dissect the neuronal elements of the antennal lobe network which mediate this stimulus processing.
title: Optical calcium imaging of relative odor concentrations of binary odorant mixtures in the Drosophila antennal lobe

text:
Decades of research have led to a thorough description of the insect mushroom body as a neuronal circuit involved in the control of adaptive behavior, e.g., associative learning. In particular, it has been revealed that mushroom body functions rely on the modulation of the mushroom body intrinsic Kenyon cells by biogenic amines, e.g., octopamine, dopamine or serotonin. Learning-induced plasticity has been proposed to be localized to the contact sites between aminergic neurons and Kenyon cells. Therefore, we asked which modulatory neurons interact with anatomically and functionally distinct mushroom body regions, and where exactly within the mushroom body subdivisions it is that they do so.

 We have adapted the recently described splitGFP-technique to label contact sites between mushroom body intrinsic Kenyon cells and extrinsic neurons. Using this approach we find spatially and structurally different contact regions between three neuromodulatory type of neurons and Kenyon cells in different subdivision of mushroom body, as well as spatially distinct zones of connectivy between Kenyon cells and aminergic neurons. 

Having localized the contact regions between aminergic neurons and Kenyon cells, we next aimed at addressing the physiology at those defined cellular regions. We therefore generated several transgenic flies that can be combined with the splitGFP label to trace back individual extrinsic or intrinsic neurons or to record neuronal activity using optical imaging. These fly strains can be used to combine  physiological and fine-scale anatomical studies, e.g. for monitoring odor-induced activity of Kenyon cells and plasticity at defined anatomical contact regions between Kenyon cells and extrinsic neurons.
title: Analysis of contact sites between intrinsic and extrinsic mushroom body neurons in drosophila

text:
Judgments of magnitude have a subjective component with systematic properties. The magnitude of the errors scale with the magnitude of the stimulus (scalar variability) and the errors tend towards the mean (regression effect). However, it is unclear how similar these systematic errors are within subjects but between magnitudes. Similarities in systematic errors across sensory modalities have been used to argue for a common neural substrate for time estimation. However, systematic errors in both distance and time estimation appear to result from combining the current sensory input with previous knowledge or expectations of the sensory input; which would imply a common but distributed mechanism. 
We examined distance and time estimation for two different but overlapping stimulus ranges, using the same production-reproduction paradigm with visual optic flow. Subjects completed all sessions of one magnitude before being tested on the other magnitude. The order in which the stimuli were presented within one subject was consistent such that a single trial for time estimation had an equivalent distance to be estimated. This was done because the order of stimulus presentation also has an effect on the systematic errors made. In addition, subjects estimated distance and time for a single range during fMRI. Time and distance estimation were measured in separate fMRI sessions. An additional control task, in which subjects moved freely but did not have to reproduce any magnitude, served as a control for both sessions.
Our preliminary findings suggest that for both time and distance, within subject behavior is more similar than between subject behavior; consistent with previous results [1]. These results are reflected in the hemodynamic activity during these tasks. Future work will focus on adapting existing theoretical principles to explain current results and applying these principles to explain the hemodynamic response seen in both of these tasks.
title: A general substrate of magnitude estimation: cerebral contributions for distance and time

text:
Mean-field theory has been very successful to link single neuron properties to the macroscopic population activity for homogeneous networks of spiking neurons (e.g. [1,2]). These studies only account for the mean population activity. This first-order statistics is sufficient to describe infinitely large neural populations, in which fluctuations of the macroscopic activity around its mean vanish. However, realistic neural populations of similar neurons can be rather small (e.g. N~1000) and macroscopic fluctuations cannot be neglected in this case.

A statistical description of such finite-size fluctuations of spiking neural networks (second-order statistics) is a challenging theoretical problem. Existing theories are either based on rather simplified neuron models or rely on certain heuristic assumptions. Here, we systematically derive stochastic population equations for the large class of generalized integrate-and-fire neurons with spike-triggered adaptation. Using a quasi-renewal approximation [3], we find a stochastic differential equation for the survivor function of the quasi-renewal process for any given last spike time. This leads to an additional noise term in the mean-field equations of [2].

Using our theory, we study spontaneous transitions between up and down states in a bistable network purely induced by intrinsic finite-size noise. Furthermore, in the asynchronous cortical state, we analytically calculate the spectral properties of the fluctuations by linearizing the dynamics about the mean activity. This allows us to investigate the role of spike-frequency adaptation and recurrent connectivity on the spontaneous activity (noise shaping) [4] and its implications for information processing.
title: Beyond mean-field theory: Fluctuation statistics of coupled populations of spiking neurons

text: Although the co-existence of both reward and saliency related signals in human ventral striatum (vStr) has been confirmed [1,2], the precise interaction between these two signals has not been fully resolved. Here, we approach this question computationally using a conditioning task that requires subject to make probabilistic choices for salient visual stimuli in order to obtain conditional reward. 27 participants were instructed to predict the occurrence of a visual stimulus by choosing between left and right button presses in the fMRI scanner. We compared a condition in which the stimulus appeared randomly on either side (Equal), against a condition in which the higher stimulus probability was assigned to the lower reward probability side (Biased), where the salient visual stimulus was misleading for the reward distribution. We found out that subjects tend to trade off the reward against the predictability of where the stimulus is more likely to appear. Behavioral results were analyzed on a single trial basis using reinforcement learning models. The stimulus prediction error (PE) and the reward PE are used in a model-based fMRI analysis and we found both PEs in the vStr suggesting that this region responses for general surprising perceptual events as well as unexpected reward delivery or omission. Furthermore, the activation patterns of either PE is different under the experimental manipulations: The stimulus PE is stronger in the Biased-condition whereas the reward PE is stronger in the Equal-condition (Figure 1). This neural activation pattern was related to the behavior that subjects went for the stimulus in the Biased-condition, but tend to optimize the performance in the Equal-condition. These data raise a possibility that the striatum encodes a value-nonspecific saliency signal in the same fashion as the reward signal for guiding behavior and that neural populations encoding these error signals are recruited dynamically depending on the experimental context.
title: Dissociable Saliency and Reward Signals in Ventral Striatum

text:
Salamander is a common model to study visual encoding in the retina, in particular the encoding of motion. We investigate the response of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) to different motion schemes like fast global jitter, jittering local objects and slow global drift. 
We found three functional types of RGCs. First, object-motion-sensitive (OMS) cells preferably respond to local motion of objects, but not when the whole scene is moving coherently (Ölveczky et al., Nature 2003). Second, we found direction-selective (DS) cells, which are known from mouse and rabbit, but not well studied in salamander. Third, we found a ganglion cell type that combines both functions. These OMS-DS cells respond selectively to a certain direction of motion and prefer small moving objects instead of global drift.
The two different kinds of DS cells not only differ in their preferences for global or local stimuli, but also in the organization of preferred motion directions. For standard DS cells the preferred directions occur in three clusters, separated by 120 degrees angular difference. The OMS-DS cells have two or more primary directions of 90 degrees angular difference. This suggests an interesting analogy to the DS cell types observed in the mammalian retina.
title: Motion Encoding in the Salamander Retina

text:
How natural scenes are encoded by retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) is still an unsolved problem. Here, we study how natural images are represented in the RGC responses by recording spikes from isolated axolotl retinas, using a multielectrode array. As stimuli, we applied a set of natural images as well as artificial noise-like stimuli and found that responses to natural images are stronger and more reliable. For each image of the stimulus set, we obtained a linearly filtered image by weighting the image with the receptive field profile. We then obtained a prediction for the spike count response through a linear-nonlinear (LN) model. 
To go beyond the LN model, we also analyzed the standard deviation of the linearly filtered images as a measure of local spatial contrast. We found that local spatial contrast is higher for the natural images than for artificial images, despite similar global contrast. In addition, local spatial contrast is positively correlated to the spike count response, and incorporating local spatial contrast in the LN model can improve spike count predictions. Finally, we used closed-loop experiments to compare responses to natural images with different degrees of spatial blurring while keeping the mean contrast over the receptive field of a given ganglion cell constant. These experiments showed that the spike count responses decay dramatically when local spatial contrast is decreased. Together, these results suggest that, besides mean light intensity, spatial contrast exerts a strong effect on RGC responses. This implies that spatial nonlinearities are important for predicting responses to natural images and that some of these effects can be captured by looking at the spatial contrast inside the receptive field.
title: Encoding of Natural Images by Retinal Ganglion Cells

text:
The receptive field is one of the most common ways to characterize the function of a neuron. Yet, receptive fields may contain further, elaborate substructure, as found, for example, in retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) [1, 2]. A method for detecting this substructure without detailed measurements of the anatomical and physiological cell properties is currently lacking.

Here, we propose a novel method, called sample-based semi non-negative matrix tri-factorization (ssNM3F), for identifying substructure in receptive fields. This method is derived from semi non-negative matrix factorization [3] and sample-based non-negative matrix tri-factorization (sNM3F) [4]. Like sNM3F, our method decomposes data into non-negative space-by-time components and activation coefficients for those components. Unlike sNM3F, however, activation coefficients can also be negative.

We present a proof of convergence for ssNM3F. We then demonstrate the technique on data that were recorded extracellularly from salamander RGCs. The data consist of the spike-triggered stimulus ensembles of individual cells, obtained under stimulation with spatio-temporal white noise. We find that ssNM3F can decompose the spike-triggered ensemble into factorized spatial and temporal components and associated activation coefficients. Variance-accounted-for (VAF) increases with increasing number of spatial and temporal components. We also find that the relaxation of the non-negativity constraint for the activation coefficients is a crucial prerequisite for increasing the VAF with increasing number of components. The number of components is selected by minimizing the Akaike information criterion. In our dataset, we find that, for many cells, the optimal number of spatial components is greater than unity.

These results suggest that ssNM3F can successfully detect substructure in receptive fields of RGCs and that semi-sNM3F can thereby provide a more detailed characterization of the spike-triggered ensemble.
title: Detection of Substructure in Receptive Fields of Retinal Ganglion Cells

text: The retina is a complex neural network which extracts visual features from the environment. Retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) form the output layer of this network. More than 15 different RGC types have been identified in the vertebrate retina using a variety of anatomical and physiological properties. Each RGC type is believed to relay specific features of the visual scene. It is not fully known, however, which features are being encoded. Thus, considerable effort is put into classifying RGCs based on their response properties. We identified RGCs in the axolotl retina, employing a spectral clustering algorithm. Spiking activity of RGCs was recorded extracellularly, using a 252-channel multielectrode array with offline spike-sorting. With this setup, typically more than 200 RGCs could be recovered from a single retina. The retina was stimulated with spatiotemporal white noise, and the receptive field dynamics for each RGC were obtained by reverse correlation (spike-triggered average).  We classified the cells by the clustering algorithm, based on the similarity of the cells’ receptive field sizes and their temporal filtering characteristics. We estimated the number of clusters using Akaike and Bayesian information criteria to be between 15 and 20. We observed groups with similar temporal properties (e.g., fast OFF cells), which could be separated based on their receptive field sizes. Moreover, a mosaic pattern of the receptive fields (a tell-tale sign of a single RGC type) was seen in more than a single cluster, in contrast to what had been previously reported for salamanders.
title: Classifying retinal ganglion cells in the salamander retina

text: Parallel processing of sensory information is a widely used strategy to quickly extract different stimulus features. Weakly electric fish provide a prime example for parallel processing in the sensory domain, since they posses two electrosensory systems: The  tuberous—or active—system is tuned to the fish’s own field and responds to distortions of this field imposed by nearby objects or the fields of conspecifics and their communication signals, called chirps. The ampullary—or passive—system responds to low-frequency modulations of electric fields as caused by prey items or chirps of some species of weakly  electric fish. We studied the neuronal representation of electric communication signals in the tuberous and ampullary system of E. virescens. We first characterized different kinds communication signals in behavioral experiments including a previously undescribed chirp. In subsequent in vivo electrophysiological recordings we studied the responses of both electrosensory systems to chirps. We show that different types of  electroreceptors encode different aspects of communication signals. Through a decoding analysis of single neurons and small populations we demonstrate that this specialization leads to complementary information in the tuberous and ampullary system about the different chirp  types. This suggests that a potential readout mechanism should consider the information provided by both parallel processing streams.
title: Parallel encoding of communication signals in the weakly electric fish Eigenmannia virescens

text:
It is indicated, both experimentally in the form of population-based processing [1] and from simulations [2], that multilayer spiking networks contribute importantly to neural processing within the brain. In particular, it has been shown that spiking networks containing hidden neurons improves performance when learning to classify input patterns between two output classes, by a spike/no-spike coding scheme [3]. However, neurons may encode information by the precise timing of spikes, that allows the classification of inputs between a large number of possible output classes.
Here, we introduce a new supervised multilayer learning rule for a spiking network that is biologically plausible and can classify input patterns on a spatio-temporally coded basis. We use a statistical approach to derive our learning rule, combined with the technique of back-propagation, that maximises the likelihood of the network generating a desired output spike pattern. Our method is derived for a network with a single hidden layer, but it can also straightforwardly be extended to networks with multiple hidden layers.
Through simulations, we demonstrate that our multilayer rule can learn to map between multiple spatio-temporal spike patterns and output spike trains, thereby establishing the practical utility of our method. Furthermore, we also will show how our learning rule can be extended to learning by reinforcement in a multilayer network, and its relation to the reward-maximising learning rule for a single-layer network [4].
title: Learning to map input-output patterns in a multilayer spiking network

reasonForTalk: The research has a unique perspective with regards to visual processing in the retina.
text: The mid $1860s$ saw the beginning of amazing discoveries as pertains to aspects of the visual system.  Schultze in this period discovered the existence of two distinct photoreceptors; Rods and Cones.  Santiago Ramon y Cajal a little later, $1930s$, discovered the existence of distinct retinal ganglion classes. Great strides in the understanding of how visual information is processed have been made from this time. In the recent past, aspects pertaining to the visual transduction process have become more apparent.  One such aspect is the importance of the convergence of the rod and cone systems to local adaptation and contrast gain control, processes extremely vital to the visual transduction process and therefore to adequate vision. However, because research until recently showed that Rod and Cone systems have operated autonomously of each other, existing retinal models have been on either system and have not incorporated this convergence.  By our research we propose a new retina model, which is biologically plausible, computationally simple and effective, and one that captures the convergence of Rod and Cone systems both in the Outer and Inner Plexiform Layers of the retina.  We also show how this convergence improves the perception of contrast and therefore the quality of vision.
title: Modelling Rod-Cone Convergence to Improve Our Understanding of  How Quality of Vision is Impacted

text:
Event-related responses in the high gamma frequency range (>60 Hz) have been observed in many different functional brain systems.  A recent study showed significant activation of intracranial EEG band-power between 60-170 Hz in the inferior temporal gyrus in response to visually presented numerals [1]. Other, fMRI based studies, revealed the involvement of the occipitotemporal region in abacus-based mental calculation tasks [2,3]. In the present work, we want to demonstrate the involvement of the ventral occipitotemporal region in an abacus-based counting/arithmetic task using functional ECoG mapping.
The real-time functional mapping system cortiQ (g.tec, Austria) was used to analyze data collected with a 256-channel g.HIamp system (g.tec, Austria). The cortiQ mapping system presented the stimuli and processed incoming data.  In this study a right-handed female patient with epilepsy who had 236 subdural electrodes implanted, participated the mapping procedure. The implanted electrodes covered the left frontal-, left temporal- and left parietal/occipital lobe, the right temporal lobe, as well as the left and right temporal base. The paradigm consisted of a 45s long counting task split into three periods of 15s and a 45s long resting period. At the beginning of the counting task the subject was asked to count from a given number (e.g., 300) either upwards or downwards in fixed steps. The paradigm was repeated three times in independent runs.
While performing the task, significant activation of the high-gamma frequency band was detected over the ventral occipitotemporal region of the right hemisphere. All three mapping sessions consistently showed the same strong activation patterns across Brodmann areas 20 and 37, as well as small activation across Brodmann areas 21, 22, 41 and 42.
 As the subject reported imagination of an abacus, the identified activation pattern in the occipitotemporal region corresponded to an abacus-based counting task.
title: High-Gamma Activation in Electrocorticographic Signals During a Mental Counting Task

text:
Processing of speech is one of the key functions of the human auditory system. Recognition of spoken words requires the detection of fine spectro-temporal acoustic features that can be orders of magnitudes shorter than the temporal extent of the encompassing auditory stream. It is unknown through which mechanisms of synaptic plasticity auditory neurons can learn to tune their responses to the relevant features. To solve the associated credit assignment problem, current speech recognition systems require either temporally segmented training data or rely on complicated algorithms for segmentation estimation that lack biologically plausible implementations.

Here we present a novel spiking neuron model of auditory processing that is capable to learn to detect phonemes in streams of natural speech without temporally segmented training data. This model is based on the recently proposed multi-spike tempotron[1] that learns to detect target features on the basis of a teaching signal that specifies the number of target feature occurrences in a trial but not their timing.

Using this neuron model, we analyze the functional significance of different neuronal response types that have been characterized throughout the auditory brain stem. Extending a previous auditory front-end of on- and offset neurons[2,3] we include populations of neurons that mimic more complex responses such as duration tuning or sustained firing behavior[4]. We quantify which components of these spike-based neural representations of the auditory input streams subserve the detection of specific classes of auditory features. Inspired by the benefits of triphones in various speech recognition systems, we analyze the effects of phonetic contexts for the learning and generalization performance of our phoneme detectors.

Our work provides a biologically plausible neuronal model of segmentation-free phoneme detection that can exploit the dramatic reduction in training data costs provided by count based labeling.
title: Spike based processing of natural speech

text:
Saccadic suppression refers to reduced visual sensitivity around (micro-)saccades. The sources of suppression remain elusive. One component of it could occur in retina, while another could be extra-retinal. Here we studied saccadic suppression in superior colliculus, SC, which receives both direct and indirect retinal input. We studied suppression across spatial frequency (SF) channels in the superficial layers (receiving direct retinal input) and compared it to deeper layers.

We recorded from 87 neurons of 2 monkeys. Inside a neuron’s RF, a stationary, vertical Gabor (0.56, 1.11, 2.22, 4.44, or 11.11 cpd) appeared. We measured peak neuronal activity 30-150 ms after grating onset. We characterized superficial-layer visual (V) and intermediate-layer visual-motor (VM) neurons. Trials with grating onset >100 ms before/after microsaccades served as baseline. We compared these to trials with gratings appearing <50 ms after microsaccades, a period of maximal suppression. In separate sessions, we measured reaction times (RT) when monkeys made saccades to the gratings: we detected microsaccades in real-time and presented the gratings at specific times (0-200 ms) after detection. This allowed us to get a time course of saccadic suppression in RT.

85/87 neurons were suppressed in at least 1 SF. VM neurons were twice as strongly suppressed as V neurons. Moreover, VM suppression was SF-dependent: it was strongest in the lower SFs. Suppression was constant across SF for V neurons. Behaviorally, suppression mirrored VM neurons: RT increased during maximal suppression and gradually returned to baseline, but this effect disappeared for high SFs.

Thus, superficial layer neurons exhibited weak non-SF-dependent suppression. Deeper neurons had strong suppression that weakened with higher SFs. Deeper neurons were more correlated with behavioral effects. These results illuminate the differential contributions of different visual processing pathways to saccadic suppression.
title: Layer-specific influences of microsaccadic eye movements on spatial vision in the primate superior colliculus

text: Current models about the neural basis of working memory storage hold conflicting ideas: while the standard model declares the centralization of the working memory (WM) storage in prefrontal cortex (PFC), a newly emerging model argues that WM is realized through a distributed network of brain areas including visual cortex. In recent studies reporting evidence for WM storage in posterior brain regions but not in prefrontal areas, either simple visual features (grating orientation, color or motion direction) or complex visual patterns were memorized. Here we designed a new experiment to further examine the neural basis of WM. We employed Chinese-native-speakers to do a short-term memory task with Chinese characters as stimuli. We used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and cross-validated MANOVA-based multivariate pattern analyses (MVPA) to identify brain regions which, during the delay period, held information about the memorized characters. We found that both prefrontal and posterior brain regions showed such content-specific information. Thus, these areas are candidate regions for WM storage, with potentially posterior brain regions storing visual details while non-visual information is represented in prefrontal areas.
title: Decoding neural representations of Chinese Characters held in Working Memory

text:
Although modern cochlear implants (CI) provide good speech intelligibility in quiet environments, in adverse listening conditions their performance degrades. Difficult scenarios are for example cocktail party situations with multiple simultaneous sound sources, noisy environments, music background or reverberations. Sound localization provides important cues to separate sources which enhance speech intelligibility. 
There is room to optimize coding of binaural information. Binaural models, such as the Lindemann model, can provide a metric to predict source localization abilities. The metric was extended to work with action potentials, which are generated by physiologically inspired models of sound coding provided by an intact inner ear model and a model of electric hearing with different CI coding strategies, enabling a comparison between NH and CI listeners. 
Using complex signals, such as speech, without noise the spatial resolution of sound localization can be investigated, showing the accuracy in a best case scenario.
Daily listening environments are always non-ideal. Therefore the metric can take several degrading factors into account. Adding background noise to the clean signal at various ratios the impact on localization can be quantified and the minimal threshold for sound localization determined.
The SNR, when localization cues break down for CI-listeners with the FS4 strategy were only 10 dB above the ones for NH, which is surprisingly good. For the NH case, tests revealed that the actual threshold was  ~10 dB lower than the calculated and just above the noise masking threshold.
In summary, the model framework introduced here is a valuable tool for the pre-evaluation and optimization of bilateral cochlear implant coding strategies. It provides quantitative values for the strength of the correlation between between left and right ear auditory spike trains. The final evaluation,  has yet to be determined by listening test.
title: Model-based Prediction of Source Localization Threshold in Noisy Environments for Normal Hearing (NH) and Cochlear Implant (CI) Listeners

text:
In the entorhinal cortex of rodents fmoving in 2D, the discharge patterns of grid cells are reminiscent of hexagonal spatial lattices with regularly spaced firing fields [1]. When animals run back and forth on a long, but narrow track, grid cells also show distinct spatial firing fields, but, in general, these are not regularly spaced [2]. In many such experiments, distant landmarks are visible; in contrast, making rats run through a maze by inserting walls into an arena changes the firing fields entirely, and the hexagonal grid disappears [3].
We hypothesized that grid-cell firing along a linear track corresponds to a linear slice through a two-dimensional hexagonal grid. If such a slice were not parallel to one of its principal axes, one would predict that, for most neurons, the firing fields are not periodically spaced and their peak firing rates change systematically. As the parameters of the putative hexagonal lattice of a given grid cell are unknown, we varied the grid spacing, field width, and peak height, and fit sections through such grids to spike data measured on linear tracks. We find that, indeed, these firing patterns mimic 1D slices through hexagonal grids, similar to results from virtual environments [4]. In addition, there is no preferential alignment of the best-fit grid to the linear-track axis, and right-to-left runs generally lead to different firing fields than left-to-right runs; surprisingly, the orientation of the best-fit hexagonal grid differs as well. This suggests that grid cells have a predisposition to form hexagonal firing rate maps in open environments, but that such maps only become anchored to a common orientation and position when the animal is allowed full freedom of movement in a two-dimensional arena. Such a finding is consistent with the emergence of omni-directional place cells in the hippocampus [5] and the link between the remapping of hippocampal place fields and the lattice realignment of firing fields in grid cells [6].
title: Slicing through the hexagonal lattice – grid-cell firing patterns on linear tracks provide insight into grid-field formation in 2D environments

text: In the hippocampal formation, some neurons fire whenever the animal's location coincides with a point of an imaginary, hexagonal grid that tessellates space. Such neurons are called grid cells and are thought to play an important role in spatial navigation [1]. Achieving a metric representation for space requires more than a single grid cell; indeed, it requires an ensemble of neurons organized in separate modules, with each module representing a different spatial scale. In addition, all grid lattices within a module must share the same orientation, which permits decoding through population vectors. In the limit of low firing rates, the highest spatial resolution is achieved when the ratio of spatial scales across successive modules is 3/2, in agreement with experimental findings [2].
title: The hexagonal grid code as a multi-dimensional clock for space

text:
Neural populations, such as hippocampal place-cell ensembles or groups of orientation-selective cells in visual cortex are thought to encode external stimuli in their joint firing rate. When assessing the performance of such a code, e.g., for stimulus reconstruction, it is usually assumed that the encoded parameters are essentially static during the integration intervals used for rate estimation. However, for many parameters, say the exact position of a rapidly moving animal, this assumption is wrong and reconstruction bears additional errors. On the other hand, instantaneous decoding and hence immediate stimulus reconstruction are not possible because action potentials are generated with a finite maximal rate. This leads to a trade-off, raising the question how integration time is related to decoding accuracy.
To address this question, we study populations of independent, Poisson model neurons with Gaussian tuning curves and study how the average squared error of a maximum likelihood decoder depends on the integration time for dynamic stimuli. This setup is an abstraction of an array of neurons encoding a moving object (Fig. A). By changing the stimulus statistics and the properties of the neural population, we analyze their effect on decoding speed and accuracy.
In all scenarios studied, the average error has exactly one minimum at an intermediate integration time. For short decoding times, an analytic lower error bound is given by an exponential function whose decay constant is the population firing rate. For long decoding times, the statistics of the stimulus’ time evolution determine the error, whereas the properties of the neural population become less important. In between, around the minimum error, the stimulus-dynamics dependent part of the error is a quadratic function of the decoding time whose curvature is given by the mean squared stimulus speed (Fig. B). For fixed integration time the mean squared error thus depends quadratically on stimulus velocity.
title: Rate-coding of dynamic stimuli: Decoding-accuracy versus integration-time

text:
Spiking neural networks (SNN) are often used to study the effects of spike timing dependent plasticity (STDP) on activity-evoked changes to the synaptic strength between two neurons. For simplicity and compatibility with more abstract rate-based models, the timing of inputs to these networks is often modelled as a stochastic poisson process where the exact timing of spikes is either completely random or has some level of correlation with other inputs. A freely firing postsynaptic neuron that receives correlated inputs is more likely to temporally form strong connections with some of those inputs, but may loose those strong connections as learning progresses. For stochastically firing inputs, the stability of strong connections strongly depends on the size of the correlated group, and learning success is commonly described as the time that a given strong subset of connections survives before decay. 

However, if inputs to spiking neural networks were instead assumed to encode meaningful information in spaciotemporal patterns instead of varying levels of correlation, many of these perceived problems with STDP can be solved. When inputs are not simply correlated, but have a tendency to fire in a given order, STDP is known to find the minimal group of inputs that still allows a fast postsynaptic response.

We show the benefits of using spaciotemporal patterns for performing spike timing dependent plasticity in pattern retention time, synaptic stability, sparseness, robustness to size of input group, and signal detection performance under noise. We suggest that stochastic inputs are insufficient to correctly describe the performance of STDP and propose that assumed behaviours of STDP should be reexamined using spaciotemporal patterns.
title: Spaciotemporal spike patterns reveal features of STDP that stochastic inputs cannot.

text:
Cone photoreceptors (cones) in the retina play a critical role in color vision. The cone has an outer segment that acts as phototransduction mechanism, an inner segment that shapes membrane potential and a synaptic terminal that communicates with the second-order neurons. Computational models for phototransduction mechanism have been developed based on the experimental analyses of cones. In order to fully understand photoresponse mechanisms such as light sensitivity and response dynamics, we need to develop a realistic computational model of a cone by integrating individual mechanisms of the functional parts.

We developed a computational model of the cone based on biophysical and physiological properties. The present model consists of three parts: outer, inner segment and synaptic terminal. The outer segment part is described based on the biophysical properties of phototransduction mechanism initiated by absorption of photon. The inner segment part includes the membrane ionic currents based on experimental analyses: $I_h,\,I_{Kv},\,I_{Ca},\,I_K$ and $I_L$ (leakage current). We also introduced the mechanism of calcium concentration by calculating calcium flux. The synaptic terminal part includes a mechanism of calcium concentration and localization of the calcium dependent chloride channel.

The present model makes it possible to simulate biophysical mechanisms underlying generation of the photocurrent and the photovoltage. The photovoltage of a cone to a light stimulus is not a mirror image of the photocurrent and a prominent depolarizing off-overshoot response is observed. The simulated results suggest that the photocurrent is shaped by the nonlinear membrane conductances and the overshoot is produced by the calcium current. In conclusion, the present model can be used for analyzing the light response properties of the cone photoreceptors quantitatively.
title: Biophysical modeling of a cone photoreceptor

text:
Cone and rod photoreceptors initiate the visual information processing by converting the image focused onto the retina into electrical signals. Rods are sensitive to dim light allowing night vision. Cones are maximally sensitive to either long(L), medium(M), or short(S) wavelength of visible light, which mediate color vision. In the retina, these photoreceptors are forming a distinctive spatial arrangement called a photoreceptor mosaic. The cones are concentrated in the fovea and the cone density decreases with distance from the fovea, while the diameter of the cone increases. Outside the fovea, the rod density rapidly increases keeping almost the same diameter. In order to elucidate the influence of the spatial arrangement on the visual information processing, it is important to develop a realistic model of the photoreceptor mosaic.

 In the present study, we developed a method for automatic generation of a realistic photoreceptor mosaic based on the anatomical characteristics. The photoreceptor mosaic is generated by a stochastic algorithm to position L, M, S cones randomly according to given ratio. In order to reproduce the density and the cone diameter, we incorporated the cone-to-cone spacing and the cone diameter obtained from experimental measurements into the model.

 As a result, the cone density in the generated photoreceptor mosaic showed a peak in the central fovea and decreased towards the periphery. The cone formed a round circle while changing the diameter with distance from fovea. Both the density and the cone diameter well correspond to those measured experimentally. In conclusion, we have succeeded in generating various types of realistic photoreceptor mosaic models which reproduced cone density, cone diameter, and L,M,S-cone ratio. By integrating this model with photoresponse characteristics, we can make a computational analysis how the spatial arrangement of photoreceptor influence on the visual information processing.
title: Automatic generation of a realistic photoreceptor mosaic

text: Population imaging in mouse auditory cortex revealed clustering of neural responses to brief complex sounds: the activity of a local population typically falls close to one out of a small number of observed states [1]. These clusters appear to group sets of auditory stimuli into a discrete set of activity patterns and could thereby form the basis for representations of sound categories. However, to be useful for the brain, such representations should be robust against fluctuations in the underlying circuitry, which are significant even in the absences of any explicit learning paradigm [2]. Here we introduce a novel circuit model of mouse auditory cortex to study the emergence of the observed activity cluster states and their structural stability in the presence of synaptic turnover. We find that generic random networks by virtue of their inhibitory recurrent connectivity can group complex sounds spontaneously into essentially discrete sets of activity states. Moreover, these states can display high degrees of stability, even when modifying a substantial fraction of synaptic connections, as long as the basic statistics of connectivity is maintained. We use the insights gained from the analysis of our model to interpret data gathered in a parallel effort, employing chronic two-photon imaging of population activity in the auditory cortex of awake mice.
title: Discrete representations in mouse auditory cortex and their stability in the presence of synaptic turnover

text:
Information theoretic approaches such as transfer entropy provide nonparametric means to analyze neural circuits. Recently, local information theoretic measures have been proposed that describe information storage and transfer in time, which allows to quantify aspects of the temporal dynamics of information flow in complex networks [1]. These measures appear highly promising for understanding information processing in neural circuits. Complementing ongoing parallel experimental efforts in cat visual cortex [2], we here use a computational circuit model to explore the capacity of these local information theoretic measures in quantifying the formation of sensory representations under the influence of top-down modulatory inputs.

We model the interaction of area 18 (A18) with the posteromedial lateral suprasylvian area (PMLS; a highly visual motion sensitive area downstream of A18), in detecting the direction of motion in moving gratings and moving dots. To do so, we construct recurrently connected population models for both A18 and PMLS, based on firing rate units. These, again, are recurrently connected with each other to facilitate interaction. Our A18 model reliably detects the direction of motion with and without PMLS but performance significantly improves under the influence of PMLS, consistent with experimental studies, in which PMLS activity was reduced through cooling and neurons in A18 were less selective [3].

For our analysis of information dynamics, we compute both the local information transfer (LIT) and the active information storage (AIS) for all neurons in the model. We find that an active PMLS facilitates the AIS within A18. When cooled, the AIS drops both for PMLS and for A18. Both the AIS and the LIT depend on time and change when the dots are changing direction. 

Altogether, our analysis based on circuit models suggest that local information dynamics can be a useful tool for studying sensory processing in interacting brain regions.
title: Local Information Dynamics in a Model of A18-PMLS Interaction in Cat Visual Cortex

text:
In mammalian visual cortex most neurons are tuned to the orientation of a visual edge, a property called orientation preference. In primates and carnivores, the preferred stimulus orientation forms a largely coherent map across the cortical surface, in which neighboring neurons often prefer highly similar orientations. To explain the formation of this orientation preference map during development, most theoretical models assume a Mexican-hat type structure of neuronal interactions. However, so far Mexican-hat shaped neuronal interactions could not been observed in anatomical or physiological data. Here we show that within our model already a low degree of Mexican-hat type neuronal interactions can lead to the formation of highly coherent orientation preference maps.
Our network model of the primary visual cortex describes the interactions between the neuronal orientation response properties. We quantified the maps emerging from these dynamics by a coherence measure evaluating the similarity of preferred orientations in neighboring neurons, and analyzed map coherence as a function of the spatial coherence of neuronal interactions.
Coherent map structure is highly robust against decreasing the level of coherence in neuronal interactions, which we have modeled by superimposing the Mexican-hat with random interaction weights of increasing strength. For a large number of neurons per hypercolumn, already marginally small levels of interaction coherence lead to high levels of coherence in the resulting orientation preference layout, as weak biases of coherence are amplified by the network. For vanishing coherence of neuronal interactions we observe a transition from a coherent map towards a random layout, reminiscent of the ‘salt-and-pepper’ organization observed in several rodent species.
We conclude that the highly coherent maps found in several species could result from a Mexican-hat bias of neuronal interactions that is much more subtle than previously anticipated.
title: Low-level coherence in neuronal interactions suffice to generate highly coherent orientation preference maps

text:
In the insect, olfactory sensory input is encoded in the form of spatio-temporal patterns in the projection neurons (PN) of the antennal lobe. These dense and overlapping patterns are transformed into sparse code represented by Kenyon cells (KC) in the mushroom body. 
Previous efforts of modelling these components of the insect olfactory system have focused on Lotka-Volterra equations to model the experimentally observed sequential activation of PNs [1]. We used this approach to model the KCs, and expanded on this in two ways: First, by adding an online Bayesian inference scheme to model the process through which the code from the PNs is read, transformed and used for decision making by KCs. Second, by modifying the connectivity matrix in the Lotka-Volterra equations to allow clusters of neurons to be activated as a sequence. 
In our model, the connectivity structure is in accord with experimental findings: the KCs have inhibitory interconnectivity [2], each PN excites a large number of KCs [3], and there is forward and backward connections between the PNs and the KCs[4]. 
The model was able to qualitatively reproduce experimentally observed activity in the PNs and the KCs, i.e. a dense and overlapping code in the PNs, and sparse coding in the KCs [5]. Additionally, the activity in individual PNs presents the previously reported excitation and inhibition epochs in response to a stimulus [6]. In accord with experimental results [7], we found that the model can recognize odours early during stimulus presentation. This also enabled the model to recognize sequences of odours, switching from one odour to another shortly after the stimulus changed. 
In conclusion, we found that the combination of established models, such as the Lotka-Volterra equations, with Bayesian inference provides a coherent explanation for a large number of experimental findings in insect odour decoding.
title: Modelling odour decoding in the antennal lobe by combining sequential firing rate models with Bayesian inference

text:
Auditory neurons encode temporal information using phase-locked spikes. In the auditory brainstem, coincidence detector neurons involved in sound localization receive bilateral phase-locked synaptic inputs and change their output spiking rates with the interaural time difference. Previous modeling studies suggested that convergence of phase-locked inputs gives rise to periodic oscillations in the membrane potential of the target neuron. This prediction was later confirmed by in vivo intracellular recording from the barn owl's nucleus laminaris (NL) [1]. 
In this study, we constructed a biologically plausible auditory coincidence detector neuron model that receives phase-locked synaptic inputs and examined how several input parameters affect the oscillating membrane potential. We derived a formula that connects the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of the membrane potential with input parameters as: SNR $= MLR^2T$, where M denotes the number of inputs, L is the average spike rates of input fibers, R is the degree of phase-locking (vector strength), and T is the time length of the analyzed waveform [2]. 
By comparing predicted SNR with experimental data, we found that (1) SNRs of mid-to-high frequency (>2 kHz) NL neurons showed good agreement with theoretical prediction, and that (2) SNRs of low frequency (<2 kHz) neurons are lower than the predicted minimum. These results suggest that low frequency NL neurons may receive significantly fewer inputs than mid-to-high frequency neurons (i.e., smaller M). Our simulations showed that changes in the number of converging phase-locked inputs greatly affect the shape of oscillating potential of the model membrane: A large number of weak synaptic inputs induce stable sinusoidal oscillations whereas a small number of strong inputs lead to more dynamic (noisy) responses. Further investigation is needed to determine the actual number of synaptic inputs in the auditory coincidence detectors in vivo.
title: Signal-to-noise ratio analysis of auditory coincidence detectors

text:
Voltage sensitive dye (VSD) imaging of multiple neurons becomes one of the most promising up-to-date methods to investigate neuronal network activity. To trace the voltage change of a particular region (ROI) in the VSD recording, the average intensity value of the ROI is calculated in each frame. However, during the experiment the cell sometimes moves and thus, the former ROI does not fit the cell border anymore, causing an artifact in the calculated voltage time course.
Experimentally, we performed VSD recording in a semi intact preparation of a leech ganglion with an attached patch of skin (Fig. a). When a poker touched the skin (Fig. b) to stimulate the sensory neurons, the skin movement also caused movement of the attached ganglion. The resulting cell movement artifact is clearly visible in the VSD signal corresponding to the voltage time course (Fig. d, red trace) obtained for the pixels of a single cell (Fig. c, region with green border), when no correction for cell movement is performed. 
The movement correction problem corresponds strongly to image registration in the field of image processing. Image registration methods try to find the best mapping matrix between two images taken from the same scene in different times and/or from different viewpoint [1]. Liu [2] developed an efficient algorithm to solve the image registration problem based on the Lucas-Kanade method for optical flow estimation, which additionally benefits from a coarse-to-fine optical flow estimation to raise the accuracy in finding corresponding points in two consecutive frames. We adapted this algorithm to the cell movement problem.  Applying this method to the dataset allows correcting movement between the frames and subsequently calculating the voltage time course. Comparison between the VSD traces before (red) and after (blue) artifact removal in Fig. d shows that the method successfully removes the movement artifact.
title: Cell movement correction in voltage sensitive dye recording during tactile stimulation

text:
It is a crucial task for all sensory systems to detect changes in external stimuli based on the time course of neuronal responses. In this study, we compare four methods for the detection of stimulus changes based on spike responses.
The dataset used for this study includes both extra- and intracellularly recorded spiking responses from a first order auditory interneuron (AN2) of crickets (Hildebrandt et al., 2011). Auditory stimuli consisted of an amplitude modulated carrier frequency of 3, 10 or 16 kHz, in which intensity peaks and gaps of either 50 or 100 ms duration and different intensity levels occurred. AN2 spike rate increased during stimulus peaks and decreased during gaps.
To detect change points (on- and offsets of peaks and gaps) in stimulus intensities based on spike responses, we applied four methods: 1. moving average, 2. classification, 3. parametric inter spike interval (ISI) and 4. quotient ISI method. While the first two methods use a smoothed continuous spike rate, both ISI methods are discrete methods analyzing the exact spike times. Furthermore, parametric (1., 3.) and non-parametric (2., 4.) methods can be distinguished.
We found that all four methods allow the detection of stimulus changes and show a better performance for detection of peaks than of gaps. The widely used moving average method (1) generally achieved the lowest detection performance, required a long analysis window and relied in most cases on wrong parametric assumptions. In contrast, the quotient ISI method (4) led to the highest detection performance for peaks and gaps. Relying only on the relative timing of two spikes, it also has the advantage of a flexible time scale. Both discrete methods require exact spike times and therefore should be applied only to intracellular or high-quality extracellular recordings. For noisy extracellular recordings, the classification method (2) was found to allow good and fast detection of stimulus peaks, but only a poor detection of gaps.
title: Different methods of change point detection in single-neuron responses

text: Maintaining attention on relevant stimuli across eye movements is both critical and natural in our daily life. While recent psychophysical studies have shed light on the dynamics of attention shifts across saccades, we focused on the neuronal correlates of such transsaccadic attention shifts in the visual cortex of non-human primates. We recorded the extracellular activity of single neurons in area MT of two macaque monkeys during a task that required them to make a saccade while maintaining attention on one of four moving random dot patterns (RDPs) in order to respond to a brief direction change in that target RDP by releasing a lever. In the first experiment, the target was either in the neurons’ pre-saccadic receptive field (RF) or directly opposite to it, while in the second experiment, the target was either in the post-saccadic RF or directly opposite to it. By assessing the neuronal responses just before and after the saccade, we were able to determine the time course of attentional modulation of neuronal activity when the target was brought into or moved out of the neuron’s RF by a saccade. Attentional enhancement of neuronal activity emerges within 60 ms after saccade offset when the attended stimulus enters the RF after the saccade. Comparing the results from the two experiments, we find that the locus of peak activity in MT switches back to the cued spatial location at the same time. The behavioral performance of the two monkeys indicates that the performance is impaired around the time of the saccade, but recovers within 50 ms after saccade offset in a manner consistent with the physiological data. Put together, our observations indicate a rapid repositioning of the attentional spotlight in MT’s retinotopic representation across a saccade.
title: Rapid transsaccadic repositioning of the attentional spotlight in macaque area MT.

text: Hippocampal place cells are active at specific locations (place fields) when a rodent is moving through an environment. Recording several of these cells in-vivo allows to reconstruct the trajectory of the animal. During awake immobility and slow-wave sleep a replay of the cell activity on a faster timescale can be observed, in which the relative order of the cell activity is preserved. During such replays, the local field potential is characterized by strong voltage deflections, sharp-waves, combined with high-frequency oscillations (~150-200 Hz), so called ripples. These sharp-wave ripples are thought to play a major role in memory consolidation and emerge from activity bursts in the hippocampal area CA3. The cellular mechanisms underlying replay during sharp waves are not well understood. To investigate these properties we implemented a conductance-based single cell model, in which we can test the influence of inhibitory and excitatory currents on the generation of action potentials. We find that inhibition is crucial for decorrelating the cell output between subsequent ripple cycles.
title: Spike generation and integration of synaptic currents in a model of CA1 pyramidal cells  during sharp-­wave ripples

text:
The principal cells of the medial superior olive (MSO) are coincidence detector neurons in the auditory brainstem that encode interaural time differences (ITDs) by their firing rate. MSO neurons receive one excitatory and one inhibitory input from each side, both of which are phase-locked. It was shown that precisely-timed inhibitory inputs are capable of tuning the timing of best coincidence [1]. For input frequencies up to 500 Hz this result could also be corroborated by a computational model of an MSO neuron [2]. Both approaches show that inhibition alone does not suffice to explain in-vivo data for higher input frequencies.
Using the computational MSO model we found that introducing amplitude asymmetries of the ipsilateral relative to the contralateral excitatory inputs had a substantial effect on ITD sensitivity tuning. Furthermore, we show that, despite the existence of fast-activating subthreshold channels in MSO neurons, a linear summation of all synaptic inputs already yields a good prediction of the resulting ITD function of the model [3].
We conclude that, a putative asymmetry of excitatory inputs adds another crucial dimension to ITD sensitivity tuning that can explain in-vivo results for higher input frequencies. The possibility to predict ITD tuning functions by a simple linear summation allows for efficiently estimating parameters, such as the level of excitatory asymmetry and the timing and intensity of inhibition, for more complex models of MSO neurons.
title: Asymmetric excitatory amplitudes modulate ITD sensitivity in a model of principal cells of the medial superior olive

text:
The information spike trains encode about an external time-dependent stimulus is quantified by Shannon's mutual information rate [1], which has been estimated in certain biological model systems [2]. However, the numerical estimation of the mutual information rate is demanding [3] and does not reveal which aspects of the stimulus are encoded. Several studies have identified mechanisms at the cellular and network level leading to low- or high-pass filtering of information, i. e. the selective coding of low- or high-frequency components of the time-dependent stimulus. However, these findings rely on an approximation, specifically, on the qualitative behavior of the coherence function, an approximate frequency-resolved measure of information flow, whose quality is generally unknown.
 
We developed a numerical procedure to directly calculate a frequency-resolved version of the mutual information rate. This can be used to study how different frequency components of a Gaussian stimulus are encoded in neural models without invoking a weak-signal paradigm or making undue assumptions on the nature of the neural encoding. We demonstrate its application for paradigmatic descriptions of neural firing like an integrator neuron and a simple setup mimicking a coincident detector cell receiving input from two leaky integrate-and-fire neurons.
title: A Frequency-resolved Mutual Information Rate

text:
Cortical activity may show transitions between states of high and low firing rates, so called up and
down states. These states have traditionally been associated with slow wave sleep or anesthesia, but
have been shown to occur also in quiet wakefulness. Recently, they have been implicated
with the gating of sensory inputs [1]. This raises the question how the transmission of information
about a weak signal (for example a sensory input) is influenced by a strong background input that
is not asynchronous-irregular but rather consists of up and down states.
As an analytical approach, we consider a leaky integrate-and-fire (LIF) neuron which is driven
by dichotomous noise, a stochastic two-state process that serves as an approximation to the up-
down input from the network. We derive exact expressions for firing statistics such as rate and
CV as well as the power spectrum of such a neuron. We then consider an additional weak additive
signal and calculate the linear response of the LIF. Combined with the power spectrum, this allows
us to assess the information transmission properties in the face of strong dichotomous fluctuations
(representing up-down input), which we compare to the known results for Gaussian white noise
(representing asynchronous irregular input).
title: Analytical approach to the transmission of a weak signal in the presence of network up/down states

text: Synchronous firing of neurons is a prominent feature in many brain areas. Here, we are interested in the information transmission by the synchronous spiking output of a neuronal population that receives a common time-dependent sensory stimulus. Earlier experimental [1] and theoretical [2] work revealed that synchronous spikes encode preferentially fast (high-frequency) components of the stimulus, i.e. synchrony acts as an information filter. In these studies a rather strict measure of synchrony was used: all neurons in the population have to fire within a short time window. Here, we generalize the definition of the synchronous output, for which only m out of N neurons in the population have to fire in synchrony. We present an analytical approach to characterize the information transfer, by deriving the cross-correlation and the coherence function between the stimulus and the synchronous output. We find that above a critical threshold of synchrony m/N, also the generalized synchronous output acts as a band-pass filter. We confirm our analytical findings by numerical simulations for the leaky integrate-and-fire neuron. By analyzing experimental data of P-Units electroreceptors of the weakly electric fish we can show that the filtering effect occurs in real neurons as well.
title: Information filtering of a common stimulus by incomplete synchrony - theory and experiment

text:
We study how different effects of intrinsic noise on spikes influence signal transmission by spiking neurons. Therefore we consider populations of neurons driven by a strong common time-dependent signal. The single elements are modeled by Poisson models, where in one case the intrinsic noise either adds and deletes spikes (AD model), whereas in the other model the intrinsic noise leads to spike time shifting (STS model). We show that although the models are indistinguishable on a single neuron level, they exhibit distinct properties of information transmission on the population level. For sufficiently large populations both models exhibit suprathreshold stochastic resonance, an effect where the mutual information rate between the input signal and the summed population response is maximized by a finite intrinsic noise strength. However, the different effects of the noise on spikes determine the population size for which suprathresholdt stochastic resonance is observed and by how much the mutual information rate is increased.

In this study we estimate the mutual information rate via its lower bound. To this end, we analytically derive the coherence function between input signal and the summed population response and the cross spectrum between different spike trains for the AD model and the STS model, respectively.
title: How does addition, deletion, or shifting of spikes by intrinsic noise affect signal transmission?

text: Sound localization relies on space dependent phase differences and magnitude modifications in the frequency spectrum of a sound. Until recently these magnitude modifications were thought to be exclusively induced by reflection of high-frequency sounds on external ear structures. Even though birds are capable of sound localization, they lack external ear structures and a high-frequency hearing. However we recently showed that the birds’ head induces the necessary magnitude modifications by diffraction. Here we show that diffraction not only works well with the low-frequency hearing of all birds, but that the avian head is especially efficient at diffracting sounds and their best hearing follows the onset of diffraction cues. Our results suggest that the birds’ low-frequency hearing is strongly linked to sound localization by diffraction, positioning itself opposite the mammalian high-frequency hearing linked to sound localization by reflection.
title: Sound localization by diffraction
