text:
Many theoretical studies of inhibition have focused on the goal to achieve a balance of excitation and inhibition. But such balance does not yet explain the emergence of powerful computational properties of networks of excitatory and inhibitory neurons. We investigate here the functional role of two inhibitory subnetworks in the arguably most common network motif of cortical microcircuits: ensembles of pyramidal cells (PCs) with lateral inhibition, commonly referred to as Winner-Take-All networks.
It has been shown in recent theoretical work (Keck et al., 2012; Habenschuss et al., 2012; Nessler et al., 2013) that spike-timing-dependent plasticity installs in this network motif an important and ubiquitously useful computational function: The emergence of sparse codes and Bayesian inference for repeatedly occurring high-dimensional spike patterns of upstream neurons (see Figure 1). This self-organization process can be related to one of the most interesting theoretical principles of statistical learning theory: Expectation Maximization.
However, this link has so far only been established for strongly simplified models with a symbolic implementation of lateral inhibition, rather than through the interaction of PCs with known types of inhibitory neurons. We close this gap and show that the interaction of PCs with two types of inhibitory networks, that reflect salient properties of somatic-targeting neurons (e.g. basket cells) and dendritic-targeting neurons (e.g. Martinotti cells), provides a good approximation to the theoretically optimal lateral inhibition needed for the self-organization of these network motifs. Our analysis suggests a new theoretical perspective on the functional role of dendritic-targeting interneurons: They modulate synaptic plasticity to compensate for unnormalized firing rates of PCs.
We provide a contribution towards closing the gap between biological data on diverse types of cortical interneurons and their putative function role.
title: Inhibitory networks orchestrate the self-organization of computational function in cortical microcircuit motifs through STDP

text:
Modern experimental technologies enable simultaneous recording of large neural populations. These high-dimensional data present a challenge for analysis. Recent work has focused on extracting low-dimensional dynamical trajectories that may underlie such responses. These methods enable visualization and may also provide insight into neural compuations. However, previous work focused on modeling a population’s dynamics without conditioning on external stimuli.

We propose a new technique that integrates linear dimensionality reduction (analogous to the STA and STC) with a latent dynamical system model of neural activity. Under our model, the spike response of a neural population is governed by a low- dimensional dynamical system with quadratic input. In this framework, the number of parameters grows linearly with population (size given fixed latent dimensionality). Hence, it is computationally fast for large populations, unlike fully-connected models.

Our method captures both noise correlations and low-dimensional stimulus selectivity through the simultaneous modeling of dynamics and stimulus dependence. This approach is particularly well-suited for studying the population activity of sensory cortices, where neurons often have substantial receptive field overlap.
title: Low-dimensional dynamical neural population models with shared stimulus drive

text:
During perceptual decisions the activity of sensory neurons co-varies with choice.  Previous findings suggest that this partially reflects “bottom-up” and “top-down” effects. However, the quantitative contributions of these effects are unclear. To address this question, we take advantage of the observation that past choices influence current behavior (sequential dependencies).    

Here, we use data from two macaque monkeys performing a disparity discrimination task during simultaneous extracellular recordings of disparity selective V2 neurons. We quantify the sequential dependencies using generalized linear models to predict choices or spiking activity of the V2 neurons. We find that past choices predict current choices substantially better than the spike counts on the current trial, i.e. have a higher “choice probability”. In addition, we observe that past choices have a significant predictive effect on the activity of sensory neurons on the current trial. This effect results from sequential dependencies of choices and neural activity alone, but also reflects a direct influence of past choices on the spike count on the current trial. 

We then use these sequential dependencies to dissect the neuronal co-variation with choice: We decomposed the choice co-variation of neural spike counts into components, which can be explained by behavior or neural activity on previous trials. We find that about 30% of the observed co-variation is already explained by the animals’ previous choice, suggesting a “top-down” contribution of at least 30%. Additionally, our results exemplify how variability frequently regarded as noise reflects the systematic effect of ignored neural and behavioral co-variates, and that interpretation of co-variations between neural activity and observed behavior should take the temporal context within the experiment into account.
title: Using sequential dependencies in neural activity and behavior to dissect choice related activity in V2

text:
In the mammalian auditory cortex, sound source position is represented by a population of broadly tuned neurons. Their firing is modulated by sounds located in all positions surrounding the animal. Peaks of the tuning curves are concentrated at lateral position, while their slopes are steepest at interaural midline, which allows for the highest localization accuracy in that area.
This experimental observations stand against initial expectations of finding a topographic cortical map of the auditory space. It has been concluded that a ''panoramic'' code has evolved to match specific demands of the sound localization task [1]. 
This work provides evidence suggesting that properties of spatial auditory neurons identified experimentally are a consequence of following a general design principle - learning a sparse, efficient representation of natural stimuli. 
A recording of binaural sounds was performed in different natural settings. Recorded stereo sounds served as an input to a hierarchical sparse-coding model. In its first layer, sounds in the left and the right ear were encoded by a population of complex-valued basis functions which separated phase and amplitude. Both parameters are known to carry information relevant for spatial hearing. Monaural input converged in the second layer, which learned a joint representation of amplitudes and interaural phase differences.
Spatial selectivity of each second-layer unit was measured by probing the model with natural sound sources recorded at different positions. Obtained tuning curves match well tuning characteristics of neurons in the auditory cortex of a monkey and of a cat.

This study connects neuronal coding of the auditory space with natural stimulus statistics and allows to form a number of experimental predictions. Additionally, results presented here suggest that cortical regions of seemingly very different or highly specific functions, may implement the same computational strategy - efficient coding.
title: A statistical model of natural stereo sounds reproduces properties of spatial representation in the mammalian auditory cortex

text:
As we navigate the world, multimodal sensory data streams are continuously parsed, in order to isolate and attend to salient and invariant features, upon which higher order cortical networks will operate, by evaluating the dynamic relations between such structural elements [1]⁠. The formation of stable representations of spatial/spectral environmental features (stimulus selectivity) along with the related ability to discriminate such features and their combinations is known to be continuously shaped by synaptic plasticity mechanisms, and it has been recently demonstrated that correlation-based inhibitory plasticity has an important role to play in such computations [2]. However, in order to adequately process information, neural circuits must not only develop stable internal representations of perceptual objects, but also reflect and represent the continuous unfolding structure of its input, which is poised with intricate temporal dependencies. Much less is currently known about the acquisition of complex temporal relations between stimuli and the (possibly specialized) role played by different adaptation mechanisms involved in this process. 
In this work, we study the properties of biologically realistic networks of LIF neurons, with differentially modulated, dynamic excitation and inhibition [2, 3]⁠. Input-specific neuronal assemblies are driven by stimulus sequences that contain complex temporal dependencies and signal propagation throughout these assemblies is gated by transient disruptions of E/I balance, in order to 'prime' the network to learn the underlying transitional probabilities and input statistics through targeted modifications. We explore the representational properties developed by these networks and the impact of the different plasticity rules in shaping the network's learning abilities while maintaining stable global dynamics. Furthermore, we assess the network's ability to extract complex temporal dependency rules between sequence elements.
title: Temporal sequence learning via adaptation in biologically plausible spiking neural networks

text:
In their natural environment, animals sense and evaluate olfactory cues of time-varying composition and concentration. Their olfactory pathways are adapted to the natural stimulus statistics, thus it is not surprising that odor processing is fast [1]. Honey bees, for example, learn to discriminate odors lasting as little as 200 ms [2]. The neural odor code in these animals emerges within 50ms after stimulus onset and neural representation changes dynamically during and after an odorant is present [1,3]. How is the insect olfactory system optimized to reliably estimate spatial and temporal aspects of the olfactory environment and what are the mechanisms behind rapid odor processing? 

In a previous work Farkhooi et al. [3] have shown that a sparse and reliable stimulus representation emerges naturally in a higher order center - the Mushroom Body (MB) - due to sequential adaptation. A adaptation conductance leads to a strong initial transient and an attenuated phasic response, progressively pronounced across sequential sensory processing stages. At the level of the Antennal Lobe (AL) - the primary olfactory center - odors instead evoke dense spatio-temporal patterns. To investigate odor encoding both at the AL and the MB level, we employ a simple  phenomenological spiking network model of the honeybee olfactory system. The model implements a transformation from a low dimensional dense odorant representation in the AL to a high dimensional sparse representation in the MB.

We demonstrate how information about the stimulus is present in both encoding schemes, by time resolved classification of neural activity. We show that a strong, transient response component at the AL level establishes a rapid odor code at the MB level for odorant identification and discrimination. Remarkably, persistent information about odor identity is present even after stimulus offset, indicating an odor after image.
title: Transformation between Neural Representations supports a Rapid Odor Code in a Spiking Model of the Insect Olfactory System

text:
Sensory perception can be understood as inference of latent causes underlying observed stimuli [1]. To perform such a task, humans and other animals need to learn the statistics of observations in terms of a generative model with latent variables corresponding to features of the environment. Visual information is represented in the cortex in a hierarchical fashion [2], of which the lowest level is well characterised by V1 receptive fields [3]. High-level object representation in the ventral hierarchy has also been widely studied [4], but understanding of intermediate levels and the nature of their interactions is still in its infancy [5]. 
Cognitive-level description of some of the top-down interactions in the visual hierarchy is provided by the results of gestalt psychology, both on the behavioural and physiological [6] levels. We formalised the gestalt effect in a probabilistic generative model of images. Such models have been proposed to describe numerous cortical functions [7], and have also been applied to image processing problems successfully [8]. However, the exact nature of dependence patterns of variables in cortical representations remains debated.
Our model characterises the statistics of the images in terms of covariance components of latent variables coupled to the pixels of the stimulus through a set of Gabor filters and observation noise. The components, corresponding to gestalts, can be learned from naturalistic images in an unsupervised fashion by an iterative expectation maximisation scheme. 
We compare the predictions on neural activity by probabilistic models aiming for independent latent representations [9], and our model, which assumes a tree-structured pattern of dependence between latent variables. We test the effect of top-down interactions on V1 activity and demonstrate alterations both in the correlation structure and variances of individual neurons depending on the presence of higher level statistical features of the stimulus.
title: Effects of higher-order statistics on activity in V1

text:
The Bernstein vision cognitive architecture [1] inspired from biological vision systems and model-driven systems engineering,  aims to develop a platform for multitude of vision applications with self-adaptation and autonomy [2]. To make such system robust and reliable we follow system engineering principles such as physics based modeling, component identification and domain characterization or contextual modeling at every stage: massively parallel hypothesis generation for decomposition, Reasoning and Model updates. In this work our focus is on illustrating how top-down contextual modeling establishes the correspondence between model space and space of possible design configurations for a given vision application with performance specification.  In essence, this can be viewed as an analog to the process in the brain where top-down expectations modulate the choice of invariant feature representations and parameters to facilitate rapid contraction dynamics to a solution.

In order to demonstrate the generality of the cognitive vision framework, we have used video surveillance and brake light detection in automotive domain as application examples.  In both these applications top-down expectations involving motion and geometry are exploited to design spatio-temporal filters (see for example [3]) that perform statistical hypotheses tests for classification of events. Both these applications utilize illumination and color invariants [4, 5, 6] in order to deal with large variations in lighting and environmental conditions. A common camera noise model is used as the basis for uncertainty characterization of the estimated results [7]. The resulting hypotheses generation subsystems involved deep architectures with filter pipelines involving convolutions followed by pooling/grouping and whose parameters are modulated by top-down expectations.
title: Top-down Contextual Modeling for Vision

text:
Neurons in the central nucleus of the main converging station in the auditory midbrain, the central nucleus of the inferior colliculus (ICC) have been shown to display either linear significant receptive fields [1] or both linear and nonlinear significant receptive fields [2].
In this study, we used reverse correlation to probe linear and nonlinear response properties of single neurons in the cat ICC. Spiking response were obtained from recordings of anesthetized cats in response to dynamic moving ripple (DMR) stimuli [3]. The DMR sound contains amplitude and frequency modulations and allows systematically mapping neural preferences. 
Spike-triggered average and covariance were computed for the envelope of the DMR, separately for each frequency carrier (range of 0-5.5 octaves). This enables studying processing of the sound envelope, and to investigate whether nonlinearities are more pronounced at the neuron’s preferred frequencies versus other frequencies.
We find that greater than half of neurons (n=120), display significant nonlinear response properties at least at one frequency carrier. Nonlinearities are dominant at the neuron’s best frequency. The nonlinear preferences can have either the same or opposite temporal receptive field pattern (e.g. on-off ) as the linear preferences. No relationship to other neural properties such as feature-selectivity, phase-locking, or the like has been found. Thus, these nonlinearities do not seem to be linked to a specific type of neuron but inherent to ICC neurons indicating a diverse range of filtering characteristics.
title: Spike-triggered covariance to probe nonlinear response properties in the inferior colliculus

text:
The primate motor, premotor, and parietal cortex play a crucial role for the planning and execution of hand movements. It has been shown that area F5 in the ventral premotor cortex and the anterior intraparietal area (AIP) carry information about grip type, wrist orientation, and hand shape during movement planning and execution. Here, we are investigating whether AIP and F5, in addition to this categorical information, also encode continuous movements by using spike signals from these areas in a non-human primate to detect and predict complete hand and arm movements and compare these to results obtained with signals from primary motor cortex (M1).
The detection of movement phases was carried out with a weighted Support Vector Machine and could be done almost equally accurately from signals in M1 or F5 (95% correct classification with M1, 94% with F5), whereas movement detection was significantly worse from AIP (85% correct). When decoding continuous hand and arm angles with a Kalman Filter, differences between M1 and F5 became more apparent: the mean correlation coefficient (CC) between real and decoded trajectories across all 27 DOF was 0.74 when using signals from M1 for decoding, whereas the CC was 0.67 for signals from F5 and 0.46 for AIP. 
These results indicate that both F5 and AIP carry information about continuous hand movements and movement timing, whereas AIP is less suited for continuous movement predictions. This information could be useful for future hand prosthetics.
title: Continuous detection and prediction of complete hand and arm kinematics from primate motor, premotor, and parietal cortex

text: Techniques to record many neurons in parallel have led to analyses of neuronal populations. Here, we focused on the fronto-parietal network of macaque monkey. Three monkeys performed a delayed grasping task where they had to grasp a handle.  All animals were implanted with 128 to 192 electrodes in AIP, F5, and M1. We recorded and analyzed populations of single neuron activity during 11 recording sessions. To reveal functional connectivity between all single neurons, we calculated crosscorrelograms (CCG) of all possible pairs. We applied graph theoretical analysis to the neuronal network. Results were power law-distributed indicating the presence of few highly connected neurons (hubs) in addition to a majority of only sparsely connected neurons. All datasets had significant smallworld values. Power spectrums of CCGs of hub-neurons compared with other neurons showed a strongly increased beta and delta power indicating an important role of oscillations to organize the functional network.
title: Role of beta and low frequency oscillations in functional network connectivity of single units in the primate motor system

text:
Nociceptors are primary afferent neurons responding to noxious mechanical or thermal stimuli. Spikes evoked from nociceptors are transmitted to the central nervous system and are thought to be perceived as pain. A central question is at what level in the nervous system thermal and mechanical stimuli conveyed by polymodal fibers are processed.
Detecting and encoding of noxious stimuli involves three main processes: transfer of stimulus in the skin to the receptor endings, generation of a receptor potential to trigger action potentials and generation of spike trains. We assess the processing using a modeling framework. Our framework consists of a stimulus transfer model, a probabilistic model of receptors and a parametric model of the firing rate.
To model the spike generation step we examined parametric models of stimulus-driven instantaneous firing rate of polymodal, unmylinated neurons. Each model consisted of two coupled ordinary differential equations (ODEs) describing the rate of an inhomogeneous point process. Two types of ODEs were investigated; one describing a linear adaptation process and another describing nonlinear, divisive adaptation. All neurons were well described by the nonlinear model, while the linear model failed to describe the firing rate variations for 3 out of 53 neurons (p<0.05, Monte-Carlo test). This finding assumed the neurons’ spikes to be generated from a Poisson process. We asked if a more elaborate point process, a Gamma process, captured spiking dynamics more accurately. Yet, modeling spikes by an inhomogeneous Gamma process often failed to capture the spiking properties (p<0.05, Monte-Carlo test, for 8 out of 80 neurons).
We are working on integrating a stimulus transfer model and a parametric model of receptor part. Our framework offers a novel method of analyzing and describing nociceptors that may enhance our understanding of different painful states and enable the functional classification of neuron subtypes in the periphery.
title: A parametric model of firing rates of pain evoked responses

text:
Recordings from the auditory receptors of Locusta migratoria reveal that the steady-state rate-intensity curve changes surprisingly little with temperature (Q10=1.5). This robustness benefits insect auditory communication, which has to be sustained over a broad range of temperatures and is predominantly limited by the temperature dependence of chemical rates [1]. The auditory receptors are excited by transduction currents from mechanoreceptors connected to a vibrating tympanum. Using a detailed biophysical model including a tympanal oscillator, as well as transduction and spike-generating membrane dynamics [2], this study explains (i) how a temperature-invariant rate-intensity curve can originate in a model with stochastic ion channels and what role the different noise sources may play; and (ii) how stimulus coding is affected in different frequency ranges. 

The effect of temperature on auditory computation is versatile. Temperature speeds up reaction rates, shapes the spectral content of ion-current fluctuations, and scales the variance of thermal noise. In deterministic models, temperature is known to shift the rheobase, i.e. the spiking threshold [3]. Here we show that close to the rheobase, where the receptors are fluctuation driven, this effect can be compensated by a noise-induced increase in firing rate. In addition to coding the average input amplitude into the average response rate, the grasshopper auditory system also evaluates the temporal structure of species-specific sound messages. To probe how temperature modifies this ability, we calculate the signal-response coherence and spike-train metrics. We find that spike jitter tends to decrease with temperature. More specifically, the signal-to-noise ratio for higher frequencies improves with increasing temperature. Based on the model, the observed effects are dissected and attributed to the temperature dependence of the deterministic dynamical system as well as the stochastic noise processes involved.
title: Temperature dependence of spike jitter in an insect auditory receptor

text: Visual working memory (VWM) is a highly limited storage system. A basic consequence of this fact is that visual memories cannot perfectly encode or represent the structure of the world. Many existing computational models of VWM assume that visual memories are noise-corrupted versions of afferent perceptual signals. However, this additive noise assumption oversimplifies the problem facing memory. When errors in visual memory are potentially costly to the organism, it is possible to reduce the probability of certain errors, but this comes at the expense of increasing the probability of other errors. This is a basic consequence of results in information theory (Shannon & Weaver, 2009; Sims, Jacobs, & Knill, 2012). Thus, implicit in the behavioral phenomena of VWM is the concept of a loss function: a mathematical entity that describes the relative cost to the organism of making different types of memory errors. The theoretical construct of a loss function features prominently in research on perception and motor control (Körding & Wolpert, 2004; Maloney & Zhang, 2010; Sims, Jacobs, & Knill, 2011; Wolpert & Landy, 2012), but to date has not been explored in the context of visual working memory. Using this framework, it is possible to define an optimally efficient VWM system as one that minimizes expected loss according to some loss function, while subject to a constraint on memory capacity. By adopting the approach of inverse decision theory (Körding & Wolpert, 2004), I demonstrate that it is also possible to infer or estimate the loss function of human VWM from behavioral data in a delayed recall experiment. The empirical loss function estimated from this process is substantially different from that assumed (implicitly) by existing models of VWM. Consequently, incorporating the construct of a loss function allows for an excellent quantitative fit to empirical data, while enriching the theoretical vocabulary for understanding and explaining human visual memory.
title: What is the loss function of visual working memory?

text: High-level visual representations often display a remarkable degree of invariance with respect to low-level changes such as translation, scaling or lighting conditions. The slowness learning approach assumes that although primary retinal signals are changing rapidly in time, the behaviorally relevant visual elements causing them typically change slowly in time. Thus, invariant representations could be learned by extracting slowly changing information from low-level inputs [1]. In previous analytical work [2], we suggested that this form of learning could be implemented in spiking neurons using spike timing-dependent plasticity (STDP), but this idea has proven to be difficult to realize in simulations because the “slowness” driving force turns out to be a second-order effect. Here, we demonstrate that this problem can be overcome by combining excitatory STDP with a balance of excitation and feedforward inhibition. To this end, we simulate an integrate-and-fire neuron receiving both excitatory and inhibitory time-varying inputs, with STDP on the excitatory connections and a recently suggested Hebbian rule on the inhibitory connections [3]. The latter establishes a balance of excitation and inhibition, which causes the neuron to emit spikes primarily during upswings of the excitatory drive, i.e., during input transients. STDP caused by these spikes could potentiate the input before and depress the input after the transient, thereby reducing the transient and effectively favoring slower signals since they produce smaller transients. Our simulations show that such a neuron can indeed tune its weights in favor of more slowly changing input signals over a relatively wide range of input signal time constants. We discuss the conditions on the excitatory STDP learning window for which this approach is functional.
title: Tuning a Spiking Neuron to Slowly-Changing Input Signals using STDP

text: Neurons in the hippocampal formation exhibit a variety of spatially tuned firing patterns [e.g., 1]. Whereas place cells in the hippocampus proper are tuned to a single location in the environment, grid cells and band cells [2] in the entorhinal cortex display spatially periodic activity. Head-direction cells are tuned to the animal’s orientation in space and found in several brain regions including the hippocampal formation. A subset of periodically firing cells, referred to as conjunctive cells, also show a tuning to head-direction. The mechanisms by which these different spatial tuning patterns emerge are not fully resolved, although a variety of competing computational models exists for each of them [e.g., 3]. Here we present a new model that can generate all aforementioned spatial firing patterns by a single mechanism. The model consists of a feedforward network with spatially tuned input projecting to a single output neuron. The essential ingredient is an interaction between excitatory and inhibitory Hebbian plasticity [4], where the latter aims to maintain a constant output firing rate by balancing excitation and inhibition. Depending on the relative spatial specificity of the excitatory and inhibitory input, the output neuron develops firing patterns that are similar to those of place, grid or band cells. Furthermore, if the spatially tuned input is endowed with head-direction selectivity, the output tuning resembles that of head-direction and conjunctive cells. A mathematical analysis of the network for a single spatial dimension matches the numerical results. In contrast to attractor models [5], our model predicts that the grid spacing should be robust to global modifications in inhibitory synaptic strength.
title: A unified model for the diverse spatial firing patterns in the hippocampal formation

text: Synchronized (i.e., zero time-lagged) oscillations carry functional benefits by dampening variability and enhancing the reliability of responses to stimuli [1]. On the other hand, theoretical work has shown that networks of cortical cells have the ability to generate asynchronous (i.e., time-lagged) spikes [2] and experimental work suggests that this form of coding may be tied to information processing [3]. Here, we employ a computational model to explore the benefits of synchronous and asynchronous oscillations in networks of spiking neurons. Starting from a model of randomly connected leaky integrate-and-fire neurons that generated spontaneous activity (Fig.1A), we injected oscillations by adding a sine wave to the subthreshold membrane potential of all cells. Synchronized oscillations were induced by adjusting this wave such that its phase was the same across all neurons (Fig.1B). For asynchronous oscillations, each neuron received a wave at a unique phase (Fig.1C). We then examined the ability of networks to respond reliably and discriminate between large depolarizing events delivered to random subsets of the population. We show that synchronized cells responded more reliably than asynchronous networks to repeated presentations of a stimulus. On the other hand, asynchronous networks were better able to discriminate between distinct stimuli. These results highlight a trade-off between reliability and stimulus discrimination. Using a principal components analysis, we examined the responses of a network that received two stimuli, each presented ten times. Asynchronous networks yielded trajectories that were clearly separable, while the trajectories of synchronous networks could not be linearly separated. Hence, asynchronous activity was the only regime where a downstream linear classifier could distinguish the two stimuli straightforwardly. We suggest that neuronal networks take advantage of both forms of coding depending on the context and requisites of the task.
title: From chaos to control: Using oscillations to harness neuronal networks

text: Networks of oscillators have been extensively studied over the past years yielding new forms of complex self-organized dynamics. In particular, new insights on collective phenomena, as the repetitive switching among different states of synchrony [1,2], led to novel approaches to neural computation [3,4]. Recent works have shown that the switching dynamics of heteroclinic networks can be used in order to solve complex tasks as bit-wise operations [5]. Nevertheless, whether this switching process could be used to reliably process signals coming from physical sensors is still an open question. Here we demonstrate that heteroclinic networks can robustly perform computation on real-time sensory input. More specifically, we implement obstacle avoidance in an e-puck robot platform. Our results show that computation by neural switching reliably performs navigational tasks and may constitute the basis for more complex autonomous behaviors.
title: Robust heteroclinic computation on real-time sensory data

text:
Visual motion perception depends on the responses of direction selective neurons in the middle temporal visual area (MT). The timecourse of these responses exhibits two distinct components: a high amplitude on-response followed by a lower sustained level of activity. For the sustained phase previous studies have documented a multiplicative modulation by spatial attention. Here we focused on comparing MT responses to the onset of attended or unattended moving stimuli. 
Responses of 127 MT neurons were recorded from two monkeys trained to perform a spatial attention task: while the monkey maintained its gaze on a central point, a stationary random dot pattern (RDP) was briefly shown either inside or outside the receptive field (RF) signaling the location of the upcoming “target”. After a brief blank period, two moving RDPs appeared inside and outside the RF. Both moved in one of 12 equally spaced directions. After random periods, the direction (or speed) of each RDP changed. The monkey had to detect the motion change in the target and to ignore the similar changes at the other location to get a fluid reward.
Comparing the population direction-tuning curves during the sustained response when spatial attention was directed into and out of the RF confirmed previous findings: a multiplicative modulation of the MT sustained response. In contrast, while MT on-responses were enhanced by spatial attention for motion directions in or close to the preferred direction, they were suppressed when the stimulus was moving in or close to the anti-preferred direction. This was accompanied by a small decrease in the tuning width resulting in the sharpening of the direction-tuning curve. This suggests that the influence of spatial attention varies between the on- and sustained-response. Attention multiplicatively enhances the sustained response, but exerts a push-pull effect on the transient representation of motion.

title: Attentional influence on neuronal responses in primate visual cortex to the onset of visual motion

text:
A recently developed autoencoder model, called Non-Negative Sparse Auto Encoder (NNSAE), is able to extract features that can be nicely interpreted by humans while being simple with respect to its implementation [1]. In this work we analyze the difficult interplay of the three different learning mechanisms, namely a regularization towards non-negativity, a homeostatic intrinsic plasticity (IP) condition [2] and a gradient-descent-based heuristic learning rule, which together constitute the model.

In a first part we examine the heuristic learning scheme and discuss the difference from an analytically exact gradient descent. Our extensive experimental results show the significant defect of the simplifying heuristics as a general learning rule. Nevertheless we can confirm the superiority of this simplification in experiments for the special case of this model, where the learning rule is combined with a strong regularization for positive weights. In a second part we analyze the diverse behavior of the model with respect to different parameter setting. We show how the reconstruction error of the autoencoder varies under variation of the target mean activity of the IP and variation of the strength of the regularization. We show that these two learning parameters are systematically linked such that for every value of the strength of the regularization there is a different optimal target value for the IP with respect to the model quality. Finally in a third part we explore a new approach to modeling the target of IP in the context of autoencoder networks. We show that learning rules for a more complex and possibly bimodal distribution as target of the homeostasis are analytically tractable using the same techniques as in [2] and we discuss the consequences of this bimodality for the interpretability of the learned features and the quality of the model.
title: Interplay of Multiple Learning Rules for Non-Negative Sparse Auto-Encoders

text: The monkey anterior intraparietal area (AIP) encodes visual information about three-dimensional object shape that is used to shape the hand for grasping. In robotics a similar role has been played by modules that fit point cloud data to the superquadric family of shapes and its various extensions. We developed a model of shape tuning in AIP based on cosine tuning to superquadric parameters. However, the model did not fit the data well, and we also found that it was difficult to accurately reproduce these parameters using neural networks with the appropriate inputs (modelled on the caudal intraparietal area, CIP). The latter difficulty was related to the fact that there are large discontinuities in the superquadric parameters between very similar shapes. To address these limitations we adopted an alternative shape parameterization based on an Isomap nonlinear dimension reduction. The Isomap was built using gradients and curvatures of object surface depth. This alternative parameterization was low-dimensional (like superquadrics), but data-driven (similar to an alternative clustering approach that is also sometimes used in robotics) and lacked large discontinuities. Isomaps with 16 or more dimensions reproduced the AIP data fairly well. Moreover, we found that the Isomap parameters could be approximated from CIP-like input much more accurately than the superquadric parameters. We conclude that Isomaps, or perhaps alternative dimension reductions of CIP signals, provide a promising model of AIP tuning. We have now started to integrate our model with a robot hand, to explore the efficacy of Isomap shape reductions in grasp planning. Future work will consider dynamics of spike responses and integration with related visual and motor area models.
title: A computational model of the anterior intraparietal area

text:
Despite the steady advances in the experimental techniques the modelling approach remains the main tool for evaluating the many hypothesis put forth by theoretical neuroscientists. In the current work we aim to study the roles of feed-forward and feed-back connections in visual processing in the thalamocortical system via a large-scale model containing more than 60 000 Hodgkin-Huxley-like neurons. In particular we are interested in the mechanisms underlying figure-ground segregation[1].
Our work is inspired by a model proposed by Hill and Tononi in 2005[2], but contains multiple adaptations. To realistically capture the dynamics of the thalamocortical system, the model incorporates two cortical areas each consisting of three separate layers, two thalamic areas with the distinction between thalamic core and matrix cells, the thalamic reticular nucleus and the respective inhibitory neurons in all areas. The synaptic connections between the areas are based on our current knowledge about the circuitry within the thalamocortical system. Extensive calibrations were performed to fit the behaviour of the neuron models to in-vivo measurements from different areas. Also the optic-tract firing patters that serve as input to the model are designed to capture the retinal synchrony described in recent studies[3].
The model allows us to study the effect that different connections have on the figure-ground computation as it is handed to progressively higher cortical areas. In particular, we compute measures of synchrony and edge enhancement to evaluate how the figure-ground segregation varies in different areas. To establish the role of feedback we manipulate the model in two different ways. First we bias the activity in higher areas to simulate a top-down flow of information to lower areas. Second, we change the strengths and connectivity patterns of feedback connections. We believe that the model can be applied to study a wide range of processes occurring in visual cortex.
title: A detailed thalamocortical model for studying figure-ground segregation

text: We will present a simple simulation of a dynamic system modeling a process of visual perception.  Our target application is the extraction of intrinsic images (albedo, surface shape) from image input, a task addressed previously with the help of statistical models, as in [1]. The system conforms to an architecture presented in outline before [2].  The system models participating sub-modalities (image gray-level, albedo, surface tilt, illumination) as two-dimensional sheets populated locally by feature spaces.  Alternate values of features are represented by units, initial uncertainty in feature values is represented by activity distributions, a tendency to collapse uncertainty is implemented by mutual inhibition between alternate values of the same variable.  Constraints on admissible or preferred constellations of feature values are implemented with the help of excitatory connections.  These come in two forms.  "Vertical" connections run between units in different modalities referring to the same image point.  They implement constraints combinations of local variables in different sub-modalities must conform to.  "Horizontal" connections run between units referring to different image points within the same modality.  They implement memory for (statistical distributions of) fields of feature values encountered in the past.  The system is subject to instabilities keeping it from converging properly.  We will present several preventive measures, among them a coarse-to-fine strategy, and will show results on runs with successful convergence.  The model is based on a software system written in C++, based on a number of classes for such processes as setting up a new modality field, installing various kinds of connectivity patterns, protocolling and diagnosing the system with a number of graphic tools.  The design of the system is optimized for easy extension to more modalities and more memory patterns.
title: A Simple Dynamic Model for Image Interpretation

text:
The perceived color of an object depends not only on the spectral composition of the light reflected from its surface, but also on the visual context such as illumination and background color. Such contextual interactions are thought to underlie perceptual phenomena like color constancy. A possible neuronal basis may be lateral interactions which manifest in contextual influence on the tuning of color-selective neurons in the visual cortex (Wachtler et al., 2003).
Here we present a model of cortical color processing that predicts color shifts induced by chromatic backgrounds as observed in psychophysical studies. The model assumes that stimulus hue is encoded by a population of neurons with Gaussian tuning curves and preferences distributed in color space, corresponding to the finding of distributed color preferences in primary visual cortex (Lennie et al 1990). Lateral inhibitory interactions between neurons sharing the same color preferences are modeled by a Difference-of-Gaussian interaction kernel. No interactions between color channels are assumed.  Due to the contextual modulation the readout of the population response showed systematic shifts in the encoded stimulus hue when stimuli were presented on colored backgrounds. The induced shifts depended on the distance between stimulus and background hues in colorspace, but were always directed away from the hue of the background. The specific shapes of the resulting induction effects strongly depended on the configuration of the population code, like the density distribution and widths of the tuning curves. Specifically, anisotropic distribution of tuning curves resulted in dependencies of the induction strength and distribution on the location in color space, in line with effects observed in psychophysical studies.  The results indicate that important computations in color vision that lead to perceptual hue shifts can be realized using simple neural mechanisms when color is represented by a distributed code.
title: Lateral interactions in an anisotropic population code for color predict human color induction effects

references.text: Dold, H.M.H. (2012). On modeling data from visual psychophysics: A Bayesian graphical model approach. Ph.D. Technische Universität Berlin.

text:
In vision science, image driven models relate image content to behavior on certain observation tasks. These models generally follow a common structure: a subband decomposition (e.g. Steerable Pyramid, Gabor filter bank) followed by non-linear operations (e.g. point nonlinearities, divisive contrast normalization, Minkowski norm pooling) followed by a decoding or readout stage.

Most models of early vision fit their parameters using maximum likelihood estimation. While this provides point-estimates of parameters, and can provide rough estimates of variance, its model description lacks sufficient detail to explore parameter interactions. We describe a method of representing models of early vision as Bayesian graphical models. This allows sampling of the posterior distribution of the parameter space using MCMC methods. These sampling procedures provide insight not only in point estimates, but also accurate estimates of parameter variances and interactions.

This work builds on work by Dold (2012) whose analysis showed frequency sensitivity artefacts. We explored this problem further, discovering that subband decompositions represent frequencies at or between filter peak-frequencies very differently, and these representations get treated differently by non-linearities, essentially leading to frequency- and orientation-aliasing. We solve this problem using a novel image-decomposition technique which samples the frequency and orientation domain (quasi) continuously and uses point process statistics to generate robust image sampling distributions.

We aim at integrating this new decomposition with our early-vision model and continuing our model analysis. Through improvements to general model architecture and analysis methods we take a step towards better, more robust models of early vision.
title: Towards robust models of early vision

text:
A longstanding hypothesis claims that spatio-temporally structured input in neural circuits enhances precision and reliability of spiking responses. While studies in single neurons well support this hypothesis both experimentally and theoretically (e.g. [1-3]) the impact of input structure on the dynamics of recurrent networks is not well understood. The high dimensional and often chaotic dynamics of large recurrent networks requires a type of analysis that is sensitive to recurrent interactions and characterizes the networks collective dynamics [4-11]. 

To address this challenge, we here demonstrate how the analysis of dynamical stability and entropy production can be generalized for examining balanced networks driven by a stream of input spike trains. Previous studies of the dynamic stability of the balanced state used a constant external input [4-9] or white noise [10-11].  An analytical expression for the Jacobian of the flow enables us to calculate the full Lyapunov spectrum. Using a single neuron model in which action potential onset rapidness can be adjusted we solved the dynamics in numerically exact event-based simulations and calculated Lyapunov spectra, dynamical entropy production rate and attractor dimension. We examined different scenarios to study the transition from constant to stochastic input, varying the Poisson rate and/or Poisson coupling strength, while keeping the firing rate of the driven population fixed. 

We demonstrate a suppression of chaos by input spike trains, for the first time extending studies of chaotic rate models to spiking neuron models [12-13]. This finding holds both for variations of input Poisson rate and Poisson coupling strength and is robust to deviations from Poisson statistics. Our study provides insight into the role of sensory streams in shaping the chaotic dynamics of large networks.
title: Input spike trains suppress chaos in balanced neural circuits

text:
First spike latencies and stationary inter-spike time intervals have been extensively used to characterize the information transfer capacities of various sensory neurons [1-5]. However, neither the importance of the contributions of these two response properties to encoding particular stimulus features nor their relation to the molecular organization of the sensory neurons are well understood.
Here, we computationally studied information transfer properties in terms of the First Event Latencies (FEL) and stationary Inter-Event time Intervals (sIEI) of the neurotransmitter release events at inner hair cell ribbon synapses. In particular, we considered mutual information carried by FEL/sIEI about intensities of sound tone bursts applied in silent background. We investigated how the mutual information depends on the presynaptic active zone organization, which was suggested to vary considerably from synapse to synapse [6,7]. We used a computational model which took into account the main aspects of the presynaptic active zone organization relevant for neurotransmitter release: release face topography, kinetics of the presynaptic Ca2+ channel gating, kinetics of Ca2+ binding to the Ca2+ sensor of exocytosis, and synaptic vesicle replenishment.
We found that, depending on the presynaptic active zone organization, information carried by the FEL is either higher or lower than the information carried by the sIEI. Moreover, the theoretical lower bound for the information carried by the FEL is always considerably higher than 0 bits, whereas the information carried by the sIEI can be arbitrarily close to 0 bits. In the later case, the transient part of the response carries the greatest part of information about the stimulus intensity in the whole release event pattern. We also found that subsequent sIEIs are weakly correlated in all cases considered. Thus, full information transfer rate by a neurotransmitter release pattern in steady state is determined mainly by the sIEI.
title: Stimulus Intensity Encoding by First Event Latencies versus Steady State Inter-Event Time Intervals of Neurotransmitter Release Events at Inner Hair Cell Ribbon Synapses

text:
During perception the brain combines sensory information with an internal model representing prior information about the outside world [1]. While the mathematical concept of probabilistic inference has previously been suggested as a framework for understanding this process [2][3], deriving testable predictions for the spiking activity of sensory neurons has been a challenge because neither the internal model that the brain has learnt, nor how it represents probabilities, is readily available.

We show how to derive such predictions in the context of psychophysical tasks without relying on specific assumptions about how probabilities are represented in the brain. Assuming that sensory neurons represent posterior probabilities, Bayes' rule implies a symmetry between bottom-up and top-down connections. Based on this insight we derive empirically testable relationships between stimulus-evoked quantities like choice probability or signal correlation and choice-related observables like tuning curve slope or noise correlation. Crucially, these relationships differ from the predictions of the signal-detection framework that is traditionally used to understand perceptual decision-making [3] and therefore allow us to differentially test these two frameworks using empirical data. Furthermore, we show how to use the observed noise correlations to infer the 'principal components' of the internal model used by the brain to perform the task.

We apply our framework to the noise correlations reported in a task-switching paradigm [5]. This reveals that the internal model used by their monkeys consists of a superposition of stimulus detection and discrimination components and reflects a large degree of task uncertainty (Fig 1A). Applying our framework to the output of a previously presented neural-sampling-based model [6] (Fig 1B) we make predictions for the effect of perceptual learning and can explain the reduction in average noise correlation observed empirically [7] (Fig 1C).
title: Inferring the brain's task-strategy from neuronal responses during perceptual decision-making

text:
Spontaneous activity and trial-to-trial variability in neocortical recordings have long been assumed to reflect intrinsic cortical noise. However, it has been shown that spontaneous activity is highly structured in space and time (1,2), contributes to trial-to-trial variability of subsequent evoked sensory responses (3) and predicts subsequent perceptual decisions (4). Furthermore, it has been demonstrated that variability in neural activity decreases with stimulus onset (5). These findings are consistent with the „sampling hypothesis“(6), according to which instantaneous population activity corresponds to samples from a posterior distribution over the represented variables.

In this study, we demonstrate that many of these phenomena can be accounted for by a deterministic self-organizing recurrent neural network model (SORN, (7)). The network consists of excitatory and inhibitory McCulloch-Pitts neurons learning a model of structured input sequences through a combination of STDP and homeostatic forms of plasticity. When confronted with previously unseen ambiguous inputs, the network approximates a Bayesian inference operation by appropriately combining the sensory input with prior knowledge encoded in the learnt network parameters. Furthermore, the network matches many of the key findings on spontaneous activity and neural variability outlined above and samples frequent input sequences during phases of spontaneous activity. While doing so, it also reproduces the lognormal statistics of synaptic connection strengths observed in cortex. The simplicity of our model suggests that these features are canonical properties of recurrent networks learning with a combination of STDP and homeostatic plasticity mechanisms. Overall, our results demonstrate that the complex dynamics of a deterministic self-organizing recurrent neural network can approximate sampling-like inference while capturing key features of neural variability at the single unit and network levels.
title: Self-organized learning and inference explain key properties of neural variability

reasonForTalk: We describe a fundamentally new insight into synaptic information transmisson in cortex
text: Cortical neurons fire in a highly irregular manner, suggesting that their input is tightly balanced and changes in presynaptic firing rate are encoded primarily in the variance of the postsynaptic currents. Here we show that such balance has a surprising effect on information transmission: Synaptic unreliability – which is ubiquitous in cortex and usually thought to impair neural communication – actually increases the information rate. We show that the beneficial effect of noise is based on a very general mechanism which contrary to stochastic resonance does not rely on a threshold nonlinearity.
title: Synaptic unreliability facilitates information transmission in balanced cortical populations

text:
While the replay of hippocampal place cell sequences during sharp-wave ripples (SWRs) has been proposed as a potential correlate of memory recall [1], recent results also suggest a role in memory-guided decision-making during goal-directed behavior [2]. Inspired by these observations, we present a novel computational model of how hippocampal place-cell sequences during awake sharp-wave ripples determine a navigational goal. The model is based on two main computational properties: (1) Continuous attractor dynamics during sharp-wave ripples generate sequential activity of place cells, progressing toward the peak location of spatially heterogeneous input to CA3. (2) The heterogeneity in CA3 inputs is caused by reward-modulated plasticity in the inputs to dentate granule cells [3]. This form of plasticity biases DG place cell firing rates during theta rhythm, progressively strengthening DG inputs to CA3 place cells with fields near the reward location. 
In contrast to previous accounts of hippocampal replay based on sequence learning (e.g., [4]), sequential activity in our model does not require previous experience of the corresponding trajectories. In fact, the constructive nature of the sequences can be viewed as a predictive process biased by memory. The model makes an explicit proposal about the role of awake sharp-wave ripple activity in spatial memory, consistent with recent observations of impaired goal navigation after SWR disruption [2], and suggests a mechanism for the goal-predictive nature of sequential place-cell activity in open-field type mazes [5].
title: Goal anticipation in a computational model of place-cell sequences during sharp wave-ripples

text:
Knee-Ankle-Foot-Orthoses (KAFOs) are modular lower-extremity orthoses prescribed to people with gait disability. KAFOs should support, correct and assist the movement of the corresponding affected joints. Traditional controllers depend on non-adaptive thresholds to switch between selected control values; therefore, they lack flexibility to adjust to common disturbances (i.e., floor unevenness, obstacles, ramps) in a satisfactory way. Novel approaches include active elements, which do not directly act on the movement. Instead they allow continuous adjustment of parameters like the affected joint's damping, leading to new challenges for the controller of such actuators.

To use the full continuous range the active element offers and to overcome shortcomings of traditional control approaches, adaptive methods like artificial neural networks (ANN) are applied. These methods can manage the active element's flexibility and the high neuromuscular variability within specific patient groups, allowing individual support of a wider range of patients. Model based tracking[1,2] of the user's gait allows to overcome the problems of finite state switching.

This study evaluates a combination of reflexive feed forward controller[3] with history dependent internal motion models for gait switching. A reflexive core allows the controller to react immediately to external influences. Gait models continuously track the user's gait and switch gait support accordingly. The controller operates a KAFO based on a controllable hydraulic damper, derived from OttoBock's C-Leg©. 

Our investigations indicate, that the presented gait models are an accurate and fast adaptive method for detection of the current gait. They fit well into and extend the used paradigm of adaptive modular neuro-control[3]. The reflexive feed forward controller benefits from the combination with the history dependent gait models in kind of enhanced precision via the motion model's detailed knowledge of the gait dynamics.
title: Internal Models Enhance Accuracy and Reaction Time for a Gait-Aware Knee-Ankle-Foot-Orthosis

reasonForTalk: Collective dynamics determine information flow patterns, revealed from data and not from theory
text: How does information flow through cortical networks: via fixed and discrete internal pathways or via routes that are continuously dynamically reconfigured? Here we show, through information theoretical analysis of LFP and single unit recordings, that functional connectivity maps between entorhinal cortex neurons display dynamic reconfiguration between theta and slow oscillations in vivo. At the level of field potentials, the flow information follows fixed paths within and between cortical layers in a brain state-dependent manner. In contrast, at the single cell level, the information flows in continuously reconfiguring networks, without changing the global amount of transferred information. We conclude that information processing operates differently at different scales: it is "liquid" at the neuronal scale, whilst it follows stable pathways at the network scale. Both modus operandi are brain-state specific, with theta oscillations being associated generally to enhanced information transmission between cortical layers.
title: Brain state-dependent "liquid" information processing

text:
The interplay of excitatory and inhibitory activity in neuronal populations is finely regulated within cortical layers. One of the key regulatory mechanisms is gain modulation, in which the amplitude of response changes while the cell's selectivity remains unaffected [1]. However, given the non-linear integration that occurs in dendrites, it is unclear how gain is modulated when the input is located at synaptic locations located throughout the dendritic arbor. 

For investigating and manipulating this balance of activity, optogenetics is a powerful tool due to the fine temporal and spatial precision it provides. Furthermore, due to the development of excitatory (e.g. channelrhodopsin ChR2) and silencing opsins (e.g. halorhodopsin NpHR), dendritic arbors can be optically coactivated independently. This provides the opportunity to examine how competing excitatory and inhibitory inputs for differing spatial and temporal patterns of activation modulate gain in individual neurons. 

We investigate this relation by testing optical activation in abstracted neuron morphologies that include models of ChR2 and NpHR [2,3]. By extending a simple ball-and-stick model, we created a family of neural morphologies that varied in polarity and branching of the dendritic trees. External driving input is provided as current injection or as multiple synaptic-like events at locations on dendrites, rather than the soma, to mimic inputs for both in vitro and in vivo scenarios. Using these models, we can predict the ability of a neuron to modulate gain based on its dendritic morphology. Finally, we test detailed biophysical models of Layer 5 Pyramidal cells and Layer 4 stellate cells and confirm our findings from abstract models. 

Our results highlight the role of dendritic morphology and the localized contribution of excitatory and inhibitory activity in gain modulation. Importantly, our model allows us to form experimental illumination strategies that are tailored to neuronal morphology.
title: Reprogramming the balance of excitation-inhibiton via optical coactivation to control neuronal gain modulation

text:
During the last two decades various methods such as high-frequency deep brain stimulation (DBS) have been developed for the treatment of oscillations associated with several pathological conditions, e.g. in Parkinson's disease [Perlmutter and Mink 2006]. These methods have been traditionally based on open-loop strategies, that is on fixed, predetermined stimulation parameters. They are highly effective in quenching the aberrant oscillations and, thus, in alleviating the clinical symptoms. At the same time, however, they introduce undesirable side effects and in most cases they do not restore the network transfer function. Recently, adaptive control strategies have emerged, which promise to increase the efficacy of the existing stimulation methods for the control and correction of the network activity dynamics [Priori et al. 2013]. 

Here, we investigate the effects of adaptive, closed-loop control schemes on networks of spiking neurons. Specifically, we design an appropriate control strategy, based on delayed state-feedback to quench sparse or stochastic oscillations, which closely resemble the pathological oscillations and are known to be robust compared to synchronous regular activity [Brunel and Hakim 2008]. Our control protocol is able to sufficiently suppress these stochastic oscillations and to drive the network in an asynchronous irregular regime. Importantly, the network transfer function, defined as the ratio of the population rate response to incoming stimuli, is also recovered. Our results thus suggest that adaptive state-feedback control is a promising strategy to design brain stimulation protocols to correct the aberrant dynamics without inducing strong side-effects.
title: Adaptive feedback control of pathological oscillations in spiking neural networks
